questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents with rapidly developing, hemorrhagic bullous lesions on his hand 12 hours after a dog bite. He has no history of immunosuppression or splenectomy. Culture of the wound is pending. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of this skin presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Staphylococcus aureus

 

  • In immunocompetent individuals, bullous hemorrhagic lesions following a dog bite are classically associated with β-hemolytic streptococci and Staphylococcus aureus, particularly methicillin-resistant strains (MRSA). 
  • S. aureus is a common pathogen in animal bite wound infections and can cause rapidly progressive bullous skin lesions due to its potent toxins (e.g., exfoliative toxin).
  • Although Capnocytophaga canimorsus is transmitted through dog bites and can cause serious systemic illness, its classic presentation is fulminant sepsis, DIC, and renal failure—especially in asplenic or immunocompromised hosts—not localized hemorrhagic bullae in healthy individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Capnocytophaga canimorsus: This is indeed part of the dog’s oral flora and can be transmitted via bites. However, it primarily causes sepsis and systemic complications (e.g., DIC, renal failure) in immunocompromised or asplenic patients, not localized hemorrhagic bullous lesions in healthy hosts.

 

Option B. Pasteurella multocida: More commonly associated with cat bites, though it can be found in dog bite wounds too. It typically causes rapid-onset cellulitis with purulent discharge, and necrotizing fascitis but is not characteristically linked to bullous hemorrhagic lesions.

 

Option D. Bacteroides fragilis: An anaerobic organism found in polymicrobial infections following bite wounds but not a primary agent of hemorrhagic bullae or rapid skin necrosis. Typically involved in deep tissue anaerobic infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In immunocompetent individuals, hemorrhagic bullous skin lesions following dog bites are most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus or β-hemolytic streptococci. 
  • Capnocytophaga is more commonly associated with systemic complications in immunosuppressed or asplenic patients.

questions.text: Which of the following actions is primarily affected due to injury to the muscle attached at the marked site?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Abduction

 

  • The marked area in the image is the greater trochanter of the femur, which serves as the attachment site for muscles such as the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus. 
  • These muscles are critical for the abduction of the thigh at the hip joint. They help to move the leg laterally and stabilize the pelvis during activities like walking.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adduction: Incorrect. Adduction of the thigh involves muscles like the adductor longus, adductor magnus, and gracilis, which attach to the medial side of the thigh and not to the greater trochanter.

 

Option B. Flexion: Incorrect. Thigh flexion is primarily performed by muscles such as the iliopsoas and rectus femoris, not the gluteus medius or gluteus minimus.

 

Option D. Extension: Incorrect. Thigh extension involves muscles like the gluteus maximus and hamstrings, which are not attached to the greater trochanter.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscles, which attach to the greater trochanter of the femur, are responsible for abduction of the thigh.
  • These muscles also play a crucial role in stabilizing the pelvis during ambulation.

choices.text: Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) less than 115 mm

questions.text: A 15-month-old child is brought to the primary health center for nutritional assessment. The healthcare worker is evaluating the child for Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) using WHO criteria. All of the following are diagnostic criteria for SAM in children aged 6-59 months except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Weight-for-age Z-score less than -3 SD

 

  • According to WHO criteria for diagnosing Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) in children aged 6-59 months, the diagnostic criteria include: Weight-for-height Z-score <-3 SD, MUAC <115 mm, or presence of bilateral pitting edema.
  • Weight-for-age Z-score <-3 SD is a criterion for underweight, not specifically for SAM. 
  • SAM diagnosis focuses on wasting (acute malnutrition) rather than underweight, which can be due to both acute and chronic malnutrition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Weight-for-height Z-score less than -3 SD: Weight-for-height Z-score <-3 SD is a standard WHO criterion for diagnosing SAM, indicating severe wasting.

 

Option B. Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) less than 115 mm: MUAC <115 mm is a WHO criterion for SAM diagnosis and is widely used for community screening.

 

Option C. Presence of bilateral pitting edema: Bilateral pitting edema is a clinical sign of kwashiorkor type of SAM and is included in WHO criteria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • SAM diagnosis is based on wasting indicators (WHZ, MUAC) and edema, not underweight criteria
  • Weight-for-age reflects both acute and chronic malnutrition, making it less specific for SAM
  • MUAC <115 mm is particularly useful for community-based screening and program admission criteria

questions.text: A 50-year-old female with breast cancer is receiving doxorubicin therapy. After cumulative dose of 350 mg/m², she develops dyspnea and pedal edema. Echocardiography shows reduced ejection fraction. Which drug could have prevented this complication?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dexrazoxane

 

  • This patient has developed anthracycline-induced cardiomyopathy leading to congestive heart failure (CHF). 
  • Doxorubicin produces cardiotoxicity as a unique adverse effect, which can manifest either acutely (within 2-3 days causing ECG changes, arrhythmias, hypotension - all reversible) or delayed (producing CHF related to total dose administered, usually at doses >300 mg/m²). 
  • The CHF is due to cardiomyopathy which may be fatal. 
  • Dexrazoxane is an iron chelating agent which, when infused i.v. before doxorubicin, has been found to reduce risk of cardiotoxicity. Anthracyclines (doxorubicin, daunorubicin, epirubicin, idarubicin) generate quinone type free radicals which contribute to cardiotoxicity. 
  • However, dexrazoxane may also compromise the anticancer efficacy of doxorubicin. 
  • Dexrazoxane can also be used to ameliorate anthracycline infusion site reaction due to extravasation.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Mesna: Mesna prevents cyclophosphamide/ifosfamide-induced hemorrhagic cystitis, not anthracycline cardiotoxicity

 

Option B. Amifostine: Prevents cisplatin nephrotoxicity and radiation-induced xerostomia, not doxorubicin cardiotoxicity

 

Option D. Leucovorin: Is used for Methotrexate toxicity rescue, not for anthracycline complications

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dexrazoxane pretreatment reduces anthracycline-induced dose-dependent cardiomyopathy and CHF but should be used judiciously as it may compromise anticancer efficacy.

choices.text: Pancreatic secretions become hypertonic at high flow rates
The major anion in pancreatic fluid is chloride (Cl⁻)
Pancreatic secretion is isotonic and has higher HCO₃⁻ than plasma at high flow rates

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding pancreatic secretion is most accurate under normal physiological conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pancreatic secretion is isotonic and has higher HCO₃⁻ than plasma at high flow rates

 

  • Pancreatic secretions are composed of bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻) and enzymes. 
  • These secretions are essential for neutralizing gastric acid entering the duodenum and for digestive enzyme activity.
  • The ductal cells of the pancreas secrete bicarbonate-rich fluid, while the acinar cells secrete digestive enzymes.
  • Secretin, released from S cells in the duodenum in response to acidic chyme or fatty acids, stimulates bicarbonate secretion from pancreatic ductal cells.
  • As pancreatic secretion flow rate increases, bicarbonate concentration rises and chloride concentration falls, due to an HCO₃⁻/Cl⁻ exchange mechanism in the ductal epithelium.
  • Importantly, pancreatic secretions remain isotonic to plasma at all flow rates.
  • Therefore, at high flow rates, pancreatic juice contains high HCO₃⁻ and low Cl⁻, maintaining isotonicity with plasma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pancreatic secretions become hypertonic at high flow rates: Incorrect. Pancreatic juice is always isotonic, regardless of the flow rate, due to active electrolyte transport and osmotic equilibration with plasma.

 

Option B. Cholecystokinin (CCK) primarily stimulates bicarbonate secretion: Incorrect. CCK mainly stimulates pancreatic enzyme secretion from acinar cells, not bicarbonate secretion. Secretin is the main regulator of HCO₃⁻ output.

 

Option C. The major anion in pancreatic fluid is chloride (Cl⁻): Incorrect. While Cl⁻ predominates at low flow rates, HCO₃⁻ becomes the major anion at high flow rates, especially after secretin stimulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Secretin stimulates bicarbonate-rich, isotonic pancreatic secretions, while CCK stimulates enzyme-rich secretions.
  • At high flow rates, pancreatic juice contains more HCO₃⁻ and less Cl⁻ compared to plasma, maintaining isotonicity across all flow conditions.

choices.text: Dorsal horn of the left side of the spinal cord
Dorsal horn of the right side of the spinal cord

questions.text: A 32-year-old construction worker sustains a puncture wound on the palmar surface of his right hand. He reports intact vibration and fine touch sensation in the injured region. The injured sensory nerve fibers are associated with Pacinian corpuscles. In the pathway that carries these sensations, the first synapse occurs at which of the following sites?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Right dorsal column nucleus

 

  • Pacinian corpuscles are rapidly adapting mechanoreceptors responsible for detecting vibration and deep pressure.
  • The sensory information they generate is carried by large myelinated Aβ fibers through the dorsal column–medial lemniscus pathway (DCML).
  • In the DCML pathway:
    • The first-order neuron cell body lies in the dorsal root ganglion.
    • The axon enters the spinal cord and ascends ipsilaterally in the dorsal column (fasciculus cuneatus for upper limb, fasciculus gracilis for lower limb).
    • The first synapse occurs in the ipsilateral dorsal column nucleus of the medulla (nucleus cuneatus for upper limb input like the hand, nucleus gracilis for lower limb).
  • Since this patient has an injury on the palmar surface of the right hand, the signal ascends in the right fasciculus cuneatus and first synapses in the right dorsal column nucleus (nucleus cuneatus).
  • Thus, the correct answer is the right dorsal column nucleus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dorsal horn of the left side of the spinal cord:

 

  • The dorsal horn is the site where pain and temperature fibers (spinothalamic tract) synapse.
  • Fine touch and vibration fibers bypass the dorsal horn and ascend ipsilaterally.
  • Left-sided dorsal horn involvement is incorrect because the pathway is still ipsilateral before crossing at the medulla.

 

Option C. Dorsal horn of the right side of the spinal cord: 

 

  • While this is ipsilateral, it is still incorrect. 
  • The dorsal horn processes nociception and temperature sensations, not vibration and fine touch.

 

Option D. Left dorsal column nucleus:

 

  • Incorrect because the crossing of fibers in the DCML pathway happens in the medulla after the first synapse.
  • Therefore, the first synapse is always ipsilateral (right side for right hand input), not contralateral.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vibration and fine touch from Pacinian corpuscles travel via the dorsal column–medial lemniscus pathway, with the first synapse occurring in the ipsilateral dorsal column nucleus (nucleus cuneatus for the upper limb).

questions.text: A 20-year-old man with cystic fibrosis is started on a cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) modulator. Which laboratory test is it most important to monitor closely during treatment with this drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Liver function tests

 

  • CFTR modulators (such as ivacaftor, lumacaftor, and elexacaftor/tezacaftor/ivacaftor) are associated with hepatotoxicity, often manifesting as elevated liver enzymes.
  • Regular monitoring of liver function tests (LFTs) is critical because drug-induced liver injury can occur, and early detection allows for timely management or modification of therapy.​
  • Guideline recommendations suggest checking LFTs at baseline, then every 3 months during the first year of therapy, and annually thereafter, with more frequent monitoring if abnormalities are detected.​

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Basic metabolic panel: Not specifically indicated for CFTR modulator monitoring, unless there are other clinical concerns.

 

Option C. Complete blood counts: Not directly affected by these drugs and not a priority for routine monitoring.

 

Option D. Urine microalbumin: creatinine: More relevant to monitoring renal or diabetic complications, not the effects of CFTR modulators.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Liver function tests must be closely monitored during treatment with CFTR modulators, as these medications can cause significant hepatotoxicity, and routine surveillance helps prevent serious complications.

choices.text: Add or switch to intravitreal aflibercept

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with center-involving diabetic macular edema (DME) receives monthly intravitreal ranibizumab. After six injections, OCT shows persistent thickening. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Add or switch to intravitreal aflibercept

 

  • For patients with center-involving DME who do not respond adequately to initial anti-VEGF therapy (e.g., ranibizumab or bevacizumab), aflibercept is often used as the next line due to its superior drying effect and improved visual outcomes in poor responders. 
  • Clinical trials (e.g., DRCR.net Protocol T) have shown aflibercept to be more effective than ranibizumab or bevacizumab in patients with worse baseline vision or persistent edema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Switch to Grid/focal laser photocoagulation: While previously used, focal laser is no longer first-line for center-involving DME due to the proven superiority of anti-VEGF agents. It may be considered in non–center-involving DME or peripheral areas, but not at this stage.

 

Option C. Proceed to Pan-retinal photocoagulation (PRP): PRP is indicated for proliferative diabetic retinopathy, not for macular edema. This patient shows DME without PDR, making PRP inappropriate.

 

Option D. Observe for another three months: Observation may lead to further visual decline. Persistent macular edema after six anti-VEGF injections is a sign of non-response, and early treatment optimization is warranted.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of persistent center-involving DME after multiple ranibizumab injections, switching to aflibercept is a data-supported strategy. Aflibercept binds multiple VEGF isoforms and has shown greater efficacy in poor responders.

choices.text: Items contaminated with cytotoxic drugs along with glass or plastic ampoules
Human anatomical waste from surgical specimens

questions.text: According to Bio Medical Waste Management Rules 2016, which of the following waste items should not be discarded in the yellow bin?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Urine bags

 

According to Bio Medical Waste Management Rules 2016, urine bags are discarded in the red bin and not in the yellow bin.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blood-soaked gauze and cotton swabs: Blood-soaked gauze is infectious waste and correctly goes in yellow bins

 

Option B. Items contaminated with cytotoxic drugs along with glass or plastic ampoules: All items used during preparation and administration of cytotoxic drugs (eg: glass and plastic bottles, ampoules, vials, iv sets, gloves, syringes without needle, dressing, cotton swabs, etc.) are discarded in yellow bin with cytotoxic label. The container is not the determining factor in the case of segregation of cytotoxic wastes.

 

Option D. Human anatomical waste from surgical specimens: Human anatomical waste is correctly disposed of in yellow bins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Yellow bins are for infectious waste, anatomical waste, and expired pharmaceuticals as per BMW Rules 2016
  • Proper segregation at source is crucial for effective biomedical waste management

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient came to the physician with complaints of heartburn and regurgitation of food. The symptoms have been present for 3 years but have worsened for the past 3 months. She took over-the-counter medications, but the symptoms did not subside. Upper GI endoscopy shows the following presentation. What is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Barrett’s esophagus

 

  • The given image is an upper GI endoscopic image of Barrett's esophagus.
  • It shows tongue shaped projections in the surrounding mucosa. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Schatzki ring: A Schatzki ring is a narrowing of the lower esophagus that can cause difficulty swallowing (dysphagia). It typically appears as a thin ring on endoscopy and wouldn't show the patchy red mucosa that is indicative of Barrett’s esophagus. The symptoms of heartburn and regurgitation are less specific to a Schatzki ring unless there is accompanying esophagitis.

 

Option C. Eosinophilic esophagitis: This is an allergic/immune condition that results in a buildup of eosinophils in the esophagus, leading to esophageal dysfunction. On endoscopy, it can show multiple rings, white specks of eosinophilic infiltrates, and longitudinal furrows, none of which are visible in the provided image.

 

Option D. Pseudo-achalasia: This refers to symptoms of achalasia due to carcinoma of esophagus. It would not cause the visible changes seen in Barrett’s esophagus on endoscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Barrett’s esophagus is the columnar metaplasia of lower esophagus.

questions.text: A 5-month-old infant is brought to the pediatrician due to failure to thrive, hepatosplenomegaly, and hypotonia. On examination, the infant appears irritable and has delayed motor milestones. A liver biopsy reveals glycogen with abnormally long, unbranched outer chains. Which of the following glycogen storage disorders is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anderson disease

 

  • Anderson disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type IV) is caused by a deficiency of the glycogen branching enzyme (GBE1). This leads to the accumulation of abnormal glycogen with fewer branching points, forming long, amylopectin-like chains. 
  • These abnormal glycogen structures are poorly soluble and tend to precipitate in tissues, especially in the liver, leading to inflammation, fibrosis, and cirrhosis.
  • Clinically, Anderson disease presents in infancy with hepatosplenomegaly, failure to thrive, muscle hypotonia, and progressive liver dysfunction, often culminating in liver failure if untreated. 
  • Unlike other GSDs, the structural abnormality in glycogen is a key diagnostic feature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. McArdle disease (GSD Type V): Caused by muscle glycogen phosphorylase deficiency. It leads to muscle cramps and myoglobinuria after exercise but the glycogen structure is normal.

 

Option B. Pompe disease (GSD Type II): Caused by acid alpha-glucosidase deficiency. Glycogen accumulates in lysosomes, particularly in the heart and skeletal muscles. The structure of glycogen is normal, but the location of accumulation is lysosomal.

 

Option C. Von Gierke disease (GSD Type I): Due to glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency, leading to hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperlipidemia, and hepatomegaly. The structure of glycogen remains normal, although the quantity is excessive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anderson disease (GSD Type IV) is characterized by accumulation of abnormal, poorly branched glycogen due to branching enzyme deficiency, leading to hepatosplenomegaly and progressive liver failure in infancy.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and tobacco use disorder presents with acute severe chest pain radiating to his back. On examination, he is diaphoretic and in moderate distress. His heart rate is 110 bpm and blood pressure is 172/94 mmHg. Oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Chest X-ray is shown below. Which of the following pathologies is most likely based on his clinical findings and imaging?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aortic dissection

 

  • Acute severe chest pain radiating to the back, in a patient with hypertension and smoking history, is highly suspicious for aortic pathology.
  • Chest X-ray shows a widened mediastinum, which, while not diagnostic, is an important clue for aortic dissection.
  • CXR findings support major thoracic vessel pathology but definitive diagnosis requires advanced imaging such as CTA or TEE.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pericardial effusion: Pericardial effusion typically presents with features of tamponade (muffled heart sounds, hypotension, and pulsus paradoxus), and CXR shows an enlarged, globular cardiac silhouette.

 

Option C. Pneumothorax: Pneumothorax presents with unilateral absence of breath sounds and hyperresonance; CXR reveals a collapsed lung, not mediastinal widening.

 

Option D. Pulmonary edema: Pulmonary edema presents with dyspnea and bilateral infiltrates or Kerley B lines on CXR, findings not present in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients presenting with acute severe chest pain and a widened mediastinum on CXR, aortic dissection must be considered; rapid diagnosis is essential for life-saving intervention.

choices.text: The event constitutes a public health risk to other States through international spread and potentially requires a coordinated international response
The event has caused more than 1000 deaths in the affected country within 30 days of onset
The event involves a pathogen with pandemic potential as listed in WHO's priority pathogen list
The event has spread to at least 3 countries across 2 different WHO regions

questions.text: According to the International Health Regulations (2005), which of the following criteria must be met for the WHO Director-General to declare a Public Health Emergency of International Concern (PHEIC)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The event constitutes a public health risk to other States through international spread and potentially requires a coordinated international response

 

  • A Public Health Emergency of International Concern (PHEIC) is defined under the International Health Regulations (2005) as "an extraordinary event which is determined to constitute a public health risk to other States through the international spread of disease and to potentially require a coordinated international response.
  • " Both criteria must be satisfied: the risk of international spread AND the need for coordinated international response. 
  • The declaration is made by the WHO Director-General based on advice from the Emergency Committee, considering factors like the seriousness of the public health impact, unusual or unexpected nature of the event, risk of international spread, and risk of restrictions on international travel or trade.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The event has caused more than 1000 deaths in the affected country within 30 days of onset: There is no specific death threshold criterion for PHEIC declaration. The focus is on international spread risk and need for coordinated response, not mortality numbers.

 

Option C. The event involves a pathogen with pandemic potential as listed in WHO's priority pathogen list: While priority pathogens are important for preparedness, PHEIC can be declared for any health event meeting the IHR criteria, not just those involving listed pathogens.

 

Option D. The event has spread to at least 3 countries across 2 different WHO regions: There is no specific requirement for spread across multiple countries or regions. A PHEIC can be declared even if the event is contained within one country but poses international risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • PHEIC declaration requires both international spread risk AND need for coordinated international response
  • The WHO Director-General makes the declaration based on Emergency Committee advice under IHR (2005)
  • No specific mortality thresholds or geographical spread criteria are mandated for PHEIC declaration
  • Examples of declared PHEICs include H1N1 pandemic (2009), Ebola outbreak(2014), Zika virus (2016), and COVID-19 (2020)

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents to the vascular surgery clinic with complaints of progressive pain in his left thigh during walking, which is relieved by rest. He also notes coldness and numbness in the left lower extremity after prolonged exertion. On physical exam, the left femoral pulse is weak, while the right femoral is palpable. Ankle-brachial index (ABI) on the left is 0.6. Which of the following is the most likely site of arterial obstruction?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) External iliac artery

 

  • The external iliac artery is the most likely site of occlusion or significant stenosis in this patient. 
  • It transitions into the femoral artery after passing under the inguinal ligament and supplies blood to the lower extremities. 
  • A lesion in the external iliac artery would cause reduced perfusion to the thigh and distal leg, resulting in exercise-induced claudication in the unilateral lower thigh, with diminished femoral pulses.
  • The finding of a unilateral weak femoral pulse with normal contralateral and distal pulses suggests a proximal obstruction, specifically at the level of the external iliac artery. 
  • The ABI value of 0.61 confirms moderate peripheral arterial disease on the affected side.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superficial femoral artery: Incorrect. While femoral artery disease may cause lower extremity ischemia leading to calf claudication, it would typically result in preserved femoral pulse but distal pulse deficits (popliteal or pedal). 

 

Option B. Popliteal artery: Incorrect. Obstruction here would affect distal pulses (dorsalis pedis/posterior tibial), not the femoral pulse. The patient's popliteal pulses are symmetric, making this less likely.

 

Option D. Abdominal aorta: Incorrect. Aortic occlusion or high-grade stenosis would typically present with bilateral symptoms and diminished bilateral femoral pulses, often seen in Leriche syndrome. This patient has unilateral symptoms, ruling this out.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Unilateral thigh claudication with diminished femoral pulse and preserved distal pulses suggests external iliac artery stenosis or occlusion; ABI helps quantify severity of peripheral arterial disease.

choices.text: Suppression of 1α-hydroxylase activity in the proximal tubule
Enhanced calcium reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule
Binding of PTH to receptors on the luminal surface of proximal tubular cells
Reduction in urinary cyclic AMP (cAMP) excretion

questions.text: Which of the following is a direct renal tubular effect resulting from the action of parathyroid hormone (PTH)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Enhanced calcium reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule

 

  • Parathyroid hormone (PTH) acts on both the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) and the distal convoluted tubule (DCT), but it produces different effects in each. 

 

Actions in the distal convoluted tubule (DCT):

 

  • In the DCT, PTH increases the reabsorption of calcium from the urine back into the blood.
  • It regulates the transcellular calcium absorption by controlling the activity of specialized calcium channels in the DCT and connecting tubule cells.
  • It also increases the expression of these calcium-transporting proteins, including TRPV5, the apical calcium channel. 

 

Actions in the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT):

  • In contrast to its effects on calcium in the DCT, PTH has two main actions on the PCT: 
    • Inhibits phosphate reabsorption: PTH decreases the reabsorption of phosphate,→ more phosphate excretion in the urine. It does this by reducing the number of sodium-phosphate cotransporters in the apical membrane of the PCT cells.
    • Stimulates vitamin D activation: PTH upregulates the activity of the enzyme 1-alpha-hydroxylase in the PCT. This enzyme is responsible for converting inactive vitamin D into its active form, calcitriol. The active form of vitamin D then promotes calcium absorption in the intestines. 
  • Parathyroid hormone (PTH) regulates calcium and phosphate balance through its actions on bone, kidney, and intestine.

 

In the kidney, PTH:

 

  1. Increases calcium reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule (DCT), thereby reducing calcium excretion.
  2. Decreases phosphate reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) by inhibiting Na⁺/phosphate cotransporters, promoting phosphaturia.
  3. Stimulates 1α-hydroxylase in the proximal tubule, increasing production of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D (calcitriol), which enhances intestinal calcium absorption.
  4. Activates adenylate cyclase, increasing cAMP, which is excreted in urine — so urinary cAMP levels rise during PTH action.
  • Thus, the key renal tubular effect is enhanced calcium reabsorption in the distal tubule.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suppression of 1α-hydroxylase activity in the proximal tubule: Incorrect. PTH stimulates, not suppresses, 1α-hydroxylase activity — leading to increased calcitriol synthesis.

 

Option C. Binding of PTH to receptors on the luminal surface of proximal tubular cells: Incorrect. PTH binds to basolateral membrane receptors, not luminal ones, initiating G-protein–mediated cAMP signaling.

 

Option D. Reduction in urinary cyclic AMP (cAMP) excretion: Incorrect. PTH increases adenylate cyclase activity, producing more cAMP, which diffuses into urine. Therefore, urinary cAMP increases, not decreases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Parathyroid hormone (PTH) enhances calcium reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule, decreases phosphate reabsorption in the proximal tubule, and stimulates 1α-hydroxylase activity, resulting in elevated calcitriol production.
  • It acts via basolateral membrane receptors and increases urinary cAMP as a marker of renal PTH activity.

questions.text: A 15-month-old child presents to a Primary Health Centre with incomplete vaccination status. The child has received BCG at birth, OPV-0 at birth, Pentavalent-1, OPV-1, and Rotavirus-1 at 6 weeks. No further vaccines were given due to family migration. The mother is concerned about catch-up vaccination. According to current immunization guidelines, what is the minimum number of visits required to complete the primary immunization schedule for this child, excluding the measles vaccines?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 visits

 

  • According to catch-up immunization guidelines, the minimum visits required are: Visit 1 - OPV-2, fIPV-1, DPT-1 (given in place of Pentavalent as Hib and Hep B component are not recommended beyond one year); Visit 2 - OPV-3, DPT-2, fIPV-2 (after minimum 4-week interval). 
  • Hence, 2 visits are sufficient.
  • If the question included measles vaccines, it would require 3 visits as MR-1 needs to be given, and booster doses would follow later. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Catch-up immunization allows simultaneous administration of multiple vaccines when there are no contraindications
  • Minimum intervals between doses must be maintained even in catch-up schedules (4 weeks for most vaccines)

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding snake envenomation and first aid are true?

 

  1. Pressure immobilization is effective for elapid bites but contraindicated for viper bites.
  2. Severe local edema (>30 cm) with respiratory failure indicates severe envenomation.
  3. Local incision and suction help remove venom effectively if performed early.
  4. Observation for 24 hours is advised in mild envenomation without systemic features.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 4 only

 

Statement 1. Pressure immobilization is effective for elapid bites but contraindicated for viper bites: Pressure immobilization is indeed recommended for elapid and sea‑snake bites, where venom absorption primarily occurs via lymphatics. It is contraindicated in viper bites, as viper venom is tissue‑destructive and compression increases the risk of local necrosis.

 

Statement 2. Severe local edema (>30 cm) with respiratory failure indicates severe envenomation: Severe envenomation is characterized by extensive edema (> 30 cm), marked pain, erythema, and systemic toxicity (e.g., hypotension, paresthesias, coma, or respiratory failure).

 

Statement 4. Observation for 24 hours is advised in mild envenomation without systemic features: If a patient presents several hours after a bite with only mild local swelling and no systemic findings, observation for at least 24 hours with vital sign and oxygen monitoring is warranted.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 3. Local incision and suction help remove venom effectively if performed early: Incorrect. Incision, suction, or cryotherapy are obsolete and dangerous practices. They can cause local hemorrhage, infection, and nerve injury, and do not effectively remove venom.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pressure immobilization delays venom spread through lymphatic compression and is indicated for elapid and sea‑snake bites, not for vipers.
  • Observation for 24 hours is adequate for mild envenomation without systemic toxicity.
  • Incision, suction, or cauterization should never be performed in snakebite management.

 

Management of snake bite -

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient is brought to the casualty with maxillofacial trauma after a road traffic accident (RTA). He has altered consciousness and desaturation. A clear liquid discharge is coming from his nostrils. What is the preferred method of securing a definitive airway for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tracheostomy

 

  • Patients with severe maxillofacial trauma are highly likely to experience severe airway compromise or obstruction. 
  • In such cases, intubation is necessary to maintain airway competency. Given the presence of facial trauma, tracheostomy is the preferred method as it bypasses the obstructed upper airway by creating an opening and placing a stoma in the anterior wall of the trachea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mask ventilation: Mask ventilation is often difficult in patients with facial trauma due to structural damage and may not provide a secure airway.

 

Option B. Laryngeal mask airway (LMA): LMA can be used temporarily but is not ideal for long-term airway management in patients with facial trauma as it does not protect against aspiration and may be dislodged.

 

Option D. Nasotracheal intubation: Nasotracheal intubation is contraindicated in patients with facial trauma due to the risk of further injury to the nasal and facial structures. History is suggestive of CSF rhinorrhea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tracheostomy is the preferred method for securing the airway in patients with severe maxillofacial trauma.
  • Mask ventilation and LMA may be used temporarily but do not provide a secure airway.
  • Nasotracheal intubation is contraindicated in facial trauma due to the risk of further injury.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man undergoes manometry to evaluate dysphagia. As the bolus moves through the lumen, the intestinal segment distal to the bolus shows relaxation before the advancing wave arrives. Which neurotransmitter is primarily responsible for mediating this relaxation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP)

 

  • During peristalsis, a bolus of food causes two coordinated responses:
    1. Contraction behind the bolus – mediated by excitatory neurotransmitters (acetylcholine, substance P).
    2. Relaxation ahead of the bolus – mediated by inhibitory neurotransmitters, especially VIP (vasoactive intestinal peptide) and nitric oxide (NO) released from myenteric plexus neurons.
  • This relaxation ensures that the lumen distal to the bolus is open, allowing smooth propulsion of the food bolus through the gastrointestinal tract.
  • Therefore, the neurotransmitter responsible for relaxation distal to the bolus is VIP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acetylcholine released from myenteric fibers:

 

  • Acetylcholine is an excitatory neurotransmitter in the gut.
  • It mediates contraction behind the bolus, not relaxation distal to it.
  • Hence, this statement is incorrect in the context of distal relaxation.

 

Option B. Dopamine released from adrenergic fibers:

 

  • Dopamine and adrenergic input generally decrease overall gut motility, but they are not responsible for the localized relaxation distal to the bolus during peristalsis.
  • This option is incorrect.

 

Option D. Substance P:

 

  • Substance P is an excitatory neurotransmitter in the enteric nervous system, working with acetylcholine to cause contraction proximal to the bolus.
  • It does not mediate relaxation distal to the bolus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Relaxation of the intestinal segment distal to a bolus of food during peristalsis is mediated by vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) released from inhibitory neurons of the myenteric plexus.

questions.text:
The fibers of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles contribute to which specific walls of the inguinal canal?


i. Anterior wall 

ii. Roof 

iii. Floor 

iv. Posterior wall
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ii and iv

 

  • The inguinal canal is an oblique passage in the lower anterior abdominal wall, extending from the deep inguinal ring to the superficial inguinal ring. 
  • Its boundaries are formed by several muscular and fascial structures:

 

ii. Roof: Formed by the arching fibers of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles.

 

iv. Posterior wall: Formed primarily by the transversalis fascia, but reinforced medially by the conjoint tendon, which is derived from the lower fibers of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis.

 

Incorrect Options:

 

i. Anterior wall: Formed mainly by the aponeurosis of the external oblique and reinforced laterally by the internal oblique.

 

iii. Floor: Formed by the inguinal ligament and lacunar ligament medially.

 

  • Thus, the fibers of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles contribute to both the roof (by their arching fibers) and the posterior wall (through the conjoint tendon).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles form the roof and posterior wall of the inguinal canal, reinforcing it and helping prevent inguinal hernia formation.

choices.text: History of ischemic stroke <3 months prior to admission
Prior history of peptic ulcer disease

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with hypertension, diabetes, and a recent ischemic stroke presents with chest pain and is found to have anterior STEMI at a non-PCI-capable hospital; he had a stroke 1 month ago and peptic ulcer disease 9 years ago. Which of the following is an absolute contraindication to fibrinolytic therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) History of ischemic stroke <3 months prior to admission

 

  • Fibrinolytic therapy is absolutely contraindicated in patients with an ischemic stroke within the past 3 months because of the high risk of life-threatening intracranial hemorrhage.
  • Hypertension can be lowered safely before fibrinolysis if below critical levels.
  • Aspirin use is routine and not a contraindication.
  • Prior peptic ulcer disease without recent bleeding is only a relative, not absolute, contraindication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recent ischemic stroke (≤3 months) is an absolute contraindication to fibrinolytic therapy in STEMI. Such patients should be transferred for PCI even if it requires a substantial delay.

choices.text: Reassure; gross motor delay is common and self-limited
Refer for early intervention and assess for neuromuscular disorder
Check plasma ammonia for urea cycle defect

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant cannot sit without support and continues to have head lag. Social smile was achieved at 2 months and babbling at 6 months. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Refer for early intervention and assess for neuromuscular disorder

 

  • By 9 months, a child should be able to sit without support. 
  • Persistent head lag and inability to sit independently at this age are red flags for motor delay, suggesting possible neuromuscular weakness or central motor dysfunction. 
  • Early referral for developmental evaluation and intervention is critical to prevent further delay. 
  • A thorough neurological and neuromuscular examination should be performed, including assessment of tone, reflexes, and serum creatine kinase (CK) levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reassure; gross motor delay is common and self-limited: Incorrect. Isolated gross motor delay at 9 months is not normal and should not be dismissed as self-limited.

 

Option B. Order brain MRI urgently: Incorrect. Brain MRI is not the initial step unless there are focal neurological deficits or regression; clinical and neuromuscular assessment comes first.

 

Option D. Check plasma ammonia for urea cycle defect: Incorrect. Urea cycle disorders present earlier with encephalopathy, vomiting, or lethargy, not isolated gross motor delay.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Failure to sit unsupported and persistent head lag at 9 months are early signs of gross motor delay. 
  • Prompt referral for early developmental intervention and evaluation for neuromuscular disorders is essential.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the clinic for evaluation of fatigue and muscle weakness after prolonged fasting. The physician explains that during fasting, the body maintains blood glucose through glycogen breakdown and gluconeogenesis, while glucose utilization occurs via glycolysis during feeding. Which key metabolic intermediate acts as a central link between these three pathways — glycolysis, gluconeogenesis, and glycogenolysis — allowing smooth interconversion between glucose utilization and glucose production depending on the body’s energy needs?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glucose 6-phosphate

 

  • Glucose 6-phosphate (G6P) is the common metabolic intermediate that connects glycolysis, gluconeogenesis, and glycogenolysis.
  • In glycolysis, G6P is converted to fructose 6-phosphate, eventually leading to pyruvate and ATP production.
  • In gluconeogenesis, G6P is generated from non-carbohydrate precursors (like lactate, glycerol, amino acids) and can be converted back to free glucose by the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase in the liver and kidney.
  • In glycogenolysis, glycogen phosphorylase releases glucose-1-phosphate from glycogen, which is then converted to G6P by phosphoglucomutase.
  • Hence, G6P serves as a crucial metabolic crossroad for carbohydrate metabolism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fructose 6-phosphate: Involved in glycolysis and gluconeogenesis, but not directly in glycogenolysis.

 

Option C. Galactose 1-phosphate: Participates in galactose metabolism, not in the three main glucose pathways.

 

Option D. UDP-glucose: A key intermediate in glycogenesis (glycogen synthesis), not glycolysis or gluconeogenesis.

 

Educational Objective:


Glucose-6-phosphate is the central metabolic hub linking glycolysis, gluconeogenesis, and glycogenolysis—allowing rapid switching between glucose utilization and production.

questions.text: A 42-year-old nulliparous woman on tamoxifen therapy for breast cancer presents with postmenopausal bleeding. Transvaginal ultrasound shows endometrial thickness of 12 mm. Endometrial biopsy reveals complex endometrial hyperplasia with atypia. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy

 

This 42-year-old postmenopausal woman on tamoxifen therapy presents with postmenopausal bleeding and endometrial biopsy showing complex endometrial hyperplasia with atypia (also known as endometrial intraepithelial neoplasia).

 

Key considerations:

 

  • Tamoxifen acts as a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) — it is anti-estrogenic in breast tissue but estrogenic on the endometrium, predisposing to endometrial hyperplasia and carcinoma.
  • Complex hyperplasia with atypia carries a high risk (up to 30–40%) of progression to endometrial carcinoma or concurrent carcinoma.
  • In a postmenopausal woman who has completed childbearing, the definitive and most appropriate management is total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy (BSO) to remove both the uterus and ovaries (which are the sources of estrogen).

 

Therefore, given her postmenopausal status, tamoxifen use, and hyperplasia with atypia, total hysterectomy with BSO is the best management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cyclic progesterone therapy: Incorrect. Cyclic oral progesterone can be used in premenopausal women or those desiring fertility, to reverse simple or complex hyperplasia without atypia. However, in postmenopausal women with atypia, it is inadequate and unsafe, as it does not eliminate the malignancy risk.

 

Option B. Levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine system (LNG-IUS): Incorrect. LNG-IUS may be considered for hyperplasia without atypia or for women wishing to preserve fertility. However, with atypical hyperplasia in a postmenopausal woman, surgical management (hysterectomy) is preferred.

 

Option D. Endometrial ablation: Incorrect. Endometrial ablation destroys the endometrial lining but does not remove the source of malignancy and precludes histologic follow-up. It is contraindicated in the presence of atypia or suspected malignancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In postmenopausal women (especially those on tamoxifen) with complex endometrial hyperplasia with atypia, the most appropriate management is total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, as there is a high risk of progression to or coexistence with endometrial carcinoma.

questions.text: Which of the following scenarios does not require head imaging prior to lumbar puncture?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Patient with known epilepsy

 

  • In a patient with known epilepsy, if they present with a seizure that is consistent with their usual pattern, head imaging is generally not required prior to lumbar puncture (LP), as the seizure may be part of their pre-existing condition. 
  • The lack of new or atypical findings in the clinical presentation typically makes imaging unnecessary. 
  • In contrast, new-onset seizures, focal neurologic findings, and papilledema are all situations where head imaging is essential to rule out serious underlying causes, such as a space-occupying lesion, infection, or increased intracranial pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Focal neurologic findings: Focal neurologic signs (e.g., weakness, visual changes, speech difficulties) are often associated with structural lesions such as tumors or abscesses. Head imaging is crucial in such cases to identify potential intracranial pathology.

 

Option C. Altered mental status: Patients with altered consciousness may have intracranial pathology, such as mass lesion, hemorrhage, or increased intracranial pressure; imaging is always indicated before LP.

 

Option D. Papilledema: Papilledema suggests increased intracranial pressure, which can result from space-occupying lesions, infections, or hemorrhage. Imaging is critical to assess the cause before performing an LP to avoid worsening of the condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While head imaging is routinely required before performing an LP in cases of new-onset seizure, focal neurologic findings, and papilledema, it is not always needed in patients with known epilepsy unless the seizure pattern is atypical or concerning for a new underlying cause.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl presents with breast development, irregular vaginal bleeding, and multiple café-au-lait spots with irregular borders. X-ray shows polyostotic fibrous dysplasia. Which type of precocious puberty does this represent?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Peripheral (GnRH-independent) due to McCune-Albright syndrome

 

  • A 6-year-old girl with breast development, irregular vaginal bleeding, and multiple café-au-lait spots with irregular borders, plus X-ray shows polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, fits the classic triad of McCune-Albright syndrome (GNAS activating mutation): (1) polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, (2) café-au-lait spots with irregular (“coast of Maine”) borders, and (3) endocrinopathies such as precocious puberty from autonomous ovarian estrogen production. 
  • In McCune-Albright, sex-steroid production is Peripheral (GnRH-independent)—gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) is not the driver, so LH/FSH are low or suppressed, and a GnRH stimulation test is non-centrally responsive. 
  • Therefore, the presentation—breast development, irregular vaginal bleeding, multiple café-au-lait spots with irregular borders, and polyostotic fibrous dysplasia in a 6-year-old girl—indicates Peripheral (GnRH-independent) due to McCune-Albright syndrome, matching option C.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central (GnRH-dependent) due to hypothalamic hamartoma: Incorrect. While central (GnRH-dependent) causes (e.g., hypothalamic hamartoma) can produce precocious puberty with breast development and irregular vaginal bleeding in a 6-year-old girl, the hallmark multiple café-au-lait spots with irregular borders and X-ray shows polyostotic fibrous dysplasia are not features of a hypothalamic hamartoma; these point instead to McCune-Albright syndrome and thus a Peripheral (GnRH-independent) mechanism, not Central.

 

Option B. Peripheral (GnRH-independent) due to ovarian tumor: Incorrect. An ovarian tumor can cause Peripheral (GnRH-independent) estrogen excess with breast development and irregular vaginal bleeding in a 6-year-old girl, but it does not explain the characteristic multiple café-au-lait spots with irregular borders and polyostotic fibrous dysplasia on X-ray; that specific combination is typical of McCune-Albright syndrome, not an isolated tumor.

 

Option D. Central (GnRH-dependent) due to CNS pathology: Incorrect.
Generic CNS pathology (central lesions) causing Central (GnRH-dependent) pubertal activation could present with breast development and irregular vaginal bleeding at 6 years, but the coexisting multiple café-au-lait spots with irregular borders and polyostotic fibrous dysplasia on X-ray identify McCune-Albright syndrome, which is Peripheral (GnRH-independent) rather than Central.

 

Educational Objective:

 

McCune-Albright syndrome (café-au-lait spots with irregular borders + polyostotic fibrous dysplasia) causes peripheral, GnRH-independent precocious puberty.

questions.text: A 45-year-old healthcare worker in NICU is found to have MRSA colonization in the anterior nares during routine screening. She is asymptomatic. What is the most appropriate treatment for decolonization?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Topical mupirocin

 

  • Topical mupirocin (or bacitracin) is the drug of choice for MRSA colonization prophylaxis in asymptomatic carriers, particularly nasal colonization. 
  • It acts by inhibiting bacterial protein synthesis by blocking isoleucyl-tRNA synthetase. 
  • For nasal MRSA carriers, especially healthcare workers, topical application to anterior nares effectively decolonizes and prevents transmission without systemic side effects. 
  • This prevents progression to active MRSA infection and protects vulnerable patients in NICU settings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral vancomycin: Vancomycin is the drug of choice for active MRSA infections, not colonization. Oral vancomycin is primarily used for Clostridium difficile colitis (pseudomembranous colitis) as it is not absorbed systemically. For MRSA colonization, oral vancomycin would be ineffective and inappropriate.

 

Option C. IV ceftriaxone: Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin that is ineffective against MRSA due to altered penicillin-binding proteins in methicillin-resistant strains. MRSA, by definition, is resistant to all beta-lactam antibiotics including cephalosporins except 5th generation cephalosporins like ceftaroline.

 

Option D. Inhaled colistin: Colistin (polymyxin E) is reserved for superbug infections caused by NDM (New Delhi metallo-beta-lactamase) producing bacteria and multidrug-resistant Gram-negative organisms. It is not indicated for MRSA colonization and would represent inappropriate antimicrobial use with risk of toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Topical mupirocin is the drug of choice for decolonization of asymptomatic MRSA nasal carriers, while vancomycin is reserved for active MRSA infections.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male smoker presents with painless hematuria. Further investigation reveals bladder cancer extending up to the muscle layer. What should be the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Radical cystectomy

 

  • Radical cystectomy is the standard treatment for muscle-invasive bladder cancer. 
  • It involves the removal of the bladder and surrounding tissues/organs (such as prostate in men and uterus in women), and it provides the best chance for long-term survival and disease control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intravesical BCG: Intravesical BCG is typically used for non-muscle invasive bladder cancer (NMIBC). It is effective in reducing recurrence and progression of superficial bladder cancer but is not adequate for muscle-invasive disease.

 

Option B. Systemic chemotherapy: While systemic chemotherapy can be used as part of the treatment plan, especially in a neoadjuvant setting (before surgery) or for metastatic disease, it is not the primary treatment of choice for muscle-invasive bladder cancer without metastatic disease.

 

Option D. TURBT: Transurethral resection of bladder tumours is used in non-muscle invasive tumors. It is not the first-line treatment for muscle-invasive bladder cancer when the patient is otherwise healthy and a surgical candidate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For muscle-invasive bladder cancer, the treatment of choice is radical cystectomy, which involves the removal of the bladder and surrounding tissues to achieve the best long-term outcomes. 
  • Painless hematuria in a smoker is highly suggestive of bladder carcinoma and should prompt thorough evaluation.

choices.text: Second generation H₁ antihistamines cross the blood-brain barrier and cause significant sedation
Promethazine has the maximum anticholinergic action among first generation antihistamines
Terfenadine and Astemizole were withdrawn due to QT prolongation
First generation H₁ antihistamines are useful in drug-induced Parkinsonism

questions.text: All of the following are true about H₁ antihistamines, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Second generation H₁ antihistamines cross the blood-brain barrier and cause significant sedation.

 

  • Second generation H₁ antihistamines represent a significant pharmacological advancement over their predecessors precisely because they do not cross the blood-brain barrier to any appreciable extent. 
  • This fundamental pharmacokinetic property eliminates the CNS depressant effects, allowing patients to use these medications without experiencing sedation, impaired psychomotor performance, or reduced alertness. 
  • Drugs like cetirizine, loratadine, fexofenadine, and desloratadine maintain their peripheral antihistaminic efficacy while sparing central nervous system function, making them suitable for patients who need to drive vehicles or operate machinery requiring constant attention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Promethazine has the maximum anticholinergic action among first generation antihistamines: Among first generation antihistamines, promethazine demonstrates the most pronounced anticholinergic activity. This property contributes to its side effect profile including dry mouth, urinary hesitancy, constipation, and blurred vision. The strong anticholinergic action also explains its utility beyond simple antihistaminic effects, including use as an antiemetic and in managing extrapyramidal symptoms.

 

Option C. Terfenadine and Astemizole were withdrawn due to QT prolongation: Both terfenadine and astemizole were withdrawn from the market due to their propensity to cause QT interval prolongation, particularly when combined with CYP3A4 inhibitors such as ketoconazole, erythromycin, or ciprofloxacin. These drugs, remembered by the mnemonic "CAT drugs" (Cisapride, Astemizole, Terfenadine - "Cat is cute = QT prolongation"), posed significant cardiac safety concerns. Fexofenadine, the active metabolite of terfenadine, was subsequently developed and does not carry this cardiac risk.

 

Option D. First generation H₁ antihistamines are useful in drug-induced Parkinsonism: First generation H₁ antihistamines possess significant anticholinergic properties that make them therapeutically useful in managing drug-induced Parkinsonism and acute muscular dystonia. The anticholinergic activity helps restore the dopamine-acetylcholine balance disrupted by antipsychotic medications. Additionally, these agents find application in common cold symptoms and motion sickness prophylaxis due to their combined antihistaminic and anticholinergic effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Second generation H₁ antihistamines are characterized by their inability to cross the BBB, providing effective peripheral antihistaminic action without CNS sedation, unlike first generation agents which have extensive central and anticholinergic effects.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman with stable myopia for the past 2 years presents for refractive correction. Her current prescription is −10.5D. On examination, her central corneal thickness is 475 microns. She has no history of systemic illness. What is the most appropriate next step in her refractive correction?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Consider Implantable Collamer Lens (ICL) placement

 

  • LASIK requires a minimum corneal thickness of >500 microns (with a residual stromal bed ≥270 microns). 
  • A thickness <470 microns is an absolute contraindication. At 475 microns, LASIK and SMILE are relatively contraindicated due to insufficient safety margin. 
  • PRK may be attempted in borderline thin corneas, but at high corrections (−10.5D), it would require ablating over 120 microns (12-15 microns per D), which is unsafe. 
  • Thus, ICL, a phakic intraocular lens implanted over the native lens, is safest and preferred for high myopia with thin corneas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Perform standard LASIK surgery: Unsafe, as the corneal thickness is <500 microns. LASIK requires sufficient tissue for flap creation and ablation.

 

Option B. Offer PRK surgery: PRK is an option in thinner corneas but not preferred for high myopia (−10.5D), due to risk of excessive tissue loss and haze.

 

Option C. Refer for SMILE procedure: SMILE also removes corneal tissue and would be inappropriate with a borderline thickness and high refractive demand.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ICL is the preferred correction method for high myopia in patients with thin corneas (<500 µm) where LASIK or PRK are unsafe.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with chronic kidney disease stage 5 requires treatment for Type 2 diabetes mellitus. Which DPP-4 inhibitor can be safely administered without dose adjustment in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Linagliptin

 

  • Linagliptin is the only DPP-4 inhibitor that is safe in renal failure without requiring dose adjustment because it is primarily metabolized in the liver rather than being excreted by the kidneys.
  • All other DPP-4 inhibitors (sitagliptin, vildagliptin, saxagliptin, alogliptin, saxagliptin) are contraindicated or require dose adjustment in renal failure.
  • DPP-4 inhibitors work by inhibiting the enzyme dipeptidyl peptidase-4, which normally degrades endogenous GLP-1, thereby potentiating insulin release and decreasing glucagon secretion.
  • These drugs do not cause hypoglycemia or weight gain, and the most common side effect is nasopharyngitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sitagliptin: It is incorrect because sitagliptin is primarily excreted unchanged in urine (renal clearance) and requires dose adjustment in CKD. It undergoes non-covalent binding to DPP-4.

 

Option B. Vildagliptin: It is incorrect because vildagliptin undergoes both hepatic and renal clearance and requires dose modification in renal failure. It causes covalent binding to DPP-4.

 

Option C. Saxagliptin: It is incorrect because saxagliptin is also contraindicated in renal failure and requires dose adjustment. It is partially renally excreted.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Linagliptin is the only DPP-4 inhibitor safe in renal failure without dose adjustment due to hepatic metabolism rather than renal excretion.

choices.text: Mallory–Denk bodies are composed of cytokeratin intermediate filaments
It may progress to micronodular cirrhosis
It is a reversible stage of alcohol-induced injury
The inflammatory infiltrate is predominantly lymphocytic

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic alcoholic presents with fatigue and hepatomegaly. Lab tests show elevated AST > ALT (AST:ALT ratio >2:1). Liver biopsy reveals Mallory–Denk bodies and neutrophilic infiltration. All of the following are correct about the lesion except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The inflammatory infiltrate is predominantly lymphocytic

 

  • This vignette describes alcoholic hepatitis in a 45-year-old chronic alcoholic with AST > ALT (typically >2:1), hepatomegaly, and biopsy showing Mallory–Denk bodies with neutrophilic infiltration. 
  • In alcoholic hepatitis, the inflammatory infiltrate is predominantly neutrophilic (polymorphonuclear), not lymphocytic—therefore option D is incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mallory–Denk bodies are composed of cytokeratin intermediate filaments True. They are eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions formed by damaged cytokeratin intermediate filaments within hepatocytes.

 

Option B. It may progress to micronodular cirrhosis: True. Chronic alcohol injury can progress from steatosis → alcoholic hepatitis → micronodular (Laennec) cirrhosis.

 

Option C. It is a reversible stage of alcohol-induced injury: True. Unlike cirrhosis, alcoholic hepatitis can show clinical and histologic improvement with abstinence and appropriate therapy, though severe cases carry high short-term mortality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In alcoholic hepatitis, expect AST:ALT>2, Mallory–Denk bodies, ballooning degeneration, and a predominantly neutrophilic inflammatory infiltrate; disease may progress to micronodular cirrhosis if alcohol use continues.

questions.text: Match the automated system with its corresponding detection method. Which of the following is the correct matching?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1–b, 2–a, 3–c, 4–d

 

  • 1–b. BACTEC → Fluorescence detection:
    • Detects bacterial growth by measuring fluorescence produced when CO₂ generated by microorganisms reacts with a fluorescent dye.
    • Earlier BACTEC models used radioisotopes, but modern systems are non-radioactive and fully automated.
    • Application: Blood cultures and mycobacterial detection.

 

  • 2–a. VITEK MS → Mass spectrometry (MALDI‑TOF):
    • Uses Matrix‑Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization – Time of Flight (MALDI‑TOF) mass spectrometry.
    • Identifies bacteria, fungi, and mycobacteria by analyzing their unique protein spectra.
    • Provides identification within minutes and eliminates the need for traditional biochemical tests.

 

  • 3–c. VersaTREK → Manometry (Pressure detection):
    • Measures pressure changes caused by gas exchange (CO₂ production or O₂ consumption) in a sealed culture bottle.
    • The pressure alteration is detected by manometric sensors, signaling microbial growth.
    • Advantage: Sensitive for both aerobic and anaerobic organisms.

 

  • 4–d. BacT/ALERT → Colorimetric pH sensor:
    • Detects microbial growth through color change caused by acid production.
    • CO₂ released by growing microbes diffuses into a color‑sensitive membrane at the bottom of the bottle, turning the sensor from blue‑green to yellow.
    • The system continuously monitors changes, providing real‑time detection without manual intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: An 88-year-old woman with coronary artery disease (status post CABG), atrial fibrillation on warfarin, hypertension, heart failure with preserved ejection fraction, and chronic kidney disease presents with altered mental status after a mechanical fall. On examination, she is somnolent but arousable. Noncontrast head CT reveals a 2-cm subdural hematoma with midline shift. Her INR is 3.2. What is the most appropriate next step in her management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Administer 4 Factor PCC

 

  • This patient has a life-threatening intracranial hemorrhage while on chronic warfarin therapy. The priority in her management is rapid and effective reversal of warfarin-induced anticoagulation.
  • 4F-PCC provides all vitamin K-dependent clotting factors (II, VII, IX, and X) and offers the fastest and most reliable correction of coagulopathy, which is critical in cases of major bleeding like subdural hematoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Administer 10 mg oral vitamin K: Vitamin K is necessary for sustained reversal but has a delayed onset and does not address the urgent need for hemostasis. It should be administered in conjunction with rapid reversal agents for complete effect.

 

Option C. Administer fresh frozen plasma: Fresh frozen plasma is a less effective alternative, as it requires larger volumes, takes longer to administer, and may not achieve the same degree of rapid INR normalization as 4F-PCC.

 

Option D. Administer platelet transfusion: Platelet transfusion is only indicated in patients with significant thrombocytopenia or concurrent antiplatelet therapy-not for isolated warfarin-induced coagulopathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For acute, major bleeding in a patient receiving warfarin (e.g., intracranial hemorrhage), immediate reversal with 4-factor prothrombin complex concentrate is the recommended therapy to rapidly restore coagulation; vitamin K should be co-administered to ensure sustained reversal. Other agents like FFP or platelets are reserved for specific situations or when PCC is unavailable.

choices.text: Recurrence is negligible and no future screening is needed
Recurrence risk may be increased; future pregnancies merit targeted renal imaging
Recurrence is guaranteed if the next fetus is male

questions.text: A woman with a previous pregnancy complicated by Potter sequence due to bilateral renal agenesis seeks counseling about recurrence risk. Which of the following statements is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Recurrence risk may be increased; future pregnancies merit targeted renal imaging

 

  • While most cases of bilateral renal agenesis leading to Potter sequence occur sporadically, some may have a genetic or familial component (autosomal dominant or recessive renal malformation syndromes). 
  • Therefore, future pregnancies carry a small but definite recurrence risk. 
  • Early targeted ultrasonography focusing on renal development and amniotic fluid volume is recommended, along with genetic counseling and testing when indicated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Recurrence is negligible and no future screening is needed: Incorrect. Recurrence is not negligible; proactive screening is essential.

 

Option C. Recurrence is guaranteed if the next fetus is male: Incorrect. Renal agenesis is not sex-linked and does not depend on fetal sex.

 

Option D. Risk is solely maternal age-dependent: Incorrect. The risk is not related to maternal age but rather to possible hereditary factors.

 

Educational Objective:


After a fetus is affected by Potter sequence due to bilateral renal agenesis, genetic counseling and targeted renal imaging in subsequent pregnancies are essential to identify possible recurrence early.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man undergoes spinal imaging for evaluation of back pain. A lateral X-ray of the spine reveals posterior scalloping of multiple vertebral bodies. Which of the following conditions is associated with this radiologic finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neurofibromatosis

 

  • Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) is the most classically associated condition with posterior scalloping of vertebral bodies. 
  • This scalloping results from dural ectasia and intraspinal neurofibromas, which cause chronic pressure against the posterior aspect of the vertebral bodies. 
  • In NF1, additional skeletal manifestations include kyphoscoliosis, vertebral dysplasia, and rib penciling.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aortic aneurysm: This can cause anterior vertebral body erosion due to pulsatile mass effect, not posterior scalloping.

 

Option C. Lymphadenopathy: Chronic paraspinal lymphadenopathy (e.g., tuberculosis or lymphoma) may affect the vertebral margins, but it more commonly causes anterior or lateral erosion rather than posterior scalloping.

 

Option D. Cretinism: Seen in congenital hypothyroidism, it leads to delayed bone maturation, metaphyseal dysplasia, and epiphyseal dysgenesis — posterior vertebral scalloping is not a feature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Posterior vertebral body scalloping is most commonly associated with neurofibromatosis type 1, due to intraspinal tumor growth or dural ectasia causing chronic pressure on the vertebrae.

questions.text:
Regarding the prevertebral fascia, which of the following statements are incorrect?

 

  1. It forms the axillary fascia by extending laterally around the subclavian vessels and brachial plexus.
  2. It covers the phrenic nerve as it descends on the anterior surface of the scalenus anterior.
  3. It contributes to the floor of the posterior triangle of the neck.
  4. It forms the false capsule of the thyroid gland.
  5. It fuses inferiorly with the pretracheal fascia to form the carotid sheath.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4 and 5

 

  • The prevertebral fascia surrounds the prevertebral muscles and extends laterally as the axillary sheath enclosing the subclavian vessels and brachial plexus → Statement 1 is correct.
  • It covers the phrenic nerve on the anterior surface of the scalenus anterior → Statement 2 is correct.
  • It forms the floor of the posterior triangle of the neck → Statement 3 is correct.
  • The false capsule of the thyroid gland is formed by the pretracheal fascia, not the prevertebral fascia → Statement 4 is incorrect.
  • The carotid sheath receives contributions from all three deep cervical fasciae (investing, pretracheal, and prevertebral), but it is not formed by fusion inferiorly → Statement 5 is incorrect.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The prevertebral fascia forms the floor of the posterior triangle, covers the phrenic nerve, and extends laterally to form the axillary sheath, but does not form the false capsule of the thyroid gland, which arises from the pretracheal fascia.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man has undergone a day care laparoscopic hernia repair. What scoring system is typically used to assess when a patient is ready for discharge from the post-anesthesia care unit (PACU) following day care surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Aldrete score

 

  • The Aldrete scoring system is commonly used to assess when a patient has recovered from the physiological effects of anesthesia. 
  • It considers five parameters: consciousness, respiration, circulation, oxygen saturation, and color, mobility and sensation of extremities. 
  • A score of 9 or 10 (out of a maximum of 10) is usually required for a patient to be considered ready for discharge from the PACU.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. APGAR score: This is a quick scoring system used to assess the physical status of a newborn immediately after birth. It's not relevant for assessing recovery from anesthesia in adults.

 

Option B. ASA physical status classification: This is used to assess a patient's overall health status prior to anesthesia, but it's not used for assessing recovery from anesthesia.

 

Option C. Mallampati score: This is used to predict the ease of intubation, but it's not used for assessing recovery from anesthesia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Aldretescore is a common scoring system employed to assess a patient's readiness for discharge from the Post-Anesthesia Care Unit (PACU) after day care surgery, considering parameters such as consciousness, oxygen saturation, hemodynamic stability, respiratory status, and ability to move.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 8 weeks gestation is diagnosed with Graves' disease. She is started on an antithyroid drug. Which drug is preferred during the first trimester of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Propylthiouracil

 

  • Propylthiouracil (PTU) is the drug of choice in the first trimester of pregnancy for treating hyperthyroidism because it has less placental transfer compared to carbimazole/methimazole due to higher plasma protein binding.
  • PTU inhibits thyroid peroxidase (blocking iodination and coupling reactions) and additionally inhibits peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 by D1-type 5-deiodinase.
  • While both PTU and carbimazole can cause congenital malformations (choanal atresia and aplasia cutis), PTU is preferred in the first trimester due to reduced fetal exposure.
  • In the second and third trimesters, carbimazole or methimazole can be used as they are more potent and require less frequent dosing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carbimazole: Is incorrect because carbimazole has greater placental transfer than PTU and is thus avoided in the first trimester. It is approximately 5 times more potent than PTU and is preferred in the second and third trimesters.

 

Option B. Methimazole: Is incorrect because methimazole (the active form of carbimazole) also crosses the placenta more readily than PTU and is avoided in early pregnancy.

 

Option D. Radioactive iodine: Is incorrect because radioactive iodine (I-131) is absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy as it crosses the placenta and destroys the fetal thyroid, causing cretinism and other abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Propylthiouracil is the antithyroid drug of choice in the first trimester of pregnancy due to less placental transfer; switch to carbimazole in later trimesters.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presented to the hospital with a history of recurrent pain in the righ tHypochondrium for 1 week, typically after fatty meals. She is a known case of hereditary spherocytosis. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gall stone disease

 

  • In patients with hemolytic disorders, black pigment stones are seen in the gall bladder, which are likely to block cystic duct and cause biliary colic or cholecystitis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Splenic infarct: May occur in sickle cell disease and will present with LUQ pain.

 

Option B. Acute pancreatitis: Patient with Acute Pancreatitis presents with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back. Lab investigations reveal increase serum amylase and lipase levels. Its management is mainly supportive care with adequate analgesia, IV Fluid therapy and oxygen administration.

 

Option D. Amoebic liver abscess: Patients with amoebic liver abscess are mostly asymptomatic. There is usually a history of dysentery with mucus in stools. It is caused by E. histolytica and on aspiration, pus with Anchovy-sauce appearance is obtained.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Hemolytic disorders with RUQ pain is likely to be due to gall stones and will be confirmed by USG abdomen.

questions.text: A researcher wants to investigate whether prolonged exposure to indoor air pollution from biomass fuel cooking is associated with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) in rural women aged 40-60 years. The study needs to be completed within 2 years with limited funding, and the prevalence of COPD in this population is approximately 8%. Which epidemiological study design would be most appropriate for this research question?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Case-control study

 

  • Given the constraints of limited time (2 years), limited funding, and a relatively low disease prevalence (8%), a case-control study is the most appropriate design. 
  • Case-control studies are efficient for studying diseases with low prevalence as they start with diseased individuals (cases) and compare their exposure history with healthy controls. 
  • This design is cost-effective, time-efficient, and suitable for studying chronic diseases like COPD where the outcome has already occurred. 
  • The retrospective nature allows investigation of past exposure to biomass fuel, making it ideal for this research scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prospective cohort study: Prospective cohort study would require following subjects over many years to develop COPD, exceeding the 2-year timeline and budget constraints.

 

Option C. Cross-sectional study: Cross-sectional study cannot establish temporal relationship between biomass fuel exposure and COPD development, limiting causal inference.

 

Option D. Randomized controlled trial: Randomized controlled trial is unethical as it would involve deliberately exposing subjects to harmful biomass fuel pollution.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Case-control studies are optimal for investigating rare diseases or outcomes with low prevalence and for studying chronic diseases where exposure occurred in the past
  • Time and budget constraints significantly influence the choice of epidemiological study design
  • Study design selection must consider ethical feasibility, especially when dealing with harmful exposures

questions.text: A 68-year-old man undergoes a barium enema for evaluation of lower abdominal pain and rectal bleeding. Which of the following findings is not typically associated with ischemic colitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dilution of barium

 

  • Ischemic colitis occurs due to reduced blood flow to the colon, leading to mucosal edema, hemorrhage, and ulceration.
  • Typical radiologic findings on barium enema include:
    • Thumb-printing — due to submucosal edema or hemorrhage.
    • Serrated or saw-tooth mucosal pattern — due to mucosal irregularity and ulceration.
    • Increased mucosal fold thickness — reflecting submucosal edema and inflammation.
  • Dilution of barium is not a feature of ischemic colitis. 
  • It occurs in malabsorption syndromes or conditions with increased intestinal secretions, where the contrast becomes less dense due to dilution by fluid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize that thumb printing, serrated mucosa, and increased mucosal fold thickness are characteristic radiologic features of ischemic colitis, while dilution of barium suggests malabsorption or secretory intestinal disorders, not ischemia.
