questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with complaints of vomiting, sweating, and dizziness after consuming a large quantity of fruit juice. Biochemical testing shows accumulation of fructose-1-phosphate in the liver, indicating a metabolic block in the fructose catabolic pathway. In a healthy individual, fructose is metabolized in the liver through a series of reactions that ultimately lead to the production of pyruvate. Which of the following enzymes is directly involved in the catabolism of fructose to pyruvate in the liver?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase

 

  • In the liver, fructose is metabolized primarily through the fructolysis pathway, which is distinct from glycolysis in its initial steps:
    1. Fructose → Fructose-1-phosphate
      (Enzyme: Fructokinase)
    2. Fructose-1-phosphate → Glyceraldehyde + Dihydroxyacetone phosphate (DHAP)
      (Enzyme: Aldolase B)
    3. Glyceraldehyde → Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate (G3P)
      (Enzyme: Triose kinase)
    4. Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate → 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate → ... → Pyruvate
      (Enzyme: Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase and other glycolytic enzymes)
  • Thus, glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase plays a direct role in converting G3P to 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate, a key step in the conversion of fructose-derived carbons into pyruvate. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phosphoglucomutase: Catalyzes the interconversion of glucose-1-phosphate and glucose-6-phosphate during glycogen metabolism, not involved in fructose catabolism.

 

Option C. Lactate dehydrogenase: Converts pyruvate ↔ lactate during anaerobic glycolysis, but acts after fructose has already been converted to pyruvate — not in fructose breakdown itself.

 

Option D. Glucokinase: Phosphorylates glucose → glucose-6-phosphate in the first step of glycolysis, not fructose.
In the liver, fructose is phosphorylated by fructokinase, not glucokinase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hereditary Fructose Intolerance (Aldolase B deficiency) → accumulation of fructose-1-phosphate, leading to:
    • Hypoglycemia (inhibition of glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis)
    • Vomiting, lactic acidosis, liver dysfunction
  • Avoiding fructose, sucrose, and sorbitol in the diet prevents symptoms.
  • Key Concept Table:

choices.text: Expectant management with regular antenatal follow-up
Termination of pregnancy and correction of anomaly before attempting conception

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with known uterine didelphys conceives naturally and is now at 8 weeks gestation. Ultrasound confirms intrauterine pregnancy in the right uterine cavity. What is the most appropriate obstetric management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Expectant management with regular antenatal follow-up

 

  • A 25-year-old woman with known uterine didelphys who conceives naturally and is now at 8 weeks gestation, with ultrasound confirming intrauterine pregnancy in the right uterine cavity, is best managed with expectant management with regular antenatal follow-up. 
  • In uterine didelphys, many pregnancies progress normally; the key is close surveillance for miscarriage, preterm birth, malpresentation, and cervical length, rather than routine intervention. 
  • Because there is no prior history provided of cervical insufficiency and the pregnancy is already intrauterine and viable in the right uterine cavity, the most appropriate obstetric management for this patient is conservative.
  • Uterine didelphys is associated with a good reproductive outcome and hence normal antenatal care is to be offered. Complications like abortions, preterm and malpresentations are slightly increased in uterine didelphys

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prophylactic cervical cerclage at 14 weeks: Incorrect. Routine prophylactic cervical cerclage at 14 weeks is not indicated solely for uterine didelphys; it is reserved for proven or suspected cervical insufficiency (eg, prior mid-trimester losses or a short cervix). 

 

Option B. Strassman metroplasty before 12 weeks: Incorrect. Strassman metroplasty before 12 weeks is a unification surgery used for bicornuate uterus and is not performed during an established pregnancy; moreover, it is not the standard correction for uterine didelphys. With a confirmed intrauterine pregnancy at 8 weeks gestation in the right uterine cavity after she conceives naturally, surgery is contraindicated; proceed with expectant management with regular antenatal follow-up as the most appropriate obstetric management for this patient.

 

Option D. Termination of pregnancy and correction of anomaly before attempting conception: Incorrect. Routine termination of pregnancy to “correct the anomaly before attempting conception” is not recommended for uterine didelphys when a viable intrauterine pregnancy exists. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In uterine didelphys with a confirmed intrauterine pregnancy (here, 8 weeks gestation in the right uterine cavity), the most appropriate obstetric management is expectant management with regular antenatal follow-up; prophylactic cerclage, Strassman metroplasty, or termination of pregnancy are not routine.

choices.text: It reversibly inhibits P2Y12 receptors on platelets
It acts immediately after oral administration
Its antiplatelet effect persists for 5 days after discontinuation

questions.text: A patient on long-term clopidogrel therapy requires urgent surgery. Which of the following statements regarding clopidogrel is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Its antiplatelet effect persists for 5 days after discontinuation

 

  • Clopidogrel irreversibly blocks P2Y12 purinergic receptors on the platelet surface, preventing ADP-induced platelet aggregation. 
  • Since platelets lack nuclei and cannot synthesize new proteins, the effect of clopidogrel lasts for the entire lifespan of affected platelets (approximately 7-10 days). 
  • However, clinically significant antiplatelet effect persists for about 5 days after discontinuation because new platelets are continuously being released from bone marrow. 
  • Complete recovery of platelet function requires generation of sufficient numbers of new unaffected platelets. 
  • Therefore, clopidogrel should be discontinued at least 5 days before elective surgery to minimize bleeding risk.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It reversibly inhibits P2Y12 receptors on platelets: Incorrect. Clopidogrel produces irreversible blockade of P2Y12 receptors, not reversible inhibition. This is in contrast to ticagrelor, which is a newer P2Y12 inhibitor that produces reversible blockade and therefore has faster onset and quicker offset of action (t½ = 12 hours). The irreversible nature of clopidogrel's action explains why its effect persists for days after discontinuation.

 

Option B. It acts immediately after oral administration: Incorrect. Clopidogrel is a prodrug that requires metabolic activation in the liver through a two-step process involving CYP2C19. Only about 50% of absorbed drug is activated, while the rest is inactivated by other enzymes. The antiplatelet action takes about 4 hours to start and develops over several days. A loading dose of 300 mg is often given to achieve faster effect. Prasugrel and ticagrelor are faster-acting alternatives.

 

Option C. Omeprazole enhances its antiplatelet effect: Incorrect. Omeprazole reduces the antiplatelet action of clopidogrel, not enhances it. Omeprazole is a CYP2C19 inhibitor that decreases the metabolic activation of clopidogrel into its active thiol metabolite. This drug interaction can reduce the cardiovascular protective effects of clopidogrel. Pantoprazole and rabeprazole are safer PPI alternatives that do not significantly inhibit CYP2C19.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clopidogrel irreversibly blocks P2Y12 receptors, requires hepatic activation via CYP2C19 (inhibited by omeprazole), and has persistent antiplatelet effect for 5 days after discontinuation, necessitating planned discontinuation before elective surgery.

questions.text: A 24-year-old lactating woman with an 18-month-old child presents with irregular heavy menstrual bleeding and requests contraceptive advice. She wishes to continue breastfeeding. Which contraceptive method is most appropriate for her?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mala-N

 

This 24-year-old lactating woman with an 18-month-old child has irregular, heavy menstrual bleeding and requests contraceptive advice while continuing breastfeeding.

 

The ideal contraceptive for her should:

 

  • Not interfere with lactation (avoid estrogen-containing methods).
  • Be effective, convenient, and reversible.
  • Help regulate or reduce menstrual bleeding.

 

Mala-N is a combined OCP that fulfills these requirements.

 

  • It can be safely used in lactating women > 6 months as after 6 months, the baby is not exclusively breast fed. Combined OCPs should be avoided in women who are breast feeding with infants < 6 months
  • It also reduces menstrual blood loss and may help with irregular heavy bleeding by inducing endometrial atrophy.
  • It provides three months of contraception per injection and is part of the national family welfare program in India.

 

Thus, Combined OCPS is the most appropriate contraceptive choice for this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Progestasert IUD: Incorrect. This is a progesterone-releasing intrauterine device that must be replaced annually and may cause irregular spotting. It is less suitable for a woman with heavy bleeding and is less effective long-term compared to injectables.

 

Option B. Copper-T 380A: Incorrect. Although safe for lactating women, copper IUDs can increase menstrual bleeding and cramps, making them unsuitable for a woman who already has heavy irregular periods.

 

Option D. Depot injection of norethisterone enanthate: Incorrect. While this progestin-only method is also compatible with lactation, it may worsen irregular bleeding patterns in some women. The national program–approved Mala-N (norethindrone enanthate) is the standard, safer choice in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In lactating women with irregular or heavy menstrual bleeding, the best contraceptive option is Combined OCP, Mala-N), as it is safe for breastfeeding > 6 months reduces menstrual loss, and provides effective, reversible contraception.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding eggs and diagnostic clues in parasitology are correct?

 

  1. Eggs of Capillaria philippinensis resemble those of Trichuris trichiura.
  2. Trichostrongylus eggs mimic hookworm eggs but larvae show tail-end bead-like swelling.
  3. Necator americanus eggs are bile-stained and float in saturated salt solution.
  4. Unfertilized eggs of Ascaris lumbricoides do not float in saturated salt solution.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 4 only

 

Statement 1. Eggs of Capillaria philippinensis resemble those of Trichuris trichiura: Correct. Capillaria philippinensis eggs resemble those of Trichuris trichiura — both are barrel-shaped with bipolar plugs, making microscopic differentiation challenging.

 

 

Statement 2. Trichostrongylus eggs mimic hookworm eggs but larvae show tail-end bead-like swelling: Correct. Trichostrongylus eggs closely resemble hookworm eggs, but their rhabditiform larvae have a characteristic bead-like swelling at the tail end, which is a diagnostic clue.

 

 

Statement 4. Unfertilized eggs of Ascaris lumbricoides do not float in saturated salt solution: Correct. Unfertilized eggs of Ascaris lumbricoides are irregular in shape, heavier, and do not float in saturated salt solutions — hence used to differentiate in stool exams. The unfertilized eggs settle down as they are heavier.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 3. Necator americanus eggs are bile-stained and float in saturated salt solution: False. Eggs of Necator americanus are not bile-stained — they are non–bile-stained and float in saturated salt solution. This error makes this statement incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Remember the unique features:

 

  • Capillaria eggs mimic Trichuris,
  • Trichostrongylus larvae show tail bead swelling,
  • Unfertilized Ascaris eggs sink in saturated salt,
  • Necator eggs are non–bile-stained, not bile-stained.

questions.text: During a mental status examination, a patient is asked, “What is the similarity between a chair and a table?” What aspect of the patient’s mental functioning is being tested?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Abstract thinking

 

Abstract thinking refers to the ability to form concepts, generalizations, and relationships between objects or ideas beyond their literal or concrete features.

 

It is commonly tested using:

 

  • Proverb interpretation: e.g., explaining the meaning of “People who live in glass houses shouldn’t throw stones.”
  • Similarity testing: e.g., “What is the similarity between a chair and a table?”

 

A patient demonstrating abstract thinking would respond, “Both are pieces of furniture.”


A patient showing concrete thinking (common in schizophrenia and certain organic brain syndromes) might respond, “Both are kept on the floor,” reflecting a literal, non-abstract association.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Attention: The ability to focus on a specific stimulus, tested using the digit repetition test.

 

Option C. Judgment: The ability to make sound decisions in real or hypothetical situations, tested using scenarios like “What would you do if you saw a house on fire?”

 

Option D. Intelligence: Tested by assessing general information and calculation skills, not by similarity testing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The similarities test assesses abstract thinking, the capacity to identify conceptual relationships—impaired in conditions such as schizophrenia and frontal lobe dysfunction.

choices.text: OFC is below normal; head ultrasound is indicated immediately
OFC is normal; remeasure in 24–48 hours to confirm baseline
OFC is abnormally large; evaluate for hydrocephalus
OFC cannot be interpreted without parental head sizes

questions.text: A term male infant (39 weeks) has an occipitofrontal circumference (OFC) of 33.0 cm at 12 hours of life. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. Weight is 3.0 kg and length 49 cm. Which interpretation is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) OFC is normal; remeasure in 24–48 hours to confirm baseline.

 

  • At term, the normal occipitofrontal circumference (OFC) ranges from approximately 33–37 cm, with an average around 34–35 cm. 
  • This infant’s OFC of 33 cm is within the lower limit of normal. 
  • Because cranial molding from vaginal delivery may transiently alter head shape, OFC should be remeasured after 24–48 hours to establish the true baseline.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. OFC is below normal; head ultrasound is indicated immediately: Incorrect. OFC of 33 cm is normal; immediate neuroimaging is unnecessary without other abnormalities.

 

Option C. OFC is abnormally large; evaluate for hydrocephalus: Incorrect. Hydrocephalus presents with OFC >37–38 cm at birth, bulging fontanelle, or dilated scalp veins.

 

Option D. OFC cannot be interpreted without parental head sizes: Incorrect. Parental OFC comparison may be useful in borderline or later cases, but this newborn measurement is interpretable now.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In term neonates, OFC averages 34–35 cm (range 33–37 cm). 
  • Initial measurement should be repeated after molding resolves to confirm baseline head size.

questions.text: A tall 10-year-old has pectus deformity, long limbs, scoliosis, lens dislocation, and developmental delay. Which feature most points away from Marfan and toward homocystinuria?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ectopia lentis downward and inward

 

Lens displacement is typically superotemporal (upward/outward) in Marfan and inferonasal (downward/inward) in homocystinuria; developmental delay also favors homocystinuria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aortic root dilation on echocardiography: Incorrect. Aortic root dilation supports Marfan.

 

Option C. Positive wrist-thumb sign: Incorrect. Wrist-thumb sign occurs in both.

 

Option D. Hindfoot valgus with pes planus: Incorrect. Foot deformities may occur in Marfan; not discriminative.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inferonasal ectopia lentis and developmental delay suggest homocystinuria rather than Marfan.

choices.text: Hyperinsulinism due to pancreatic islet cell hyperplasia
Low cortisol from congenital adrenal hypoplasia
Transient hypoparathyroidism due to maternal diabetes

questions.text: A macrosomic neonate with macroglossia and omphalocele develops jitteriness at 2 hours of life. Which mechanism best explains this complication?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hyperinsulinism due to pancreatic islet cell hyperplasia

 

  • The triad of macrosomia, macroglossia, and omphalocele is characteristic of Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (BWS), caused by imprinting abnormalities on chromosome 11p15 affecting genes that regulate growth (e.g., IGF-2).
  • These infants often develop neonatal hypoglycemia due to pancreatic islet cell hyperplasia, which leads to excessive insulin secretion. 
  • Hyperinsulinism increases glucose uptake, resulting in symptomatic hypoglycemia manifested by jitteriness or seizures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Low cortisol from congenital adrenal hypoplasia: Incorrect. Congenital adrenal hypoplasia leads to cortisol deficiency but not associated with macroglossia or omphalocele.

 

Option C. Transient hypoparathyroidism due to maternal diabetes: Incorrect. Transient neonatal hypocalcemia due to maternal diabetes is unrelated to this syndrome and presents later.

 

Option D. Increased IGF-2 causing hypercalcemia: Incorrect. IGF-2 overexpression causes overgrowth and tumor predisposition (e.g., Wilms tumor, hepatoblastoma), not hypercalcemia.

 

Educational Objective:


Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome results from imprinting defects on chromosome 11p15 and is characterized by macrosomia, macroglossia, omphalocele, and neonatal hypoglycemia due to hyperinsulinism from islet cell hyperplasia.

choices.text: Abdominal ultrasound every 3 months until 8 years, and AFP every 2–3 months until 4 years
Yearly abdominal ultrasound until adolescence; no AFP needed
Chest CT every 6 months until 8 years
Whole-body MRI annually from birth to 8 years

questions.text: Parents ask about cancer screening for their child diagnosed with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (BWS). Which of the following plan aligns with standard surveillance?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Abdominal ultrasound every 3 months until 8 years, and AFP every 2–3 months until 4 years

 

  • Children with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (BWS) are at increased risk for embryonal tumors—particularly Wilms tumor and hepatoblastoma. Surveillance aims to detect these malignancies early. 
  • Standard recommendations include abdominal ultrasound every 3 months until around 8 years of age to screen for Wilms tumor, and serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) measurement every 2–3 months until 4 years of age to screen for hepatoblastoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Yearly abdominal ultrasound until adolescence; no AFP needed: Incorrect. Annual imaging is insufficient for early detection, and AFP is essential for hepatoblastoma monitoring.

 

Option C. Chest CT every 6 months until 8 years: Incorrect. Chest CT is not part of standard surveillance; metastasis is detected only after a primary tumor diagnosis.

 

Option D. Whole-body MRI annually from birth to 8 years: Incorrect. Whole-body MRI is not routinely indicated and would expose the child to unnecessary interventions.

 

Educational Objective:


Children with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome require serial abdominal ultrasound and AFP surveillance to detect Wilms tumor and hepatoblastoma early, following a regular 3-month interval schedule during early childhood.

questions.text: A 2-week-old neonate presents with severe hypotonia, recurrent seizures, and poor feeding. The parents report a distinct burnt sugar odor in the infant’s urine. Examination reveals lethargy, failure to thrive, and signs of metabolic acidosis. A DNPH (2,4-dinitrophenylhydrazine) test performed on the urine and result is shown in the image below. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies best explains this neonate’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Branched-chain α-ketoacid dehydrogenase

 

  • The clinical picture, odor of burnt sugar in the urine, and metabolic acidosis in a neonate are hallmark features of Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD). 
  • This rare autosomal recessive disorder results from a deficiency of branched-chain α-ketoacid dehydrogenase complex (BCKDC).
  • This enzyme is required for the oxidative decarboxylation of branched-chain amino acids—leucine, isoleucine, and valine.
  • When BCKDC is deficient, these amino acids and their corresponding ketoacids accumulate, causing neurotoxicity. 
  • The DNPH test, which detects ketoacids, produces a yellow-orange precipitate confirming the presence of branched-chain ketoacids in urine.
  • If left untreated, MSUD can lead to severe neurological damage and death. Treatment includes dietary restriction of branched-chain amino acids and supplementation with thiamine in thiamine-responsive variants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isovaleryl-CoA dehydrogenase: Deficiency causes isovaleric acidemia, characterized by a sweaty feet odor and metabolic acidosis, but not the burnt sugar odor or DNPH positivity seen in MSUD.

 

Option B. Dihydrolipoamide dehydrogenase:This enzyme is part of multiple enzyme complexes (e.g., PDH, α-KGDH) and is involved in energy metabolism. Its deficiency may result in lactic acidosis but does not cause branched-chain ketoacid buildup.

 

Option D. Mitochondrial transacylase: This is not a specific term for any enzyme involved in branched-chain amino acid metabolism. It is a distractor in this context and not linked to MSUD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD) is caused by deficiency of branched-chain α-ketoacid dehydrogenase, leading to accumulation of branched-chain amino acids and their toxic ketoacids. 
  • It presents in neonates with hypotonia, seizures, metabolic acidosis, and a characteristic burnt sugar urine odor.

choices.text: Treatment is provided free of cost for BPL patients only
Treatment is provided free of cost for all patients irrespective of economic status
Treatment cost is subsidized by 50% for BPL patients
Treatment is free only for the first 2 months of intensive phase

questions.text: A 35-year-old male diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis belongs to Below Poverty Line (BPL) category. He is concerned about the treatment cost under the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP). What should be told to the patient regarding the cost of anti-tuberculosis treatment under NTEP?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Treatment is provided free of cost for all patients irrespective of economic status

 

  • Under the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP), anti-tuberculosis treatment is provided completely free of cost to all patients regardless of their economic status, whether BPL or APL. 
  • This ensures universal access to TB treatment and removes financial barriers to treatment completion, which is crucial for achieving the goal of TB elimination by 2025.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • NTEP provides completely free anti-tuberculosis treatment to all patients regardless of economic status
  • This universal free treatment policy removes financial barriers and improves treatment completion rates
  • Free treatment includes all drugs, diagnostic tests, and follow-up investigations under NTEP

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with progressive pain and swelling around his distal femur for 3 months. Pain is worse at night and partially relieved by NSAIDs. The physical exam shows a tender, firm mass with mild overlying warmth. X-ray shows a well-defined lytic lesion with a sclerotic rim in the metaphysis of the distal femur. Biopsy finding is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Osteoid osteoma

 

  • This 17-year-old boy with pain and swelling around the distal femur, pain worse at night relieved by NSAIDs, and a small, well-defined lytic lesion with a sclerotic rim on X-ray, has classic features of an osteoid osteoma.

 

Key features:

 

  • Age: Usually seen in adolescents and young adults.
  • Location: Cortex of long bones (especially proximal femur and tibia, but may occur in distal femur).
  • Pain: Severe nocturnal pain relieved by NSAIDs or aspirin due to prostaglandin E2 production by the tumor.
  • X-ray: Small (<2 cm) radiolucent nidus surrounded by reactive sclerotic bone.
  • Histology:
    • Interlacing trabeculae of woven bone lined by osteoblasts (the key diagnostic finding).
    • Minimal atypia and surrounded by vascular connective tissue stroma.
  • The benign nature and small size differentiate it from other aggressive bone tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Giant cell tumor of bone: Incorrect. Occurs in young adults (20–40 years), typically at the epiphysis of long bones. Histology shows numerous multinucleated giant cells in a stromal background, not osteoid trabeculae lined by osteoblasts.

 

Option B. Osteosarcoma: Incorrect. Occurs in adolescents around the metaphysis of long bones (often near the knee) but shows malignant osteoid production, pleomorphic tumor cells, and destructive “sunburst” or Codman triangle appearance on X-ray — not seen here.

 

Option D. Ewing sarcoma: Incorrect. A malignant small round blue cell tumor of bone seen in children and adolescents, usually in the diaphysis, with onion-skin periosteal reaction on imaging and t(11;22) translocation. Histology shows sheets of uniform small round cells, not osteoid trabeculae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Osteoid osteoma is a benign bone tumor of adolescents characterized by severe nocturnal pain relieved by NSAIDs, radiolucent nidus with sclerotic rim, and interlacing trabeculae of woven bone lined by osteoblasts on histology.

questions.text: All of the following are selective glucocorticoids without having any mineralocorticoid activity except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hydrocortisone

 

  • Hydrocortisone is the only option listed that has significant mineralocorticoid activity. 
  • In fact, hydrocortisone is the glucocorticoid with maximum mineralocorticoid activity. 
  • The mnemonic "0M" (Zero Mineralocorticoid) helps remember selective glucocorticoids: Triamcinolone, Dexamethasone, Betamethasone, and Paramethasone all have zero mineralocorticoid activity. 
  • These drugs avoid mineralocorticoid-related side effects like sodium and water retention, edema, hypokalemic alkalosis, and progressive rise in blood pressure. 
  • Hydrocortisone, being similar in structure and activity to the natural hormone cortisol, retains both glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid properties, making it suitable for replacement therapy in adrenal insufficiency where both activities are needed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dexamethasone: It is incorrect because dexamethasone is a selective glucocorticoid with zero mineralocorticoid activity. It has maximum glucocorticoid potency and is long-acting (>36 hours).

 

Option B. Betamethasone: It is incorrect because betamethasone is also a selective glucocorticoid with zero mineralocorticoid activity. It is used antenatally for fetal lung maturation (12 mg IM every 24 hours × 2 doses).

 

Option C. Triamcinolone: It is incorrect because triamcinolone is a selective glucocorticoid with zero mineralocorticoid activity. It is intermediate-acting (12-36 hours).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Hydrocortisone has the highest mineralocorticoid activity among glucocorticoids; dexamethasone, betamethasone, triamcinolone, and paramethasone have zero mineralocorticoid activity.

questions.text:
Regarding the indications for an upper segment (classical) cesarean section, consider the following statements:

  1. It is preferred in cases of placenta accreta syndrome.
  2. It is indicated when a large fibroid occupies the anterior lower uterine segment.
  3. It is performed in cases of extensive adhesions in the lower uterine segment.
  4. Cervical cancer is a contraindication to performing a classical cesarean section.
  5. It may be chosen when the lower uterine segment is underdeveloped, such as in preterm pregnancies.

Which of the following statements are correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3 and 5 only

 

A classical (upper segment) cesarean section involves a vertical incision in the upper uterine segment and is performed only under specific indications where a lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) is not feasible or safe.

 

1. It is preferred in cases of placenta accreta syndrome: The placenta is abnormally adherent, and attempting a lower segment incision risks severe hemorrhage.

 

2. It is indicated when a large fibroid occupies the anterior lower uterine segment: Obstructs access to the lower segment, making incision and delivery difficult.

 

3. It is performed in cases of extensive adhesions in the lower uterine segment: Often occur due to previous surgeries or infections, limiting access to the lower uterus.

 

5. It may be chosen when the lower uterine segment is underdeveloped, such as in preterm pregnancies: In very preterm pregnancies, the lower uterine segment may not be well-formed, requiring a classical incision for adequate access.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 4. Cervical cancer is a contraindication to performing a classical cesarean section: This is incorrect because cervical cancer is actually a contraindication to performing a cesarean section — surgical delivery can worsen bleeding and dissemination. Such cases require specialized obstetric oncology management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A classical (upper segment) cesarean section is indicated when the lower uterine segment cannot be safely used — as in placenta accreta, fibroids, dense adhesions, or an underdeveloped segment — but contraindicated in cervical cancer due to risk of hemorrhage and tumor spread.

questions.text: A patient develops hoarseness following thyroid surgery. Laryngoscopy shows a paramedian position of one vocal cord. Which intrinsic laryngeal muscle is not paralyzed?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cricothyroid

 

  • The cricothyroid muscle is supplied by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve, a branch of the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X).
  • In thyroid surgery, injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) is the most common cause of postoperative vocal cord palsy.
  • The RLN supplies all intrinsic muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid.
  • Therefore, when the RLN is injured, all other intrinsic muscles (posterior cricoarytenoid, lateral cricoarytenoid, thyroarytenoid, interarytenoid) are paralyzed, leaving only the cricothyroid functional.
  • The intact cricothyroid muscle tenses the vocal cord, pulling it toward the paramedian position, which explains the laryngoscopic finding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Posterior cricoarytenoid: 

 

  • The only abductor of the vocal cords.
  • Paralysis leads to inability to open the glottis → cord remains near midline (paramedian).

 

Option C. Lateral cricoarytenoid: 

 

  • Primary adductor of the vocal cords.
  • Paralysis leads to failure of complete glottic closure during phonation.

 

Option D. Thyroarytenoid: 

 

  • Relaxer of the vocal cords.
  • Paralysis results in loss of fine pitch control and hoarseness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The cricothyroid muscle, supplied by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve, is the only intrinsic laryngeal muscle not innervated by the recurrent laryngeal nerve.
  • In recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy, the affected vocal cord assumes a paramedian position, and cricothyroid remains functional.

questions.text: A 28-year-old hiker presents with a recent febrile illness that began 2 weeks after a camping trip in a forested area. He now complains of palpitations and lightheadedness. ECG reveals a first-degree atrioventricular (AV) block. On examination, a faded, annular rash is noted on his left thigh. Which of the following vectors is most likely responsible for transmission of the causative pathogen?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ixodid tick

 

  • The patient exhibits classical signs of Lyme's disease, including:
    • History of forest exposure,
    • Erythema migrans (faded annular rash), and
    • AV conduction abnormality (carditis).
  • Lyme's disease is caused by the spirochete Borrelia burgdorferi and is transmitted by the Ixodid tick (Ixodes scapularis), commonly found in wooded regions.
  • Cardiac involvement, typically manifesting as transient AV block, occurs during the early disseminated phase of the disease. 
  • Diagnosis is clinical in early stages, and serology supports the diagnosis in later stages. 
  • Treatment involves IV ceftriaxone in patients with carditis or neurologic complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aedes aegypti: This mosquito species transmits arboviruses such as Dengue, Chikungunya, Zika and Yellow fever. These viruses do not cause AV block, nor do they present with erythema migrans or cardiac manifestations in the same manner as Lyme disease.

 

Option C. Phlebotomus argentipes: This is the sandfly vector for Leishmania donovani, the agent of visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar). It typically causes fever, hepatosplenomegaly and pancytopenia, not cardiac conduction abnormalities.

 

Option D. Tunga penetrans: A parasitic flea causing tungiasis, which presents as painful cutaneous nodules or ulcers, usually on the feet. It does not transmit systemic infections or cardiac complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Borrelia burgdorferi, the causative agent of Lyme disease, is transmitted by Ixodes ticks. 
  • Cardiac manifestations such as transient AV block can occur in the early disseminated phase. 
  • Early recognition and treatment are critical to avoid long-term sequelae.

choices.text: Screening and Basic management of Mental health ailment
Care for Common Ophthalmic and ENT problems
Bi-weekly super-specialist care in Cardiology and Endocrinology

questions.text: Under the Ayushman Bharat Health and Wellness Centre initiative, the expanded package of services at Ayushman Arogya Mandir includes all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bi-weekly super-specialist care in Cardiology and Endocrinology

 

  • In Ayushman Bharat Health and Wellness Center, under PMJAY
    • Health and wellness center (SHC or PHC)
    • 5 lakh/ Family/ Year
  • Bi-weekly super-specialist care in Cardiology and Endocrinology is not provided at Ayushman Arogya Mandir under AB-HWC.
  • Expanded range of services
    • The expansion of services has been planned in incremental manner
    • As a first step, screening, prevention, control and management of Non communicable diseases and chronic communicable diseases like tuberculosis and leprosy has been introduced at Ayushman Arogya Mandir
      1. Care in pregnancy and childbirth
      2. Neonatal and infant health care services
      3. Childhood and adolescent health care services
      4. Family planning, contraceptive services and other reproductive health care services
      5. Management of communicable disease: National Health Programs
      6. Management of common communicable diseases and General out-patient care for acute simple illnesses and minor ailments
      7. Screening, Prevention, Control and Management of Non-Communicable diseases and chronic communicable diseases like TB and Leprosy
      8. Basic Oral health care
      9. Care for Common Ophthalmic and ENT problems
      10. Elderly and Palliative health care services
      11. Emergency Medical Services
      12. Screening and Basic management of Mental health ailment

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Emergency Medical Services: The expanded package of services includes first-level care for emergencies and trauma (Emergency Medical Services).

 

Option B. Screening and Basic management of Mental health ailment: The expanded package explicitly includes Screening and Basic management of Mental health ailments.

 

Option C. Care for Common Ophthalmic and ENT problems: The expanded package explicitly includes Care for Common Ophthalmic and ENT problems (Eye and ENT care).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The following services were introduced as the expanded range of services at the Ayushman Arogya Mandir apart from the already existing services:

  1. Basic Oral health care
  2. Care for Common Ophthalmic and ENT problems
  3. Elderly and Palliative health care services
  4. Emergency Medical Services
  5. Screening and Basic management of Mental health ailment

choices.text: Upper part of right inferior lobe

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with a history of dysphagia following a stroke aspirates food while lying supine. A subsequent chest X-ray shows lobar consolidation. In the supine position, aspiration pneumonia most commonly involves which lobe of the lung?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Upper part of right inferior lobe

 

  • In the supine position, aspirated material tends to enter the posterior segments of the upper lobes or the superior segment of the lower lobes, most commonly on the right side due to the more vertical orientation of the right main bronchus.
  • When standing or sitting, aspiration more often involves the basal segments of the lower lobes, especially the right lower lobe.

     

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right superior lobe: The superior lobe may be involved only if the patient is sitting upright, where aspirated material tends to settle in the lower parts of the lung fields. However, in the supine position, gravity directs material posteriorly rather than superiorly, so this is incorrect.

 

Option B. Right middle lobe: Aspiration into the middle lobe is less common, as this segment is not aligned with the main bronchial tree’s gravitational path in either upright or supine positions. The middle lobe is more commonly affected in conditions like middle lobe syndrome, not aspiration.

 

Option D. Lingula: The lingula is part of the left upper lobe and can be involved in aspiration on the left side, but aspiration is far more frequent on the right, due to the vertical course of the right main bronchus. Thus, the lingula is an incorrect answer here.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a supine patient, aspirated material most commonly enters the posterior segment of the upper lobe or superior segment of the lower lobe, typically of the right lung, due to bronchial anatomy.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child has a normal bone mineral density. X-ray of his knees is given below. Identify the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Scurvy

 

  • It is the deficiency of vitamin C, causing defect in the osteoid formation. 
  • The rosary found in this condition is sharp and tender. 
  • Radiological Features: 
    • Sclerosed Margins of Epiphysis
    • Osteopenia – ground glass appearance – 1st sign – thinning of cortex (pencil thin cortex).
    • Metaphysis maybe deformed or fractured.
    • Frankel’s line (zone of provisional calcification increases in width and opacity) due to failure of resorption of calcified cartilage and stands out compared to the severely osteopenic metaphysis.
    • Scurvy line or scorbutic zone (Trummerfeld’s zone) – radiolucent transverse band adjacent to the dense provisional zone.
    • Margins of the epiphysis appears sclerotic, termed as ringing of epiphyses or Wimberger’s sign (Ring sign).
    • Lateral metaphyseal spur (Pelkan spur) at ends of metaphysis is produced by outward projection of zone of provisional calcification and periosteal reaction.
    • Corner or angle sign is peripheral metaphyseal cleft.
    • Subperiosteal hemorrhage in lower end of femur and tibia

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rickets:

 

  • In rickets, maturation of osteoid occurs before closure of growth plates, which superimposes the skeletal growth abnormalities i.e., incomplete skeletal calcification and softening of bones. 
  • There is irregular laying of osteoid with widening of osteoid seam and islets into the diaphysis, and thin and weak new trabeculae. 
  • On joint loading, juxta-epiphyseal metaphysis becomes broad and cup-shaped. 
  • The characteristic feature of rickets is thickening and widening of growth plate (physis); indistinct and hazy metaphysis abnormally wide (splaying) with cupping or flaring (Brush-like appearance); and bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices.

 

 

Option C. Osteopetrosis:

 

  • Also called as marble bone disease, it is a diaphyseal dysplasia characterized by failure of bone resorption due to functional deficiency of osteoclast. 
  • Due to functional deficiency of osteoclasts, calcified chondroid (cartilage) and primitive woven bone persists down into metaphysis and diaphysis leading to osteosclerosis and increased brittleness of bones. 
  • It may present with mild anemia, pathological fractures, premature osteoarthritis, and rarely osteomyelitis of mandible. 
  • Pancytopenia develops resulting in abnormal bleeding, easy bruising, progressive anemia, and failure to thrive. 
  • There is severe infection, esp. in Mandible, and Cranial nerve palsies (2nd, 7th and 8th—blindness and deafness). 
  • Laboratory parameters are serum calcium low, serum PTH high, serum phosphate low and serum ALP high. Radiological hallmark is increased radiopacity of bones. 
  • There is no distinction between cortical and cancellous bone, because intramedullary canal is filled with bone. Rugger jersey spine is seen.

 

 

Option D. Metaphyseal dysplasia:

 

  • Also known as Pyle disease, it is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by flaring of the ends of long bones with relative constriction and sclerosis of the diaphysis and mild cranial sclerosis. 
  • The flared metaphyses are relatively lucent. 
  • The patients are often asymptomatic, although genu valgus deformity may be a feature. 
  • Patients present with short-limb dwarfism characterized by coxa vara, and spinal abnormalities. Radiograph reveals bulbous expansion of metaphysis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given x-ray image in the question is suggestive of features due to vitamin C deficiency, scurvy. 
  • Following are the features seen in a patient with scurvy on a plain radiograph:

questions.text: In a study on post-transcriptional gene silencing, an enzyme that processes precursor RNA into short double-stranded fragments was inhibited, leading to gene upregulation. Which of the following enzyme is inhibited?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dicer

 

  • Dicer is an RNase III endonuclease that processes precursor microRNA (pre-miRNA) and long double-stranded RNA into short ~21–23 nt siRNA/miRNA duplexes, which guide RISC to silence target mRNAs post-transcriptionally.
  • Inhibiting Dicer blocks siRNA/miRNA production, reducing silencing and causing gene upregulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DNA polymerase: DNA replication, not RNA silencing.

 

Option B. Ribonuclease P: Processes tRNA 5′ ends, unrelated to miRNA/siRNA generation.

 

Option D. RNA polymerase II: Transcribes mRNA and many pri-miRNAs but does not process them into short dsRNAs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dicer, an RNase III endonuclease, generates siRNA/miRNA from precursor RNAs; inhibiting Dicer reduces RNA interference and increases target gene expression.

choices.text: Chloroquine 25 mg/kg over 3 days + primaquine single dose
Quinine 600 mg TDS for 7 days + clindamycin 300 mg TDS for 7 days

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant woman at 10 weeks gestation presents with confirmed Plasmodium falciparum malaria. She has high-grade fever and parasitemia but no signs of severe/complicated malaria. What is the most appropriate treatment regimen?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Quinine 600 mg TDS for 7 days + clindamycin 300 mg TDS for 7 days

 

  • During the first trimester of pregnancy, falciparum malaria must be treated promptly and aggressively as it has serious implications for both mother and fetus. 
  • The safest and recommended regimen is quinine 600 mg (10 mg/kg) three times daily for 7 days plus clindamycin 300 mg three to four times daily (20 mg/kg/day) for 7 days. 
  • This combination can be used safely during all trimesters of pregnancy and is the preferred option during the first trimester. 
  • Quinine is a rapidly acting erythrocytic schizontocide that has been proven safe in pregnancy, particularly in the first trimester. 
  • Clindamycin, abacteriostatic antibiotic with slow-acting schizontocidal properties, markedly potentiates quinine's antimalarial activity and can be used safely in children and pregnant women, unlike doxycycline which is contraindicated. 
  • The combination ensures effective parasite clearance while maintaining fetal safety. 
  • Patients should be monitored for cinchonism (headache, blurred vision, tinnitus, deafness) and hypoglycemia, both known side effects of quinine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT) for 3 days: It is incorrect because safety of ACT during the first trimester is unproven. Artemisinin-based combination therapy may be used during second and third trimesters as a better-tolerated 3-day alternative, but should be avoided in the first trimester due to insufficient safety data.

 

Option B. Chloroquine 25 mg/kg over 3 days + primaquine single dose: It is incorrect because chloroquine-resistant P. falciparum is now widespread in India, making chloroquine an inappropriate choice for falciparum malaria regardless of pregnancy status. Additionally, primaquine is contraindicated in pregnancy due to risk of hemolysis in G6PD-deficient fetuses.

 

Option D. Mefloquine 15 mg/kg single dose + artesunate: It is incorrect because mefloquine can cause neuropsychiatric adverse effects and should not be used in cerebral malaria or during first trimester. The combination with artesunate represents an ACT regimen that lacks sufficient first-trimester safety data.

 

Educational Objective:

 

First-trimester falciparum malaria in pregnancy requires 7-day treatment with quinine plus clindamycin, which is safe across all trimesters; ACT may be considered only in second and third trimesters.

choices.text: A positive slide test confirms S. aureus infection without further testing.
A negative slide test rules out all coagulase-producing organisms.
A positive slide test should be confirmed with a tube coagulase test.
Slide coagulase test detects both bound and free coagulase.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding interpretation of the slide coagulase test?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A positive slide test should be confirmed with a tube coagulase test.

 

  • The slide coagulase test detects bound coagulase (also known as clumping factor), which causes visible clumping of bacteria when mixed with plasma.
  • While a positive result (seen on the left side of the image) suggests coagulase production, it does not definitively confirm Staphylococcus aureus because other species like S. lugdunensis may also produce bound coagulase.
  • Therefore, a positive slide coagulase test must always be confirmed with the tube coagulase test, which detects free coagulase, the definitive marker for S. aureus identification.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A positive slide test confirms S. aureus infection without further testing: Incorrect. While S. aureus is slide coagulase positive, so is S. lugdunensis. Without confirming the presence of free coagulase via the tube test, we cannot conclusively identify S. aureus.

 

Option B. A negative slide test rules out all coagulase-producing organisms: Incorrect. Staphylococcus schleiferi, for example, is slide coagulase negative but tube coagulase positive. Thus, a negative slide test does not rule out coagulase positivity.

 

Option D. Slide coagulase test detects both bound and free coagulase: Incorrect. The slide coagulase test detects only bound coagulase (clumping factor). Free coagulase is detected exclusively by the tube coagulase test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • S. aureus is coagulase-positive in both tube and slide coagulase tests.
  • Other Staphylococcus species:
    • S. lugdunensis → slide coagulase positive only
    • S. schleiferi → tube coagulase positive only
    • S. epidermidis, S. saprophyticus → coagulase negative

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with increasing fatigue, pallor, and splenomegaly. His CBC shows Hb 9.5 g/dL, WBC 3,200/μL, platelets 70,000/μL. A bone marrow aspirate is attempted but results in a dry tap. A biopsy shows a fibrotic marrow with clusters of atypical megakaryocytes. JAK2 mutation is positive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Myelofibrosis

 

  • This 50-year-old man presents with fatigue, pallor, splenomegaly, pancytopenia (low Hb, WBC, and platelets), a dry tap on bone marrow aspiration, and a fibrotic marrow with atypical megakaryocytes — all classic features of primary myelofibrosis, a chronic myeloproliferative neoplasm.
  • Key diagnostic features of Myelofibrosis:

 

Clinical:

 

  • Progressive fatigue, pallor (due to anemia), and massive splenomegaly (due to extramedullary hematopoiesis).

 

Laboratory:

 

  • Pancytopenia due to bone marrow failure.
  • Teardrop-shaped RBCs (dacrocytes) on peripheral smear.
  • JAK2 V617F mutation positive in ~50–60% of cases.

 

Bone marrow findings:

 

  • Dry tap due to fibrosis.
  • Biopsy shows marrow fibrosis and clusters of atypical megakaryocytes, which release fibrogenic growth factors (e.g., PDGF, TGF-β), leading to reactive stromal proliferation.
  • The splenomegaly occurs due to extramedullary hematopoiesis as the bone marrow becomes progressively fibrotic and unable to produce blood cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute myeloid leukemia (AML): Incorrect. AML typically presents with pancytopenia and blast cells (>20%) in bone marrow or blood. The marrow is usually hypercellular, not fibrotic, and a dry tap with megakaryocytic clusters is not characteristic.

 

Option B. Hairy cell leukemia: Incorrect. Also presents with pancytopenia and splenomegaly, and may cause a dry tap due to marrow fibrosis. However, the bone marrow biopsy shows lymphocytes with cytoplasmic projections (“hairy cells”), and the immunophenotype is CD11c+, CD25+, CD103+. JAK2 mutation is absent.

 

Option D. Chronic myeloid leukemia (CML): Incorrect. CML shows marked leukocytosis, basophilia, and splenomegaly. The bone marrow is hypercellular, not fibrotic, and the Philadelphia chromosome (BCR-ABL fusion) is characteristic, not JAK2 mutation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Primary myelofibrosis is a chronic myeloproliferative disorder characterized by JAK2 mutation, bone marrow fibrosis, atypical megakaryocytes, pancytopenia, and massive splenomegaly due to extramedullary hematopoiesis.
  • A dry tap on bone marrow aspiration is a hallmark finding.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with patchy hair loss. On trichoscopic examination, segmentation of the hair follicle is noted. Which structure demarcates the upper and lower portions of the hair follicle?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Arrector Pili Muscle

 

  • The arrector pili muscle is a small band of smooth muscle that connects the hair follicle to the dermal tissue. 
  • Its point of attachment divides the follicle into two anatomical zones — the upper follicle (above the attachment) associated with the sebaceous gland and pilo-sebaceous unit, and the lower follicle (below it), containing the bulb where active hair growth occurs. 
  • This muscle also aids thermoregulation by producing ‘goosebumps’ when contracted.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stem Cells: Located in the bulge region of the follicle; responsible for regeneration, not segmentation.

 

Option B. Huxley’s Layer: Part of the inner root sheath; plays no role in dividing follicular segments.

 

Option D. Adamson’s Fringe: Marks the lower border of the keratogenous zone, not the upper-lower follicle junction.

 

Educational Objective:


The arrector pili muscle demarcates the upper and lower portions of the hair follicle and is key in both structure and thermoregulation.

questions.text: All of the following tests are done weekly to monitor feeding regimens except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vit. D

 

Monitoring of patients receiving enteral or parenteral nutrition is essential to assess adequacy, detect complications, and guide therapy adjustments.

 

The frequency of investigations depends on the phase of feeding (initiation, stabilization, or maintenance) and the clinical stability of the patient.

 

Weekly Monitoring Parameters:

 

  • Hematological and metabolic tests:
    • Complete Blood Count (CBC)
    • Electrolytes (in stable patients, may shift from daily to weekly)
    • Serum albumin and total proteins
    • Calcium, zinc, and copper
    • Thiamine, Vitamin B12, and folate
    • Serum triglycerides (important for patients on lipid emulsions)

 

These tests help monitor for nutritional adequacy, infection, inflammation, or metabolic disturbances.

 

Vitamin D, however, is not monitored weekly — its level reflects long-term nutritional status, not short-term metabolic changes.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: It is indicated for primary prevention of coronary artery disease
It decreases the risk of colon cancer
It decreases the risk of breast cancer with long-term use
It decreases the risk of endometrial cancer in women with an intact uterus

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It decreases the risk of colon cancer

 

Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) is primarily used to relieve vasomotor symptoms (e.g., hot flashes, night sweats) and prevent postmenopausal osteoporosis. It is not recommended for cardiovascular or cancer prevention due to associated risks.

 

  • Protective effect on colon: Studies, including the Women’s Health Initiative (WHI), show that combined estrogen–progestin therapy modestly reduces the risk of colorectal cancer. However, this benefit is outweighed by other risks, including breast cancer and thromboembolic events.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is indicated for primary prevention of coronary artery disease: Incorrect. HRT is not recommended for primary or secondary prevention of cardiovascular disease. In fact, it may increase the risk of myocardial infarction, stroke, and venous thromboembolism in older postmenopausal women.

 

Option C. It decreases the risk of breast cancer with long-term use: Incorrect. Prolonged combined HRT (estrogen + progestin) increases the risk of breast cancer. The risk rises with duration of therapy and declines after discontinuation.

 

Option D. It decreases the risk of endometrial cancer in women with an intact uterus: Incorrect. Estrogen-only therapy increases the risk of endometrial carcinoma in women with an intact uterus. Adding progestin counteracts this risk, so combined therapy is required for women who have not undergone hysterectomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) may reduce the risk of colorectal cancer, but it is not indicated for preventing cardiovascular disease or cancers. 
  • It increases breast and endometrial cancer risk (if unopposed estrogen is used) and should only be used for short-term symptom relief in carefully selected postmenopausal women.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man with major depressive disorder has been on sertraline 100 mg/day for 8 weeks with good response. He now complains of sexual dysfunction. All of the following strategies can help manage this adverse effect except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increasing the SSRI dose

 

  • Sexual dysfunction (decreased libido, anorgasmia, delayed ejaculation) is a common and dose-related adverse effect of SSRIs, occurring in 30-60% of patients. 
  • It results from increased serotonin at 5-HT2 and 5-HT3 receptors. Increasing the SSRI dose would worsen sexual dysfunction, not improve it, as the effect is dose-dependent. 
  • Management strategies include: (1) Waiting for spontaneous improvement (though often doesn't occur), (2) Dose reduction if clinically feasible, (3) Drug holidays (especially with short-acting SSRIs like sertraline, paroxetine—skipping doses on weekends), (4) Adding bupropion (which increases dopamine/norepinephrine), (5) Switching to antidepressants with lower rates of sexual dysfunction (bupropion, mirtazapine, vilazodone), (6) Adding phosphodiesterase inhibitors (sildenafil) in men.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adding bupropion: This is a correct management strategy. Bupropion, which inhibits dopamine and norepinephrine reuptake without affecting serotonin, can counteract SSRI-induced sexual dysfunction. It can be added to the existing SSRI or used as monotherapy. Studies show it improves sexual function in 50-60% of patients.

 

Option B. Switching to mirtazapine: This is a correct management strategy. Mirtazapine has lower rates of sexual dysfunction compared to SSRIs (5-10% vs 30-60%). It works by blocking 5-HT2 and 5-HT3 receptors and α2-adrenergic receptors, with a different mechanism than SSRIs. It would be appropriate to switch if sexual dysfunction is intolerable.

 

Option D. Drug holiday on weekends: This is a CORRECT management strategy. For short half-life SSRIs like sertraline or paroxetine, skipping Friday and Saturday doses can improve sexual function on weekends without significant loss of antidepressant effect. This doesn't work well for long half-life SSRIs like fluoxetine.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

SSRI-induced sexual dysfunction is dose-dependent; management includes dose reduction, drug holidays, adding bupropion, or switching to alternatives like mirtazapine or bupropion, not increasing the SSRI dose.

choices.text: Perivascular neutrophilic infiltrate with fibrinoid necrosis
Loss of Schwann cells and segmental demyelination
Loss of oligodendrocytes with relative preservation of axons
Neuronal loss with Lewy body inclusions in cytoplasm

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents with blurred vision in one eye that developed over a few days. Two months later, she experiences weakness in both lower limbs and urinary urgency. Neurologic examination reveals loss of vision in the right eye and increased tone with brisk reflexes in the lower limbs. MRI brain shows periventricular plaques, and MRI spine shows patchy demyelinating lesions in the cervical cord. CSF analysis reveals elevated IgG index with oligoclonal bands on electrophoresis. Which of the following pathologic features is characteristic of her disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Loss of oligodendrocytes with relative preservation of axons

 

  • This 29-year-old woman with recurrent episodes of optic neuritis (blurred vision) and motor weakness with urinary urgency, MRI showing periventricular plaques and spinal demyelination, and CSF with oligoclonal IgG bands, has Multiple Sclerosis (MS).
  • Multiple Sclerosis is a chronic, immune-mediated demyelinating disease of the central nervous system (CNS) characterized by autoimmune destruction of myelin and oligodendrocytes in the brain and spinal cord.
  • Pathologic features:
    • Loss of oligodendrocytes, leading to segmental demyelination.
    • Relative preservation of axons (in early lesions).
    • Perivascular lymphocytic (T-cell and macrophage) inflammation.
    • Formation of gliotic scars (plaques) in white matter, particularly periventricular, optic nerve, and spinal cord regions.
  • This demyelination disrupts nerve conduction, leading to the classic relapsing-remitting neurologic deficits (visual, sensory, motor, and autonomic symptoms).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Perivascular neutrophilic infiltrate with fibrinoid necrosis: Incorrect. This is characteristic of vasculitis, such as polyarteritis nodosa or microscopic polyangiitis, not MS. MS lesions show lymphocytic (T-cell), not neutrophilic, inflammation.

 

Option B. Loss of Schwann cells and segmental demyelination: Incorrect. This describes peripheral nervous system demyelination, as seen in Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) or chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP). MS affects CNS myelin (oligodendrocytes), not PNS myelin (Schwann cells).

 

Option D. Neuronal loss with Lewy body inclusions in cytoplasm: Incorrect. This finding is typical of Parkinson disease or Lewy body dementia, not a demyelinating disorder. MS primarily affects myelin and oligodendrocytes, not neuronal cell bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multiple Sclerosis is a CNS demyelinating disorder characterized by autoimmune destruction of oligodendrocytes, resulting in loss of myelin with relative preservation of axons, periventricular plaques, and oligoclonal IgG bands in CSF.

choices.text: Nail pitting is of deep irregular and coarse type
Joint involvement seen in 5–30% of patients
Deficient Th1 and Th17 Helper Cells

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with silvery scaly plaques on the extensor surfaces and nail pitting. Which of the following statements is not true regarding psoriasis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Deficient Th1 and Th17 Helper Cells

 

  • Psoriasis is an inflammatory, non-infectious disorder caused by overactivation of Th1 and Th17 immune pathways, leading to cytokine-mediated keratinocyte proliferation. 
  • It is associated with HLA-C*06:02, especially in early-onset disease. 
  • Joint involvement (psoriatic arthritis) occurs in 5–30% of cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nail Pitting is of deep irregular and coarse type: Common finding, typically deep and irregular — true.

 

Option B. Genetic Predisposition HLA-C*06:02: HLA-C*06:02 is well-established — true.

 

Option C. Joint Involvement seen in 5–30% of patients: Psoriatic arthritis is a known association — true.

 

Educational Objective:


Psoriasis involves overactive Th1/Th17 pathways, not deficiency — leading to hyperproliferative inflammatory lesions.

questions.text: A researcher is studying point mutations in the beta-globin gene. She identifies a single nucleotide substitution in the coding sequence where the codon GAC (coding for aspartic acid) is changed to GAG (coding for glutamic acid). Which of the following best describes this type of mutation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Conserved mutation

 

  • A conserved mutation refers to a change in a nucleotide sequence that alters one amino acid to another with similar biochemical properties (e.g., charge, polarity, or size), often preserving the function and structure of the resulting protein.
  • In this case:
    • GAC codes for aspartic acid (Asp).
    • GAG codes for glutamic acid (Glu).
  • Both Asp and Glu are acidic amino acids with similar chemical properties (negatively charged side chains), so this is considered a conservative (or conserved) substitution—the protein function is likely retained.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Silent mutation: A silent mutation does not change the amino acid due to redundancy in the genetic code. Here, the amino acid changes (Asp → Glu), so this is not silent.

 

Option B. Nonsense mutation: A nonsense mutation introduces a premature stop codon, resulting in a truncated protein. That is not the case here.

 

Option D. Non-conserved mutation: This would involve a substitution leading to an amino acid with different biochemical properties, potentially disrupting protein function. Since Asp and Glu are similar, this is not a non-conserved change.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A conserved mutation is a nucleotide substitution that changes an amino acid to another with similar chemical properties, minimizing functional disruption of the protein. An example is Asp (GAC) to Glu (GAG), both acidic amino acids.

questions.text: Which type of hernia is depicted in the following diagram?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Maydl’s hernia

 

The diagram shows Maydl's hernia/Hernia-en-W/Retrograde hernia, where 2 loops of the bowel remain in the sac with the connecting loop inside the abdomen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Richter's hernia: In Richter's hernia, a small portion of the antimesenteric wall of the intestine is trapped within the hernia. Strangulation can occur without the presence of intestinal obstruction. Clinically, it mimics gastroenteritis.

 

 

Option B. Pantaloon hernia: In pantaloon hernia, both direct and indirect hernia occur on the same side.

 

Option C. Littre's hernia: In Littre's hernia, Meckel's diverticulum is the content.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The diagram illustrates a Maydl’s hernia, a condition where two bowel loops are within a hernial sac with the intervening segment lying within the peritoneal cavity and at risk for strangulation.

choices.text: Administer a hemostatic agent through the chest tube
Continue resuscitation for the next 6 hours

questions.text: A 49-year-old male patient was brought to the ER after a road traffic accident. On examination, the following was noted in X-ray. Tube thoracostomy was done and around 1850 ml blood was drained in 1 hour. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Emergency thoracotomy

 

  • In massive hemothorax, presence of >1500 ml blood in ICD immediately is an indication for thoracotomy.
  • Given the significant blood loss (1850 ml) and the critical condition of the patient, emergency thoracotomy is the most appropriate management.
  • It allows for direct access to the bleeding source for immediate control of bleeding and repair of injuries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Administer a hemostatic agent through the chest tube: This is not appropriate when there is a massive blood loss.

 

Option B. Continue resuscitation for the next 6 hours: While resuscitation is necessary, immediate control of bleeding is critical in this case.

 

Option C. Urgent thoracentesis: This is not the suitable intervention for a severe condition like this.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of significant blood loss and critical condition, emergency thoracotomy is essential to control bleeding and repair injuries immediately.

questions.text:
In which of the following documentary evidence alone can be allowed as proof without the need of oral evidence in the court?

 

  1. Victim who died after giving Dying declaration 
  2. Report from Director of Fingerprint Bureau
  3. A witness willing to provide a written statement but don’t want to attend court due to anxiety.
  4. Deposition recorded in a lower court where cross-examination occurred
  5. Injury report by a government medical doctor of a reputed institute
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 4 only

 

  • The Indian Evidence Act provides specific exceptions under which documentary evidence is admissible without requiring oral testimony.
  • These include:

 

Statement 1. Victim who died after giving Dying declaration: Dying declaration is admissible when the person is dead and the statement relates to the cause and circumstances of death.

 

Statement 2. Report from Director of Fingerprint Bureau: Reports from designated government experts such as the Director of Fingerprint Bureau are admissible under Section 293 of CrPC without summoning the expert to court.

 

Statement 4. Deposition recorded in a lower court where cross-examination occurred:  Depositions from prior court proceedings are allowed, provided cross-examination occurred.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 3. A witness willing to provide a written statement but don’t want to attend court due to anxiety: Anxiety does not qualify as an exception. Documentary substitution is not allowed unless legally excused (e.g., death, untraceability).

 

Statement 5. Injury report by a government medical doctor of a reputed institute: A medical report is always required to be testified orally by the doctor in the court.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Exception to oral evidence (where document alone is acceptable):

 

  1. Dying declaration
  2. Expert opinions expressed in a book
  3. Deposition of a medical witness taken in  a  lower court
  4. Evidence given by a witness  in  a  previous  judicial proceeding
  5. Statements by persons who  cannot  be  called  as  witnesses: e.g. dead, untraceable etc.
  6. Report of  certain government scientific experts:
    1. Chemical  Examiner 
    2. Chief  Controller  of  Explosives,
    3. Director  of Fingerprint  Bureau,
    4. Director of a Central Forensic Science Laboratory

questions.text: A 72-year-old male presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of worsening dull, aching pain in his left thigh and a noticeable bowing of his left leg. He reports a subjective feeling of warmth over the affected area. Physical examination confirms the anterior bowing of the left tibia and palpable warmth over the mid-shaft of the bone. Laboratory tests reveal an elevated serum Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP) level with normal serum calcium and phosphate levels. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Paget's Disease

 

  • Also known as Osteitis Deformans, it is a chronic disorder of the adult skeleton in which localized areas of bone resorption and formation are highly accelerated and disorganized, leading to structurally weak and deformed bone.
  • It typically affects people over the age of 50-55, fitting the 72-year-old male.
  • Dull, aching bone pain and progressive bone deformity are hallmark signs.
  • Increased local warmth is a common sign due to the highly active, rapidly remodelling bone.
  • Isolated, marked elevation of serum Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP) is the classic biochemical signature, reflecting the massive increase in osteoblast activity (bone formation phase) following the initial lytic phase. Serum calcium and phosphate remain normal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteoporosis:

 

  • A systemic skeletal disease characterized by low bone mass and microarchitectural deterioration of bone tissue, leading to increased bone fragility and fracture risk.
  • Osteoporosis is typically asymptomatic until a fracture occurs. It does not cause local warmth, significant long-bone bowing, or an isolated elevated ALP.
  • ALP is usually normal, unless a recent fracture has occurred. Serum calcium and phosphate are also typically normal.

 

Option B. Osteomyelitis:

 

  • An infection of the bone, most commonly bacterial.
  • While it causes pain and local warmth, the onset is usually acute or subacute, often accompanied by fever, chills, and other signs of systemic illness. The pain is typically more intense and throbbing.
  • It does not cause the progressive bowing/enlargement deformity described in the case.
  • Though ALP may be slightly elevated, the characteristic lab finding is a marked elevation of inflammatory markers (ESR and CRP), and often an elevated White Blood Cell (WBC) count, which are not mentioned.

 

Option C. Fibrous Dysplasia:

 

  • A benign bone disorder where normal bone is replaced by abnormal fibro-osseous tissue.
  • Fibrous dysplasia is a developmental disorder typically diagnosed in children or young adults. Presentation in a 72-year-old is highly unusual.
  • ALP may be mildly elevated if the disease is extensive (polyostotic), but the levels are often not as high as in Paget's disease. The classic clinical triad of the case (pain, bowing, warmth, and isolated high ALP) does not align with a late-onset presentation of this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The case describes a classic presentation involving bone pain, deformity (bowing), local warmth, and an isolated, significantly elevated Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP) in an elderly patient. 
  • This combination points strongly to a condition involving rapid, disorganized bone turnover.

questions.text: A team of biochemists is studying an enzyme involved in an essential metabolic pathway to develop a new class of inhibitors for therapeutic use. To determine the type of inhibition, they perform enzyme kinetics experiments and analyze the results using a Lineweaver–Burk plot (double reciprocal plot).The results show two straight lines that are parallel to each other — one representing the enzyme without inhibitor and the other in the presence of the inhibitor. Further analysis reveals that, in the presence of the inhibitor, both the maximum velocity (Vmax) and the Michaelis constant (Km) of the enzyme are decreased. Which type of enzyme inhibition does this pattern represent?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Uncompetitive inhibition

 

  • To interpret enzyme inhibition, we analyze changes in Vmax and Km using enzyme kinetic plots such as the Lineweaver–Burk plot (1/V vs 1/[S]).
  • In this case:
    • The two lines are parallel, meaning they never intersect.
    • This indicates that both Vmax decreases and Km decreases proportionally.
    • Therefore, the slope (Km/Vmax) remains constant.
  • This kinetic pattern is characteristic of uncompetitive inhibition.

 

Mechanism of Uncompetitive Inhibition:

 

  • The inhibitor binds only to the enzyme–substrate (ES) complex, not to the free enzyme.
  • This binding locks the substrate in the enzyme, preventing product formation.
  • As a result:
    • Vmax decreases → because some enzymes are “trapped” in the ES–inhibitor complex.
    • Km decreases → because substrate binding is stabilized (ES complex is more easily formed).
  • Hence, both Vmax and Km decrease, giving parallel lines on the Lineweaver–Burk plot.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Competitive inhibition:

 

  • Inhibitor competes with substrate for the active site.
  • Km increases, Vmax unchanged.
  • Lines intersect on the y-axis (not parallel).

 

Option C. Non-competitive inhibition:

 

  • Inhibitor binds both free enzyme and ES complex at an allosteric site.
  • Vmax decreases, Km unchanged.
  • Lines intersect on the x-axis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Uncompetitive inhibition often occurs with multi-substrate enzyme systems, and it’s less common than competitive or non-competitive inhibition.
  • Some drugs that target enzymes in metabolic or signaling pathways act through uncompetitive mechanisms to maintain specificity under certain cellular conditions.

 

Summary Table of Enzyme Inhibition Types:

questions.text: A 32-year-old multiparous woman opts for permanent contraception. Which method of tubal sterilization is most commonly performed during cesarean section?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pomeroy technique

 

  • This 32-year-old multiparous woman desires permanent contraception and is planned for tubal sterilization during a cesarean section.
  • Among the available methods, the Pomeroy technique is the most commonly performed method of tubal ligation during cesarean delivery.
  • Procedure summary:
    • A loop of the fallopian tube (usually the isthmic portion) is elevated.
    • A catgut suture is tied at the base of the loop to create a knuckle.
    • The looped segment is then excised, leaving two sealed ends.
    • The cut ends subsequently undergo fibrosis, ensuring permanent occlusion.
  • Advantages of the Pomeroy technique:
    • Simple, safe, and quick.
    • Can be performed easily during cesarean section or minilaparotomy.
    • Low failure rate.
    • Easy to identify tube ends if reanastomosis is attempted later.
  • Thus, the Pomeroy method is the preferred and most widely used technique for tubal sterilization during cesarean section.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Filshie clips: Incorrect. Filshie clips are mechanical occlusion devices applied laparoscopically for interval sterilization, not commonly during cesarean section.

 

Option C. Essure device: Incorrect. The Essure device is a hysteroscopic method of tubal occlusion placed via the cervix, used for interval sterilization. It is not suitable intraoperatively or during cesarean section.

 

Option D. Irving technique: Incorrect. The Irving method involves burying the proximal cut end of the tube into the uterine muscle. It is more complex and time-consuming, reserved for repeat sterilization after failure of a previous method, not routine use during cesarean section.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Pomeroy technique is the most common method of tubal sterilization during cesarean section, as it is simple, reliable, and effective, involving ligation and excision of a loop of the fallopian tube.

choices.text: TORCH screening; treat specific infection if positive
Antiphospholipid antibody panel; aspirin + heparin if positive
Thyroid function tests; levothyroxine if hypothyroid

questions.text: A 30-year-old G4A3 presents for preconception counseling. She had first miscarriage at 8 weeks, second at 11 weeks with absent fetal cardiac activity, and third pregnancy loss at 24 weeks due to early-onset severe preeclampsia with fetal demise. She is otherwise healthy. What is the most appropriate investigation and treatment for future pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Antiphospholipid antibody panel; aspirin + heparin if positive

 

  • A 30-year-old G4A3 seeking preconception counseling with losses at 8 weeks, 11 weeks with absent fetal cardiac activity, and 24 weeks due to early-onset severe preeclampsia with fetal demise, while otherwise healthy, fits placental-mediated pregnancy morbidity from antiphospholipid syndrome (APS). 
  • Test the antiphospholipid antibody panel (lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin IgG/IgM, anti-β2-glycoprotein I IgG/IgM) and confirm persistence ≥12 weeks apart. 
  • In future pregnancy, low-dose aspirin + heparin (LMWH) improves live-birth rates and reduces preeclampsia/placental complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TORCH screening; treat specific infection if positive: Infections are uncommon causes of recurrent early miscarriage and do not explain early-onset severe preeclampsia at 24 weeks or fetal demise; routine TORCH testing is not recommended for this scenario.

 

Option C. Thyroid function tests; levothyroxine if hypothyroid: Thyroid disease can contribute to loss, but it does not account for the combination of 8- and 11-week miscarriages (absent cardiac activity) plus a 24-week preeclampsia-related fetal demise; not the most appropriate targeted evaluation here.

 

Option D. Genetic karyotyping; preimplantation genetic testing: Parental karyotyping/PGT may address chromosomal causes of early loss (often in IVF contexts) but does not address placental/immune pathology; it fails to explain early-onset severe preeclampsia at 24 weeks suggestive of APS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recurrent early losses plus a second-trimester fetal demise from early-onset severe preeclampsia → evaluate for APS with an antiphospholipid antibody panel and treat future pregnancy with low-dose aspirin + heparin if positive.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with cirrhosis presents 18 hours after his last drink with tremors, sweating, tachycardia, mild confusion, and visual hallucinations. Which drug is most appropriate for managing his alcohol withdrawal?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lorazepam

 

  • Lorazepam represents the optimal benzodiazepine choice in this cirrhotic patient experiencing alcohol withdrawal.
