  • Unlike other benzodiazepines, lorazepam undergoes direct glucuronide conjugation without forming active metabolites. 
  • This metabolic pathway remains relatively preserved even in advanced liver disease, preventing drug accumulation and enhanced toxicity. 
  • The patient's clinical presentation—tremor, autonomic hyperactivity, mild confusion, and visual hallucinations—indicates moderate alcohol withdrawal syndrome requiring prompt benzodiazepine intervention. 
  • Oxazepam shares similar safety characteristics but has slower, more irregular absorption making lorazepam preferable for acute management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chlordiazepoxide: While historically the "commonest BZD used to cover alcohol withdrawal," chlordiazepoxide has a t½ of 6-12 hours with active metabolites that extend duration of action. In cirrhosis, these metabolites accumulate, leading to prolonged sedation and potential hepatic encephalopathy. This option could become a distractor if one ignores cirrhosis.

 

Option B. Diazepam: Despite rapid absorption and effectiveness in alcohol withdrawal, diazepam has a biological effect t½ much longer than plasma t½ due to active metabolites. It is contraindicated in liver failure due to metabolite accumulation.

 

Option D. Clonazepam: Though effective as an anticonvulsant, clonazepam forms active metabolites and has prolonged action. It's not the preferred choice for acute alcohol withdrawal management in cirrhotic patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with liver disease requiring benzodiazepine therapy, select agents metabolized by glucuronidation (lorazepam, oxazepam) rather than those forming active metabolites through hepatic oxidation, to prevent drug accumulation and enhanced toxicity.

choices.text: Prolonged use of antimicrobials leads to its deficiency
The dietary requirement is 15–20 mg per day

questions.text: A 65-year-old man is admitted to the hospital with complaints of easy bruising, gum bleeding, and blood in stool for the past few days. His past medical history reveals that he has been on broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy for 3 weeks following a severe urinary tract infection. The physician suspects a vitamin deficiency affecting the blood coagulation cascade. Which of the following statements regarding the suspected vitamin is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prolonged use of antimicrobials leads to its deficiency

 

  • A 65-year-old man admitted with easy bruising, gum bleeding, and blood in stool over the past few days, after broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy for 3 weeks for a severe urinary tract infection, suggests vitamin K deficiency affecting the blood coagulation cascade. 
  • Vitamin K is required for γ-carboxylation (activation) of clotting factors II, VII, IX, X, and proteins C and S. 
  • Prolonged use of antimicrobials decreases gut flora that synthesize vitamin K, so “Prolonged use of antimicrobials leads to its deficiency” is true and explains the bleeding phenotype in this clinical scenario. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It acts as an anticoagulant: Incorrect. The suspected vitamin, vitamin K, functions as a procoagulant cofactor enabling activation of clotting factors; it does not act as an anticoagulant. Deficiency therefore causes bleeding (easy bruising, gum bleeding, blood in stool).

 

Option C. The dietary requirement is 15–20 mg per day: Incorrect. Daily requirements for vitamin K are in micrograms (≈ 90–120 µg/day in adults), not 15–20 mg per day. The patient’s deficiency is driven by 3 weeks of broad-spectrum antimicrobial use rather than inadequate intake alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin K deficiency commonly follows prolonged broad-spectrum antimicrobial therapy due to loss of gut flora–derived vitamin K, leading to impaired γ-carboxylation of clotting factors and bleeding.

questions.text: A screening test for cervical cancer was conducted on 1000 women. The results showed that 80 women tested positive, out of which 60 actually had cervical cancer. Among the 920 women who tested negative, 40 actually had cervical cancer. What is the sensitivity and specificity of this screening test?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sensitivity = 60%, Specificity = 97.8%

 

To calculate sensitivity and specificity, construct a 2x2 table:

 

 

 

  • Sensitivity = TP/(TP+FN) = 60/(60+40) = 60/100 = 60%
  • Specificity = TN/(TN+FP) = 880/(880+20) = 880/900 = 97.8%

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sensitivity measures the ability of a test to correctly identify diseased individuals (TP/(TP+FN))
  • Specificity measures the ability of a test to correctly identify non-diseased individuals (TN/(TN+FP))

questions.text: A 45-year-old man underwent a renal transplant six months ago. He now presents with rising serum creatinine and mild tenderness over the graft site. There are no signs of infection, and urine culture is sterile. Biopsy shows lymphocytic infiltration and vascular endothelial damage. Which of the following immune cells are primarily responsible for this type of graft rejection?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) T lymphocytes

 

  • This patient developed acute transplant rejection occurring within weeks to months (commonly around 6 months) after transplantation.
  • The biopsy findings of lymphocytic infiltration and vascular endothelial damage are typical of acute cellular rejection, which is mediated primarily by T lymphocytes.

 

Mechanism:

 

  • Acute rejection may be:
    1. Cell-mediated (T-cell–mediated):
      • CD8⁺ cytotoxic T cells directly attack graft parenchymal cells and vascular endothelium.
      • CD4⁺ helper T cells release cytokines, leading to inflammation and tissue injury.
    2. Humoral (antibody-mediated):
      • Caused by antibodies against donor HLA antigens.
      • Characterized by vasculitis and C4d complement deposition.
  • In this case, the lymphocytic infiltration indicates T-cell–mediated rejection, which is the most common form of acute rejection after several months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Macrophages: Incorrect. Macrophages are involved mainly in chronic rejection and type IV hypersensitivity, but in acute transplant rejection, T cells play the central role in initiating graft injury.

 

Option B. B lymphocytes: Incorrect. B cells produce antibodies responsible for antibody-mediated (humoral) rejection, which is typically associated with complement deposition and vasculitis, not the cellular infiltrate described here.

 

Option D. Neutrophils: Incorrect. Neutrophils dominate hyperacute rejection, which occurs within minutes to hours of transplantation due to preformed anti-donor antibodies, not in delayed (6-month) rejections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute transplant rejection occurring weeks to months after transplantation is primarily mediated by T lymphocytes, leading to lymphocytic infiltration and endothelial injury in the graft.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presents with chronic cough and unintentional weight loss. A chest CT scan reveals a well-circumscribed mass in the right lower lobe of the lung. Biopsy of the tumor is shown in the image below. IHC staining is performed to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following markers is most likely to be positive in this tumor?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Synaptophysin

 

  • This patient’s presentation—lung mass composed of uniform cells with “salt-and-pepper” chromatin—is consistent with a neuroendocrine tumor such as carcinoid tumor or small-cell carcinoma of the lung.
  • Synaptophysin is a neuroendocrine immunohistochemical marker found in presynaptic vesicles of neurons and neuroendocrine cells.
  • It is strongly positive in neuroendocrine tumors, including:
    • Carcinoid tumors
    • Small-cell carcinoma of the lung
    • Pheochromocytoma
    • Medullary thyroid carcinoma
  • Other common neuroendocrine markers include chromogranin A and neuron-specific enolase (NSE). 
  • The positivity of synaptophysin supports the neuroendocrine origin of the tumor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GFAP: Incorrect. Glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) is an intermediate filament found in astrocytes and other glial cells. It is positive in astrocytomas, glioblastomas, and ependymomas, not in neuroendocrine tumors.

 

Option C. Calretinin: Incorrect. Calretinin is a calcium-binding protein expressed in mesothelial cells. It is used as a marker for mesothelioma and some neural tumors, but it is not characteristic of neuroendocrine tumors.

 

Option D. Cytokeratin: Incorrect. Cytokeratin stains epithelial cells, so it may be positive in carcinomas of epithelial origin. However, while some neuroendocrine tumors may co-express cytokeratin, it is not a specific neuroendocrine marker. Synaptophysin is far more specific for confirming neuroendocrine differentiation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Synaptophysin is a neuroendocrine immunohistochemical marker found in presynaptic vesicles of neurons and neuroendocrine cells. 
  •  It is positive in neuroendocrine tumors, including carcinoid tumors and small-cell carcinoma of the lung.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presents with primary amenorrhea. She has normal breast development (Tanner stage IV) but absent pubic and axillary hair. On examination, a blind-ending vaginal pouch is noted. Karyotype shows 46,XY. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS)

 

  • This 14-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea, normal breast development (Tanner stage IV), absent pubic and axillary hair, blind-ending vaginal pouch, and 46,XY karyotype has features classic for Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS).
  • In AIS, there is a mutation in the androgen receptor gene, leading to end-organ resistance to androgens. Despite having a male (46,XY) karyotype and functioning testes that produce normal or elevated testosterone, the tissues cannot respond to androgens.
  • Key findings include:
    • Normal breast development → due to peripheral aromatization of androgens to estrogens.
    • Absent pubic and axillary hair → due to androgen receptor defect (androgens stimulate hair growth).
    • Blind vaginal pouch, absent uterus and upper vagina → due to anti-Müllerian hormone (AMH) from Sertoli cells causing Müllerian duct regression.
    • 46,XY karyotype confirms a genotypic male.
  • Thus, the most likely diagnosis is Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Turner syndrome: Incorrect. Turner syndrome (45,XO) presents with short stature, streak ovaries, shield chest, and primary amenorrhea, but no breast development and normal pubic hair. Karyotype differs (45,XO, not 46,XY).

 

Option B. Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome: Incorrect. MRKH presents with primary amenorrhea and a blind vaginal pouch, but these patients are 46,XX females with normal pubic and axillary hair and normal ovarian function, unlike AIS (46,XY and absent hair).

 

Option D. Imperforate hymen: Incorrect. Imperforate hymen causes primary amenorrhea due to obstructed menstrual flow, leading to cyclical pain and hematocolpos, but the reproductive tract (uterus, vagina) and secondary sexual characteristics are normal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS) results from a defect in the androgen receptor in a 46,XY individual, leading to female external genitalia, breast development, absent pubic/axillary hair, blind vagina, and absence of uterus and testes in the abdomen or inguinal canal.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding diagnostic testing for Zika virus are correct?

 

  1. IgM ELISA is limited by cross-reactivity with Dengue virus antibodies, reducing its specificity.
  2. Real-time multiplex RT-PCR assays available in India target NS5 of ZIKV, nsP4 of Chikungunya, and 3′UTR of Dengue virus.
  3. Plaque Reduction Neutralization Test (PRNT) is a more specific assay for Zika virus, particularly in regions endemic for multiple flaviviruses.
  4. NS3 protease gene is routinely used as a highly specific PCR target in Zika diagnostics due to its conserved nature.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 3 only

 

Statement 1. IgM ELISA is limited by cross-reactivity with Dengue virus antibodies, reducing its specificity: Correct.  IgM ELISA for Zika virus has poor specificity due to cross-reactivity with other flaviviruses like Dengue, making confirmatory testing essential.

 

Statement 2. Real-time multiplex RT-PCR assays available in India target NS5 of ZIKV, nsP4 of Chikungunya, and 3′UTR of Dengue virus: Correct. In India, multiplex real-time RT-PCR kits detect ZIKV (NS5 region), CHIKV (nsP4), and DENV 1–4 (3′UTR).

 

Statement 3. Plaque Reduction Neutralization Test (PRNT) is a more specific assay for Zika virus, particularly in regions endemic for multiple flaviviruses: Correct. PRNT remains the most specific test to differentiate Zika from other flavivirus infections, especially in endemic areas.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 4. NS3 protease gene is routinely used as a highly specific PCR target in Zika diagnostics due to its conserved nature: Incorrect. NS3 is not the primary PCR target for ZIKV. Instead, NS5 (non-structural protein 5) is used due to its greater specificity and diagnostic utility. NS3 is not widely used due to its variability and less consistent amplification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In endemic settings, RT-PCR and PRNT are more reliable for diagnosing Zika virus due to the cross-reactivity seen in IgM ELISA with other flaviviruses like Dengue. 
  • NS5 is the preferred PCR target, not NS3.

choices.text: Distance from the lower margin of symphysis pubis to sacral promontory
Distance from the midpoint of sacral promontory to the uppermost margin of symphysis pubis
Distance that can be measured clinically on per vaginal examination
Distance from posterior margin of symphysis pubis to tip of sacrum

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida undergoes pelvic assessment. Which of the following represents the true conjugate of the pelvis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Distance from the midpoint of sacral promontory to the uppermost margin of symphysis pubis

 

  • The true conjugate (also known as the anatomical conjugate) is an important anteroposterior diameter of the pelvic inlet.
  • It extends from the sacral promontory to the upper (anterosuperior) margin of the symphysis pubis. This measurement represents the actual bony dimension of the pelvic inlet through which the fetal head must pass during labor.
  • Although it cannot be measured directly on physical examination, it is crucial for assessing pelvic adequacy and is typically estimated indirectly from the diagonal conjugate (measurable on per vaginal examination) by subtracting approximately 1.5–2 cm.
  • Thus, among the options provided, the true conjugate is correctly defined as the distance from the midpoint of the sacral promontory to the uppermost margin of the symphysis pubis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Distance from the lower margin of symphysis pubis to sacral promontory: Incorrect. This represents the diagonal conjugate, not the true conjugate. The diagonal conjugate can be measured clinically on per vaginal examination and is usually 1.5–2 cm longer than the true conjugate.

 

Option C. Distance that can be measured clinically on per vaginal examination: Incorrect. This again refers to the diagonal conjugate, which is clinically measurable, unlike the true conjugate.

 

Option D. Distance from posterior margin of symphysis pubis to tip of sacrum: Incorrect. This describes the obstetric conjugate only partially and inaccurately; the obstetric conjugate actually extends from the sacral promontory to the nearest point on the posterior surface of the pubic symphysis. It is the narrowest fixed diameter of the pelvic inlet and is smaller than the true conjugate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The true conjugate (anatomical conjugate) of the pelvis extends from the sacral promontory to the upper border of the symphysis pubis and represents a key anteroposterior diameter of the pelvic inlet used to assess pelvic adequacy for childbirth.

choices.text: Continue salbutamol and add IV hydrocortisone

questions.text: A 25-year-old asthmatic woman being nebulized with salbutamol suddenly develops facial swelling, urticaria, and BP drops to 70/40 mmHg. She becomes unresponsive. What is the most appropriate immediate intervention?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intramuscular adrenaline 1:1000 (0.5 mL) immediately

 

  • This is anaphylactic shock (likely from nebulizer preservatives like benzalkonium/EDTA). 
  • Adrenaline is DOC for anaphylaxis, and preferred route is IM/SC, NOT IV. 
  • Use 1:1000 concentration (0.5 mL = 0.5 mg) into anterolateral thigh. 
  • IM provides rapid absorption (5-10 min) while avoiding IV bolus risks (severe hypertension, arrhythmias, cerebral hemorrhage). 
  • Repeat at 10 minutes if first dose fails. Only after two failed IM doses consider IV adrenaline 1:10,000 via controlled infusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Continue salbutamol and add IV hydrocortisone: Continue salbutamol and add IV hydrocortisone: Dangerously delays definitive treatment. This is anaphylaxis, not just asthma. Salbutamol only provides β₂ bronchodilation, doesn't address cardiovascular collapse. Hydrocortisone has delayed onset (hours) and prevents biphasic reactions but plays no role in acute management. Adrenaline must be given immediately.

 

Option C. Intravenous adrenaline 1:10,000 via slow infusion: Intravenous adrenaline 1:10,000 via slow infusion: IV adrenaline is NOT first-line. Used only when: (1) two IM doses failed, (2) patient in extremis despite initial IM dose, or (3) ICU setting with monitoring. Starting with IV bypasses safer IM route and exposes to unnecessary risks.

 

Option D. Intravenous isoprenaline 1-2 mg bolus: Intravenous isoprenaline 1-2 mg bolus: Completely inappropriate and potentially fatal. Isoprenaline is pure β-agonist with NO α activity. Causes profound vasodilation (β₂), worsening hypotension. Anaphylaxis requires α₁ vasoconstriction—isoprenaline cannot provide this. The dose stated is also massive and would cause severe arrhythmias.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Anaphylactic shock requires immediate IM adrenaline 1:1000 (0.5 mL) as first-line; IM route is safer than IV, with repeat dosing at 10-minute intervals before considering IV adrenaline 1:10,000.

questions.text: According to 8th AJCC classification of colorectal cancers, involvement of the mesorectum in rectal cancer is staged as?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T3

 

  • The mesorectum refers to the fatty connective tissue surrounding the rectum, which contains lymphatics, blood vessels, and lymph nodes.
  • Involvement of the mesorectum occurs when the tumor penetrates the muscularis propria and extends into the perirectal fat — a defining feature of T3 rectal cancer in the AJCC 8th edition classification.
  • This stage indicates extramural spread but without invasion of adjacent organs or structures, distinguishing it from T4 lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with nails as shown in the picture below. Which of the following features is false regarding her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pitting Edema

 

  • Yellow Nail Syndrome is characterized by the triad of yellow dystrophic nails, non-pitting lymphedema, and pleural effusion. 
  • It results from lymphatic dysfunction. Pitting edema is not seen; rather, the swelling is firm and non-pitting. 
  • The syndrome may also be associated with bronchiectasis, chronic sinusitis, and an increased risk of malignancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Yellow Dystrophic Nails: Thickened, discolored nails due to impaired lymphatic drainage — true.

 

Option B. Increased Risk of Malignancy: True; associated with lymphoma and bronchogenic carcinoma.

 

Option C. Pleural Effusion: Common pulmonary feature — true.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Yellow Nail Syndrome is marked by non-pitting lymphedema, yellow dystrophic nails, and pleural effusion — pitting edema is not a feature.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with headache and seizures. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the brain reveals empty delta sign. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with this radiologic sign?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Superior sagittal sinus thrombosis

 

  • The "Empty delta sign" is a classic radiologic sign seen on contrast-enhanced CT of the brain. 
  • It appears as a triangular area of enhancing dura surrounding a central filling defect within the superior sagittal sinus, indicating thrombosis.
  • This sign is most commonly seen in superior sagittal sinus thrombosis (SSST), where the thrombus prevents contrast from filling the central sinus, while the dura mater around it enhances due to engorged collateral veins and inflammation.
  • It’s a hallmark of cerebral venous sinus thrombosis (CVST) and can be accompanied by symptoms like headache, seizures, papilledema, or focal neurologic deficits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dissecting aortic aneurysm: This is a vascular emergency involving the aorta, not the cerebral venous system. It would not produce an empty delta sign on brain imaging.

 

Option B. Jugular venous thrombosis: While this may present with neck swelling and pain, it does not classically produce the empty delta sign, as that sign is specific to the superior sagittal sinus on intracranial imaging.

 

Option D. Deep venous thrombosis (DVT): Refers to limb vein thrombosis, particularly in the legs. It’s not related to intracranial venous structures, and does not appear on brain CT imaging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The empty delta sign is a characteristic finding on contrast CT in superior sagittal sinus thrombosis and should be recognized as a diagnostic clue for cerebral venous sinus thrombosis.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding α-1 antitrypsin deficiency are correct? 

 

  1. It results from mutations in the SERPINA1 gene leading to misfolded AAT protein accumulation in hepatocytes.
  2. The PiZZ genotype is associated with severe disease and early-onset panacinar emphysema.
  3. Hepatic manifestations occur due to deficiency of circulating AAT leading to unopposed neutrophil elastase activity in the liver.
  4. Periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive, diastase-resistant globules in hepatocytes are characteristic on liver biopsy.
  5. Smoking accelerates lung damage by oxidizing methionine residues in AAT, reducing its antiprotease activity.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Only 1, 2, 4 and 5 are correct

 

Statement 1. It results from mutations in the SERPINA1 gene leading to misfolded AAT protein accumulation in hepatocytes: Correct. AAT is encoded by the SERPINA1 gene on chromosome 14q32.1. Mutant forms (especially Z allele) misfold and accumulate in hepatocytes, leading to hepatotoxicity.

 

Statement 2. The PiZZ genotype is associated with severe disease and early-onset panacinar emphysema: Correct. Homozygous PiZZ individuals produce very low AAT → panacinar emphysema (especially in lower lobes) and juvenile cirrhosis.

 

Statement 4. Periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive, diastase-resistant globules in hepatocytes are characteristic on liver biopsy: Correct. Classic biopsy finding due to accumulated misfolded glycoprotein AAT in the endoplasmic reticulum.

 

Statement 5. Smoking accelerates lung damage by oxidizing methionine residues in AAT, reducing its antiprotease activity: Correct. Cigarette smoke oxidizes methionine residues in AAT, inactivating it → accelerated lung destruction and earlier onset of emphysema.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 3. Hepatic manifestations occur due to deficiency of circulating AAT leading to unopposed neutrophil elastase activity in the liver: Incorrect.
Hepatic injury is due to toxic accumulation of misfolded AAT within hepatocytes, not due to elastase activity in the liver. Elastase-mediated damage occurs in lungs, not liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In AAT deficiency, lung disease is due to lack of antiprotease activity (unopposed elastase), whereas liver disease is due to toxic accumulation of misfolded AAT in hepatocytes (PAS-positive, diastase-resistant globules); PiZZ is severe, and smoking-induced methionine oxidation further impairs AAT.

choices.text: Perform urine pregnancy test, then administer DMPA
Administer DMPA and advise backup contraception for 7 days
Withhold DMPA and start from next menstrual cycle
Administer DMPA without any additional precautions

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman on depot medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA) presents 14 days late for her scheduled injection. She has been sexually active. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Administer DMPA without any additional precautions

 

Depot Medroxyprogesterone Acetate (DMPA) is a progestin-only injectable contraceptive given every 12 weeks (3 months) for effective pregnancy prevention.

 

  • The World Health Organization (WHO) and CDC (U.S. MEC) guidelines allow a grace period of up to 2 weeks (14 days) beyond the scheduled date for the next DMPA injection.
  • During this 2-week window, contraceptive efficacy is maintained, and the woman is still protected.

 

In this scenario:

 

  • The woman is 14 days late, meaning she is still within the acceptable grace period.
  • She has been sexually active, but since the contraceptive protection is maintained during the 2-week window, no pregnancy test or backup contraception is required.
  • Therefore, the DMPA injection should be administered immediately without any additional precautions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Perform urine pregnancy test, then administer DMPA: Incorrect. A pregnancy test is not necessary when the woman is within the 14-day grace period, as ovulation suppression is still effective.

 

Option B. Administer DMPA and advise backup contraception for 7 days: Incorrect. Backup contraception is needed only if the woman is more than 2 weeks late (>14 days) or if there are risk factors for ovulation. In this case, she is exactly 14 days late, and contraceptive protection is still intact.

 

Option C. Withhold DMPA and start from next menstrual cycle: Incorrect. This would leave the patient unprotected and increase the risk of pregnancy. DMPA should not be withheld if within the permitted time frame.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a woman is ≤14 days late for her next DMPA injection, she remains protected from pregnancy. The DMPA dose should be given immediately without pregnancy testing or additional contraception.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with progressive hoarseness of voice and episodes of respiratory distress. On laryngoscopic examination, findings are shown in the image. Histopathology reveals koilocytosis. Which of the following HPV types is most commonly associated with this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HPV 6 and 11

 

  • The image and clinical presentation are classic for Recurrent Respiratory Papillomatosis (RRP), especially in pediatric cases. 
  • This condition is characterized by benign papillomatous lesions on the respiratory epithelium, particularly the larynx. 
  • It is caused by low-risk HPV types 6 and 11, typically transmitted perinatally from the mother.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HPV 16 and 18: These are high-risk oncogenic types associated with cervical, anogenital, and oropharyngeal cancers, not benign respiratory papillomas.

 

Option C. HPV 4 and 27: These types are associated with cutaneous warts (verruca vulgaris), not mucosal papillomas.

 

Option D. HPV 31 and 45: These are also high-risk types linked to cervical dysplasia and malignancy, not laryngeal papillomatosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recurrent laryngeal papillomatosis presenting with verrucous lesions on laryngoscopy is strongly associated with HPV types 6 and 11, not the high-risk oncogenic strains.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements correctly differentiate Entamoeba histolytica from Entamoeba coli?

 

  1. E. histolytica shows unidirectional motility, while E. coli is non-purposeful
  2. E. coli contains RBCs in its cytoplasm
  3. Nuclear karyosome is central in E. histolytica, eccentric in E. coli
  4. Chromatoid bodies are filamentous in E. coli and rounded in E. histolytica
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 3 and 4 only

 

Statement 1. E. histolytica shows unidirectional motility, while E. coli is non-purposeful: Correct. Entamoeba histolytica shows very active, purposeful, unidirectional motility using finger-like pseudopodia, whereas E. coli displays sluggish, non-purposeful motility with blunt pseudopodia.

 

Statement 3. Nuclear karyosome is central in E. histolytica, eccentric in E. Coli: Correct. The karyosome in E. histolytica is small and centrally located; in E. coli, it is large and eccentric.

 

Statement 4. Chromatoid bodies are filamentous in E. coli and rounded in E. Histolytica: Correct. Chromatoid bodies of E. histolytica are thick with rounded ends, while those of E. coli are filamentous with thread-like ends.

 

Incorrect statement:

 

Statement 2. E. coli contains RBCs in its cytoplasm: Incorrect. E. coli does not ingest RBCs; this is a key differentiator from E. histolytica, which often does.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Entamoeba histolytica Vs Entamoeba coli:

 

 

Cyst Characteristics:

choices.text: Loss of myenteric ganglion cells (Auerbach plexus) in the esophageal wall
Intestinal metaplasia of squamous epithelium at the gastroesophageal junction
Mucosal ulceration with transmural lymphoid aggregates

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with progressive dysphagia, initially to solids and later to liquids, along with regurgitation of undigested food and nocturnal cough. There is no history of weight loss or hematemesis. Barium swallow shows marked dilatation of the esophagus with a distal narrowing (“bird-beak” appearance). Manometry reveals failure of relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES). Which of the following histopathologic findings is most characteristic of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Loss of myenteric ganglion cells (Auerbach plexus) in the esophageal wall

 

  • This 45-year-old man has progressive dysphagia (initially to solids, later to liquids), regurgitation of undigested food, and nocturnal cough, along with bird-beak narrowing on barium swallow and failure of LES relaxation on manometry — classic features of achalasia cardia.

 

Pathogenesis:

 

  • Achalasia results from loss of inhibitory ganglion cells (that produce nitric oxide and VIP) in the myenteric (Auerbach) plexus of the esophageal wall.
  • This causes:
    1. Failure of LES relaxation → functional obstruction.
    2. Aperistalsis in the distal esophagus.
    3. Progressive esophageal dilatation proximally.

 

Histologic finding:

 

  • Loss of myenteric (Auerbach) ganglion cells between the circular and longitudinal muscle layers of the esophagus.
  • Inflammatory changes may be seen in early stages, followed by fibrosis and muscle hypertrophy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intestinal metaplasia of squamous epithelium at the gastroesophageal junction: Incorrect. This describes Barrett esophagus, a complication of chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), not achalasia.

 

Option C. Submucosal fibrosis with eosinophilic infiltration: Incorrect. Seen in eosinophilic esophagitis, typically associated with atopy and dysphagia in young adults, not with LES dysfunction or bird-beak deformity.

 

Option D. Mucosal ulceration with transmural lymphoid aggregates: Incorrect. Characteristic of Crohn disease, which can involve the GI tract anywhere from mouth to anus, but not the esophagus in this pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Achalasia cardia is caused by loss of myenteric (Auerbach) plexus ganglion cells, leading to failure of LES relaxation, aperistalsis, and esophageal dilatation, producing the characteristic bird-beak appearance on barium swallow.

choices.text: Increase in lever ratio due to ossicular chain
Area ratio between tympanic membrane and stapes footplate
Phase lag compensation by tensor tympani
Resonance of the auditory canal enhancing low frequencies

questions.text: Which of the following best describes how the middle ear amplifies sound energy to overcome impedance mismatch between air and cochlear fluid?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Area ratio between tympanic membrane and stapes footplate

 

  • The middle ear acts as an impedance-matching transformer, enabling efficient energy transfer from air to cochlear fluid. 
  • The key mechanisms are:
    1. Area ratio advantage — the tympanic membrane ≈55 mm²) is ~17× larger than the stapes footplate ≈3.2 mm²), concentrating pressure at the oval window.
    2. Lever ratio — malleus and incus act as a lever 1.3:1).
      Together, these give ~20–25 dB amplification.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase in lever ratio due to ossicular chain: The lever ratio contributes partly but is not the main mechanism.

 

Option C. Phase lag compensation by tensor tympani: Tensor tympani modulates vibration to protect from loud sounds, not impedance matching.

 

Option D. Resonance of the auditory canal enhancing low frequencies: External canal resonance aids frequency selectivity, not impedance conversion.

 

Educational Objective:


The area ratio between tympanic membrane and stapes footplate provides the principal pressure gain for efficient sound transmission to the cochlea.

choices.text: The 2-year-old child due to highest risk of progression to active TB
The 55-year-old female with chronic cough as a potential secondary case
The 59-year-old diabetic male due to immunocompromised status
The 25-year-old pregnant woman due to pregnancy-associated immunosuppression

questions.text: A 31-year-old newly diagnosed pulmonary tuberculosis patient registers at a PHC. During household contact screening, the ASHA worker identifies 4 household contacts, as mentioned in below options. Following current NTEP guidelines for sequential contact investigation, which contact requires the most immediate priority for clinical evaluation and TST/IGRA testing?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The 55-year-old female with chronic cough as a potential secondary case

 

  • According to NTEP guidelines, household contact screening follows a sequential priority approach. 
  • The primary objective is to identify additional active TB cases (secondary cases) rather than just identifying contacts at risk of developing TB. 
  • The 55-year-old female with chronic cough represents the highest immediate priority as she has symptoms suggestive of active tuberculosis and needs urgent evaluation to rule out active disease. 
  • Once active cases are excluded or treated, then focus shifts to preventive therapy for high-risk contacts like children under 6 years. 
  • The sequential approach prioritizes: 1) Symptomatic contacts for active case detection, 2) Children <6 years for preventive therapy, 3) Other vulnerable groups.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The 2-year-old child due to highest risk of progression to active TB: While children <6 years are high priority for TPT, symptomatic contacts take precedence for immediate evaluation to detect active TB cases.

 

Option C. The 59-year-old diabetic male due to immunocompromised status: Diabetic contacts are important but asymptomatic immunocompromised individuals come after symptomatic contacts in the screening sequence.

 

Option D. The 25-year-old pregnant woman due to pregnancy-associated immunosuppression: Pregnant women require special consideration but screening symptomatic contacts for active disease takes priority over asymptomatic high-risk groups.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • NTEP contact screening follows sequential priority: symptomatic contacts first, then children <6 years, then other vulnerable groups.
  • All household contacts of pulmonary TB patients should be screened, but timing and priority follow evidence-based protocols.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman is admitted with a week of abdominal pain and fevers. Her serum creatinine is 4.1 mg/dL (previously 1.0 mg/dL), and urine sediment shows dysmorphic red blood cells. Serologies are pending. Kidney biopsy reveals crescentic glomerulonephritis on light microscopy. What is the least likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hemolytic uremic syndrome

 

  • Crescentic glomerulonephritis signifies rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, most often associated with conditions such as ANCA-associated vasculitis and anti-GBM disease, both of which are classic causes and fit this patient’s presentation.
  • IgA nephropathy may infrequently cause crescentic GN, typically after an acute illness, though more often presents with hematuria/proteinuria.
  • Hemolytic uremic syndrome, however, is characterized by microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and AKI usually due to endothelial injury (often from Shiga toxin-producing E. coli), not by crescentic glomerulonephritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ANCA vasculitis: A leading cause of crescentic glomerulonephritis and very consistent with this history and pathology.

 

Option B. Anti-glomerular basement membrane disease: Frequently causes rapidly progressive GN with crescent formation.

 

Option D. IgA nephropathy: Rarely, aggressive cases result in crescentic GN, so less likely but still possible compared to HUS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Crescentic glomerulonephritis is a pathological hallmark of rapidly progressive GN, most commonly from ANCA-associated vasculitis and anti-GBM disease, but is not a feature of hemolytic uremic syndrome, which involves a thrombotic microangiopathy mechanism.

choices.text: Person-to-person spread has been confirmed in nosocomial outbreaks
Aspiration is the most common mode of infection
Contaminated aerosol from air conditioners can be a source
Direct instillation during respiratory procedures is a known route

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding transmission of Legionella except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Person-to-person spread has been confirmed in nosocomial outbreaks

 

  • Legionella species are transmitted via environmental exposure, primarily from contaminated water sources (air conditioners, cooling towers, humidifiers).
  • Aspiration of contaminated water is the most common route.
  • Aerosol inhalation and direct inoculation during respiratory procedures are also recognized routes.
  • There is no evidence of human-to-human transmission, even during hospital outbreaks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Legionella spreads through environmental water sources, not between humans. Hence, infection control focuses on water system maintenance, not patient isolation.

questions.text: A batch of improperly refrigerated mackerel causes flushing, dizziness, and nausea in several individuals within an hour of consumption. Subsequent microbiological analysis reveals gram-negative bacteria colonizing the fish muscle. Which of the following bacterial species is most commonly associated with this form of foodborne illness?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Morganella morganii

 

  • Scombroid fish poisoning is caused by ingestion of preformed histamine due to bacterial decarboxylation of histidine in fish muscle. 
  • This occurs when fish such as tuna or mackerel are not properly refrigerated, allowing bacteria to proliferate. 
  • The most common organism implicated is Morganella morganii, a gram-negative rod known to produce histidine decarboxylase, which converts histidine into histamine—leading to allergy-like symptoms despite absence of true IgE-mediated hypersensitivity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Escherichia coli: Although it is part of the enteric flora and can contribute to histamine production, it is not the most common bacteria associated with scombroid fish poisoning.

 

Option B. Pseudomonas aeruginosa: It may be found in spoiled fish but is less frequently implicated in histamine production causing scombroid reactions.

 

Option D. Proteus vulgaris: Part of the Proteeae tribe, like Morganella, but is less frequently associated with clinically significant histamine production in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Scombroid fish poisoning is caused by ingestion of histamine in spoiled fish and most commonly linked to Morganella morganii, not by true allergic mechanisms. 
  • Proper refrigeration is essential to prevent this foodborne illness.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with end-stage renal disease requires the creation of an arteriovenous (AV) shunt for hemodialysis access in the lower limb. During preoperative vascular mapping, the surgeon identifies an artery located posterior to the medial malleolus and approximately 2.5 cm anterior to the tendon of the calcaneus, which is suitable for anastomosis with the great saphenous vein. Which artery is most likely used for this AV shunt?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Posterior tibial artery

 

  • The posterior tibial artery, a terminal branch of the popliteal artery, is the principal artery of the posterior compartment of the leg. 
  • It travels downward, accompanied by the tibial nerve, and passes behind the medial malleolus within the tarsal tunnel, lying 2.5 cm anterior to the tendon of the calcaneus (Achilles tendon).
  • Because of its superficial and accessible position, it is often selected for arteriovenous (AV) shunting with the great saphenous vein in patients requiring hemodialysis access—especially when upper limb veins are unsuitable.
  • The pulse of this artery is also palpated behind the medial malleolus, making it a key landmark in peripheral vascular examination.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior tibial artery: This artery passes through the interosseous membrane between medial & lateral malleolus to enter the anterior compartment of the leg and continues as the dorsalis pedis artery on the dorsum of the foot. It lies anteriorly, not posteriorly, and therefore is not used for AV shunt formation behind the medial malleolus.

 

Option C. Peroneal artery: A deep branch of the posterior tibial artery, it supplies the lateral compartment of the leg but lies deep and close to the fibula, making it inaccessible for surgical procedures such as AV shunting.

 

Option D. Dorsalis pedis artery: This is the continuation of the anterior tibial artery on the dorsum of the foot, located near the tendons of the extensor hallucis longus and extensor digitorum longus. It is not located posterior to the medial malleolus and hence not suitable for AV shunt with the great saphenous vein.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The posterior tibial artery, located behind the medial malleolus and anterior to the Achilles tendon, is commonly used for arteriovenous shunt creation with the great saphenous vein in hemodialysis patients due to its accessibility and reliable flow.

questions.text: The choledochal cyst that most resembles an accessory gallbladder is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type II

 

  • True diverticulum of the CBD.
  • Appears as a saccular outpouching from the CBD—mimics an accessory gallbladder in shape and location.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type I: Fusiform dilation of the common bile duct (CBD). This is a continuous dilation of the CBD, not a diverticulum-like structure.

 

Option C. Type III: Choledochocele (dilation of distal CBD within duodenal wall). Located intraduodenally, not resembling gallbladder anatomy.

 

Option D. Type IV:  Multiple cysts, intrahepatic and/or extrahepatic. Complex and diffuse cystic disease—not localized or gallbladder-like.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Type II choledochal cysts are rare and present as isolated diverticula off the CBD, often mistaken for accessory gallbladders on imaging.
  • Surgical excision is typically curative, and differentiation from gallbladder duplication is crucial for operative planning.

choices.text: The disease increases the risk of colorectal carcinoma
There is transmural inflammation involving the full thickness of the bowel wall
Toxic megacolon is a known complication
Extraintestinal manifestations may include primary sclerosing cholangitis

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with chronic bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain. Colonoscopy shows continuous mucosal inflammation starting from the rectum. Biopsy reveals crypt abscesses and pseudopolyps. All of the following statements about her disease are true, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) There is transmural inflammation involving the full thickness of the bowel wall

 

  • The clinical picture—chronic bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, colonoscopy with continuous mucosal inflammation starting from the rectum, and biopsy showing crypt abscesses and pseudopolyps—is classic for ulcerative colitis (UC).
  • UC is limited to the mucosa and submucosa, not transmural; therefore, the statement that there is transmural inflammation involving the full thickness of the bowel wall is incorrect for this disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The disease increases the risk of colorectal carcinoma: True.
Long-standing, extensive UC increases colorectal cancer risk; surveillance colonoscopy is recommended.

 

Option C. Toxic megacolon is a known complication: True. Toxic megacolon is a life-threatening complication associated with severe UC.

 

Option D. Extraintestinal manifestations may include primary sclerosing cholangitis: True. UC is linked to PSC, along with other extraintestinal features (e.g., arthritis, uveitis, skin disease).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ulcerative colitis shows continuous, rectum-starting mucosal inflammation with crypt abscesses and pseudopolyps and is not transmural; complications include toxic megacolon, PSC, and increased colorectal cancer risk.

choices.text: It is the drug of choice for paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia
It has the shortest half-life (<10 seconds) among antiarrhythmic drugs
It should be given as a slow intravenous infusion
It does not fit into Class I to IV classes of Vaughan William’s classification of antiarrhythmic drugs

questions.text: Regarding adenosine in the treatment of arrhythmias, all are true except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It should be given as a slow intravenous infusion

 

  • Adenosine must be given as a rapid IV push (bolus injection) into a central or large peripheral vein, NOT as slow infusion. 
  • Due to its extremely short half-life (<10 seconds), adenosine is rapidly degraded in blood. 
  • Slow infusion would result in complete drug degradation before reaching the heart, making it ineffective. 
  • Rapid bolus injection ensures adequate drug concentration reaches the AV node to terminate PSVT before metabolism occurs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is the drug of choice for paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia: Adenosine is the DOC for paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). It terminates re-entry circuits involving the AV node by causing transient AV block.

 

Option B. It has the shortest half-life (<10 seconds) among antiarrhythmic drugs: Adenosine has the shortest t½ (<10s) of all antiarrhythmics due to rapid uptake by red blood cells and metabolism. This ultra-short duration is advantageous for safety.

 

Option D. It does not fit into Class I to IV classes of Vaughan William’s classification of antiarrhythmic drugs: Adenosine is classified separately in Others/miscellaneous drugs along with digoxin, atropine, and magnesium. Doesn't fit into Classes I-IV based on ion channel effects.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Adenosine must be given as rapid IV push (not slow infusion) due to its ultra-short half-life (<10 seconds) to ensure adequate drug delivery before metabolism.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to the acute onset of a painful limp and a complaint of right groin and knee pain that began 24 hours ago. His parents mention he was recovering from a mild viral upper respiratory infection three days prior. He resists passive movement of the right hip, but his pain is significantly worse with internal rotation and abduction. Laboratory tests reveal a normal leukocyte (WBC) count and a minimally elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). A bedside ultrasound shows a small, unilateral hip joint effusion. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transient Synovitis

 

  • A common, self-limiting inflammation of the hip joint's synovial lining. It is the most frequent cause of acute hip pain and limping in children aged 3 to 10.
  • Fits the typical age range (3-10 years).
  • Often follows a mild viral upper respiratory infection (URI) 1-3 weeks prior, as described.
  • Presents with acute limp and vague pain referred to the groin or knee. Pain is worse with movement, especially internal rotation and abduction.
  • Typically shows a normal or minimally elevated WBC count and a minimally elevated ESR/CRP. These normal or near-normal inflammatory markers are crucial for distinguishing it from Septic Arthritis.
  • Usually shows a small, unilateral hip joint effusion on ultrasound, consistent with simple inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Legg-Calvé-Perthes Disease:

 

  • Idiopathic avascular necrosis (death) of the capital femoral epiphysis (the ball of the hip joint).
  • LCPD has a more insidious (gradual) onset and is a chronic condition, often presenting with a gradual, painless limp over months. It is not typically preceded by an acute viral illness.
  • ESR and WBC counts are usually normal, which complicates its differentiation from transient synovitis, but the acute, 24-hour onset in this case argues against the slow progression of LCPD. The definitive diagnosis is made via X-ray (later stage) or MRI (earlier stage).

 

Option C. Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis:

 

  • A heterogeneous group of chronic arthritides with onset before age 16.
  • While it can present with an acute flare, JIA is characterized by chronic joint symptoms lasting at least six weeks. A 24-hour history is too short for a definitive diagnosis.
  • JIA usually shows more consistently elevated inflammatory markers (ESR/CRP) and often involves multiple joints over time.

 

Option D. Septic Arthritis:

 

  • Bacterial infection of the joint space (usually Staphylococcus aureus in this age group), a true orthopaedic emergency.
  • While it presents with an acute, painful limp and a severely restricted, painful hip, the systemic signs are key.
  • Septic Arthritis almost always presents with the "sepsis" pattern, defined by the Kocher Criteria (high sensitivity for ruling out infection): High Fever (>38.5°C or 101.3°F), inability to bear weight (severe pain).
  • Significantly elevated ESR (usually >40mm/hr) and CRP (usually > 2.0 mg/dL).
  • Significantly elevated WBC count (often > 12,000/mm3).
  • Crucially, the patient's normal WBC and minimally elevated ESR rule out Septic Arthritis with high confidence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The case describes the classic presentation of a transient hip irritation in a young child: acute onset of limp/pain, preceding viral illness, minimal systemic signs, and hip effusion without frank infection. 
  • This scenario requires a careful ruling out of Septic Arthritis, which is a surgical emergency.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with persistent postcoital bleeding for 3 months. On speculum examination, a friable cervical growth is noted. Punch biopsy confirms squamous cell carcinoma. Clinical examination reveals a 3 cm cervical lesion with bilateral parametrial involvement extending to the pelvic sidewall. There is no hydronephrosis on imaging. What is the FIGO stage of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IIIB

 

  • On clinical examination, there is a 3 cm cervical lesion with bilateral parametrial involvement extending to the pelvic sidewall. 
  • In the FIGO (2018) cervical cancer staging system, extension to the pelvic sidewall places the disease in Stage IIIB, regardless of lesion size (e.g., 3 cm) or histology (squamous cell carcinoma). 
  • The statement that there is no hydronephrosis on imaging is noted; hydronephrosis (or a non-functioning kidney) is another independent criterion for Stage IIIB, but its absence does not downstage a tumor that already extends to the pelvic sidewall. 
  • Therefore, given bilateral parametrial involvement reaching the pelvic sidewall on clinical examination of a friable cervical growth proven by punch biopsy to be squamous cell carcinoma, the FIGO stage is IIIB.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IIB: Incorrect. IIB = parametrial involvement without pelvic sidewall; here it extends to the pelvic sidewall (and there is no hydronephrosis on imaging), so not IIB in this 35-year-old woman with squamous cell carcinoma (punch biopsy), friable cervical growth (speculum examination), 3 cm, persistent postcoital bleeding for 3 months.

 

Option B. IIIA: Incorrect. IIIA = lower third of vagina without sidewall; this case has bilateral parametrial involvement extending to the pelvic sidewall on clinical examination of a 3 cm squamous cell carcinoma (punch biopsy) after persistent postcoital bleeding for 3 months and friable cervical growth; no hydronephrosis on imaging noted.

 

Option D. IVA: Incorrect. IVA = adjacent organ (bladder/rectum) mucosa; here only pelvic sidewall involvement is described with no hydronephrosis on imaging, in a 35-year-old woman with punch biopsy–confirmed squamous cell carcinoma, 3 cm, friable cervical growth on speculum examination, persistent postcoital bleeding for 3 months → IIIB, not IVA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FIGO: extension to the pelvic sidewall (with or without hydronephrosis) defines Stage IIIB.

questions.text: All of the following drugs cause irreversible ototoxicity except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Macrolides

 

  • Macrolides cause reversible ototoxicity, unlike the other options which cause irreversible damage. 
  • Macrolide-induced ototoxicity manifests as tinnitus and hearing loss, usually with high doses or prolonged therapy, particularly with erythromycin and azithromycin. 
  • The ototoxicity is dose-dependent and reversible upon drug discontinuation, typically resolving within days to weeks. 
  • The mechanism involves temporary effects on cochlear outer hair cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aminoglycosides: Aminoglycosides cause irreversible ototoxicity affecting both cochlear (auditory) and vestibular function. Amikacin causes maximum cochlear toxicity while streptomycin causes maximum vestibular toxicity. The damage results from accumulation in perilymph and endolymph, generating reactive oxygen species that destroy hair cells. Once damaged, cochlear hair cells do not regenerate, making the toxicity permanent.

 

Option B. Cisplatin: This platinum-based chemotherapeutic agent causes irreversible bilateral cochlear damage through direct toxicity to outer hair cells and stria vascularis. High-frequency hearing loss is characteristic and cumulative with dose. The ototoxicity is one of the major dose-limiting side effects of cisplatin therapy, and there is no effective preventive treatment.

 

Option C. Vancomycin: Vancomycin causes irreversible ototoxicity, though less frequently than aminoglycosides. The risk increases with high serum levels (>60-80 mg/L), prolonged therapy, concurrent use of other ototoxic drugs, and renal impairment. The mechanism involves direct toxic effects on cochlear hair cells, resulting in permanent hearing loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Macrolides cause reversible ototoxicity, while aminoglycosides, cisplatin, and vancomycin cause irreversible ototoxic damage to cochlear hair cells.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs has been recently approved by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for the management of schizophrenia and works primarily via a cholinergic (muscarinic) mechanism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cobenfy (xanomeline + trospium)

 

  • Cobenfy is the combination of the muscarinic M1/M4 receptor agonist xanomeline and the peripherally acting muscarinic antagonist trospium. 
  • It has been approved by the FDA for the treatment of schizophrenia in adults. 
  • This marks a novel mechanism of action among antipsychotics, shifting from the traditional dopamine D2 receptor blockade toward acetylcholine (cholinergic) pathways.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lumateperone: Acts via serotonin and dopamine modulation, not a cholinergic mechanism.

 

Option C. Cariprazine: A dopamine D2/D3 partial agonist; not newly approved for schizophrenia nor cholinergic.

 

Option D. Trofinetide: Approved for Rett syndrome (a neurodevelopmental disorder), not for schizophrenia; mechanism unrelated to cholinergic M1/M4 receptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The FDA approval of Cobenfy (xanomeline + trospium) illustrates a paradigm shift in schizophrenia treatment: targeting muscarinic (M1/M4) receptors instead of relying solely on dopamine-D2 receptor antagonism.

choices.text: Primary prevention; highly cost-effective in all populations
Secondary prevention; cost-effective only in high-prevalence areas
Primary prevention; cost-effective mainly in high-prevalence populations

questions.text: A community health program implements administration of iron and folic acid tablets to all adolescent girls in schools regardless of their hemoglobin levels to prevent iron deficiency anemia. This intervention is being evaluated for its cost-effectiveness compared to screening-based targeted supplementation. What level of prevention does this intervention represent, and what is typically its cost-effectiveness profile?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Primary prevention; cost-effective mainly in high-prevalence populations

 

  • Universal iron-folic acid supplementation to adolescent girls regardless of hemoglobin status represents primary prevention as it aims to prevent iron deficiency anemia before it occurs. 
  • However, its cost-effectiveness is mainly justified in populations with high prevalence of iron deficiency, where the number needed to treat is lower, making it more economically viable than targeted screening approaches. 
  • The key phrase "regardless of their hemoglobin levels" indicates this is primary prevention (no screening/detection involved). 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary prevention; highly cost-effective in all populations: While it is primary prevention, universal supplementation is not highly cost-effective in all populations, particularly those with low prevalence of iron deficiency.

 

Option B. Secondary prevention; cost-effective only in high-prevalence areas: This is primary prevention, not secondary prevention, as no screening or early detection is involved in the universal approach.

 

Option D. Secondary prevention; universally cost-effective approach: This represents primary prevention, and cost-effectiveness varies significantly based on population prevalence rates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Universal supplementation without screening represents primary prevention by preventing disease occurrence.
  • Cost-effectiveness of universal interventions depends heavily on disease prevalence in the target population.

choices.text: To obtain a cervical sample for HPV DNA testing
To visualize the cervix during colposcopy
To aspirate uterine contents during dilation and curettage

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is used in gynecological procedures. What is its primary purpose?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) To obtain a cervical sample for HPV DNA testing

 

  • The instrument shown in the image is a Cytobroom (also called a cervical cytobrush).
  • It is primarily used to collect exfoliated cells from the cervix, specifically from the transformation zone, for HPV DNA testing or Pap smear (cytology).
    • The soft nylon bristles allow gentle scraping of both ectocervical and endocervical cells, ensuring a high-quality sample without causing trauma or bleeding.
    • This technique increases the detection accuracy of precancerous cervical lesions caused by high-risk Human Papillomavirus (HPV) strains.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To collect endometrial biopsy samples: Incorrect. Endometrial biopsy requires a Pipelle cannula or Karman cannula, not a cytobroom.

 

Option C. To visualize the cervix during colposcopy: Incorrect. Visualization is done using a colposcope, not a cytological sampling tool.

 

Option D. To aspirate uterine contents during dilation and curettage: Incorrect. Aspiration is performed using a suction cannula, not a brush-type instrument.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A Cytobroom is used to collect cervical samples for HPV DNA testing or Pap smear, helping in early detection of cervical cancer and premalignant lesions.

choices.text: Refer to neurosurgery for transsphenoidal surgery

questions.text: A 45‑year‑old woman with central obesity, facial rounding, and easy bruising has elevated 24‑hour urinary cortisol and failure to suppress cortisol on a low‑dose dexamethasone test. Plasma ACTH is 70 pg/mL (normal 5–60), and pituitary MRI is normal. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Perform high‑dose dexamethasone suppression test

 

  • This patient has confirmed Cushing's syndrome with an elevated plasma ACTH level, indicating ACTH‑dependent disease. 
  • If pituitary MRI is normal, further testing is required to distinguish between a pituitary (Cushing’s disease) and an ectopic ACTH source because it may not show an abnormality in up to 40% of cases (small tumors may fall below the sensitivity of detection). Characteristically, pituitary corticotrope adenomas fail to enhance following gadolinium administration on T1-weighted MRI images.
  • The high‑dose dexamethasone suppression test (and CRH/desmopressin stimulation test) helps evaluate this by assessing whether cortisol secretion is suppressible. 
  • In Cushing’s disease, high‑dose dexamethasone partially suppresses cortisol levels, whereas ectopic ACTH secretion is resistant to suppression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Initiate osilodrostat: It is a steroidogenesis inhibitor that is used after the cause of hypercortisolism is established or when surgery is contraindicated.

 

Option B. Perform late‑night salivary cortisol: Useful for screening, but this patient already has established hypercortisolism.

 

Option C. Refer to neurosurgery for transsphenoidal surgery: Indicated only when Cushing’s disease is confirmed as the source, not before differentiating from ectopic ACTH production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In ACTH‑dependent Cushing’s syndrome, a normal pituitary MRI does not exclude pituitary disease. 
  • A high‑dose dexamethasone suppression test or inferior petrosal sinus sampling is necessary to differentiate pituitary from ectopic ACTH secretion before proceeding to surgery.

questions.text:
All of the following statements about iodinated intravascular contrast agents are accurate, except: 

 

  1. They are used in digital subtraction angiography
  2. They are radio-opaque
  3. They can cause anaphylactic reactions
  4. They are used in magnetic resonance imaging
  5. They are excreted mainly by the kidneys
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4 only

 

Statement 4. They are used in magnetic resonance imaging: False.
Iodinated intravascular contrast media are not used in MRI. MRI utilizes gadolinium-based contrast agents, which alter magnetic properties of tissues—not X-ray absorption like iodine does. Hence, iodinated contrast is irrelevant in MR imaging.

 

Correct Statements:

 

Statement 1. They are used in digital subtraction angiography: Iodinated contrast is commonly used in digital subtraction angiography (DSA) to visualize blood vessels by subtracting pre-contrast images from contrast-enhanced images.

 

Statement 2. They are radio-opaque: These agents are radio-opaque due to iodine content, enhancing visibility on X-ray and CT scans.

 

Statement 3. They can cause anaphylactic reactions: Iodinated contrast can cause anaphylactoid reactions (e.g., urticaria, bronchospasm, hypotension), even in patients without prior allergies.

 

Statement 5. They are excreted mainly by the kidneys: Iodinated contrast is primarily excreted via the kidneys, which is why caution is warranted in patients with renal impairment due to risk of contrast-induced nephropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Iodinated contrast agents are not used in MRI, where gadolinium-based compounds are the contrast of choice. 
  • They are primarily used in CT and angiographic procedures and excreted renally.

questions.text:
Match the syndromes with the appropriate treatment kit and choose the correct combination: 

 

Column A

 

1. Vaginal discharge

2. Genital Ulcer Disease- Non herpetic for patients allergic to penicillin

3. Lower abdominal pain

4. Genital Ulcer Disease- Herpetic

 

Column B
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-B, 2-A, 3-C, 4-D

 

  • The National AIDS Control Organisation (NACO) and Government of India follow a syndromic management approach for sexually transmitted and reproductive tract infections (STIs/RTIs).
  • Each syndrome is treated empirically using a color-coded STI/RTI treatment kit to ensure timely therapy, even before laboratory confirmation.

 

Correct matches and rationale:

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Which of the following correctly matches the mycotoxin to its clinical effect or usage?

 

  1. Fumonisins — Pulmonary edema in pigs
  2. Trichothecenes — Used in biological warfare (Yellow rain)
  3. Zearalenone — Cholangiocarcinoma in humans
  4. Ochratoxin — Balkan endemic nephropathy
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 4 only

 

Statement 1. Fumonisins — Pulmonary edema in pigs: Fumonisins are produced by Fusarium moniliforme and cause pulmonary edema in pigs, equine leukoencephalomalacia, and esophageal carcinoma.

 

Statement 2. Trichothecenes — Used in biological warfare (Yellow rain): Trichothecenes, from Fusarium graminearum, are potent inhibitors of protein synthesis and were used as biological warfare agents (notably yellow rain).

 

Statement 4. Ochratoxin — Balkan endemic nephropathy: Ochratoxin, particularly from Aspergillus ochraceus, causes nephropathy, including Balkan endemic nephropathy.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 3. Zearalenone → Cholangiocarcinoma in humans: Incorrect. Zearalenone is associated with genital and reproductive disorders in pigs, not cancer in humans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mycotoxins vary in their source, clinical presentation, and toxic effects.
  • Linking the correct toxin with its pathology helps in accurate diagnosis, especially in zoonotic and toxicology-related cases.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with high-grade fever, productive cough with thick sputum, and pleuritic chest pain. Chest X-ray shows bulging of the interlobar fissure. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Klebsiella pneumonia

 

  • Klebsiella pneumoniae classically causes a lobar pneumonia with a bulging fissure sign on chest radiograph. 
  • This sign results from intense inflammation and copious exudate production, leading to expansion of the affected lobe, usually the upper lobe. 
  • The thick, mucoid "currant jelly" sputum and association with alcoholics or debilitated individuals are classic features.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Staphylococcal pneumonia: Typically causes bronchopneumonia or necrotizing pneumonia with cavitation or pneumatoceles, not associated with bulging fissures.

 

Option C. Pulmonary edema: Presents with bilateral perihilar infiltrates ("bat wing" appearance), not lobar expansion or fissure bulging.

 

Option D. Pneumoconiosis: Refers to chronic interstitial lung diseases from inhaled dust particles; radiographic findings include reticulonodular opacities, but not lobar consolidation or fissure bulging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The bulging fissure sign on chest X-ray is a classic radiological hallmark of Klebsiella pneumonia, indicating extensive lobar inflammation and consolidation.

choices.text: Failure of tubal opening due to tensor veli palatini dysfunction
Excessive patency of the tube during respiration
Narrow bony isthmus obstructed by cholesteatoma
Overactivity of salpingopharyngeus muscle causing reflux

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy has recurrent otitis media with effusion. Tympanometry shows type C curve. Which functional abnormality of the Eustachian tube best explains this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Failure of tubal opening due to tensor veli palatini dysfunction

 

  • The Eustachian tube equalizes middle ear and nasopharyngeal pressures, ventilating the middle ear.
  • The tensor veli palatini is the principal muscle that opens the tube during swallowing or yawning.
  • Failure of opening leads to negative middle ear pressure → retracted tympanic membrane → Type C tympanogram.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Excessive patency of the tube during respiration: Patulous tube causes autophony hearing one’s own breath, not effusion.

 

Option C. Narrow bony isthmus obstructed by cholesteatoma: Bony obstruction isthmus is rare and unrelated to recurrent effusion.

 

Option D. Overactivity of salpingopharyngeus muscle causing reflux: Salpingopharyngeus assists opening, not closure; overactivity doesn’t cause this pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type C tympanogram indicates negative middle ear pressure due to failure of Eustachian tube opening—commonly from tensor veli palatini dysfunction.

questions.text: A 28-year-old G3P2 woman with previous two cesarean sections presents at 38 weeks gestation in active labor with sudden severe suprapubic pain, vaginal bleeding, and fetal bradycardia. On examination, the uterus is tender, fetal parts are easily palpable abdominally, and there is evidence of shock. What is the most appropriate surgical management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Total hysterectomy

 

  • This 28-year-old G3P2 woman at 38 weeks gestation with previous two cesarean sections presents in active labor with sudden severe suprapubic pain, vaginal bleeding, fetal bradycardia, a tender uterus, fetal parts easily palpable abdominally, and evidence of shock—a classic picture of uterine rupture. 
  • In the setting of a large rupture with hemodynamic instability (shock) and likely extensive lower-segment tear through a prior cesarean scar, the MOST appropriate surgical management is rapid laparotomy with total hysterectomy.
  • A total hysterectomy (leaving the cervix) is faster, controls hemorrhage promptly, and is favored in exsanguinating rupture where speed and hemostasis are paramount. 
  • This approach directly addresses uterine rupture, vaginal bleeding, tender uterus, fetal parts palpable, fetal bradycardia, and shock in active labor after previous cesarean sections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Salpingectomy: Incorrect. This is indicated in a ruptured ectopic pregnancy

 

Option C. Uterine artery ligation only: Incorrect. Uterine artery ligation may reduce bleeding but does not treat the uterine rupture itself. With vaginal bleeding, fetal bradycardia, a tender uterus, and shock, definitive surgical management is required. Ligation alone delays hemostasis and fails to address the full-thickness tear.

 

Option D. B-Lynch compression suture: Incorrect. A B-Lynch compression suture is designed for uterine atony postpartum, not for a full-thickness uterine rupture in active labor with fetal parts palpable and hemodynamic instability. It would not close the defect and not control hemorrhage adequately in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In uterine rupture—especially in active labor after previous cesarean sections with shock, vaginal bleeding, tender uterus, fetal bradycardia, and fetal parts palpable abdominally—the most appropriate, rapid, lifesaving management is subtotal hysterectomy to achieve definitive hemorrhage control.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old female with moderate acne is prescribed two recently approved topical agents. One inhibits androgen receptors, while the other is a fourth-generation retinoid. Which of the following statements is true regarding these drugs?

 

  1. Trifarotene has been approved for acne.
  2. Clascoterone Propionate cream is effective in acne.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both

 

  • Both statements are correct. Clascoterone Propionate 1% cream acts as an androgen receptor inhibitor, reducing sebum production and inflammation.
  • Trifarotene is a topical fourth-generation retinoid effective in acne vulgaris, particularly truncal acne.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clascoterone (androgen receptor blocker) and Trifarotene (fourth-generation retinoid) are newly approved agents for acne management.

choices.text: Decreases the number of LDL receptors exposed at the cell surface, thus LDL uptake is lowered and blood cholesterol levels rise.
Inhibits the binding of apo B to the LDL receptor, thus blocking uptake of the lipoprotein and raising blood cholesterol levels.
Increases the absorption of cholesterol from the intestine.
Increases the synthesis and secretion of VLDL in the liver, leading to increased LDL formation in the blood.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man with a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia comes for routine follow-up. Despite being compliant with a low-fat diet and statin therapy, his LDL cholesterol levels remain elevated. His physician considers adding a newer class of drugs known as PCSK9 inhibitors to his regimen. These monoclonal antibodies act by targeting proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9 (PCSK9), a protein that regulates plasma LDL cholesterol levels. What is the function of PCSK9 on blood cholesterol levels?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreases the number of LDL receptors exposed at the cell surface, thus LDL uptake is lowered and blood cholesterol levels rise.

 

  • PCSK9 binds the LDL receptor (LDLR) on hepatocytes and targets it for lysosomal degradation instead of recycling back to the cell surface. 
  • Fewer surface LDLRs → reduced hepatic LDL uptake → higher plasma LDL-cholesterol. PCSK9 inhibitors (monoclonal antibodies) block this interaction, preserving LDLRs, increasing LDL clearance, and lowering LDL-C.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inhibits the binding of apo B to the LDL receptor, thus blocking uptake of the lipoprotein and raising blood cholesterol levels: Incorrect. PCSK9 does not inhibit apo B–LDLR binding; it promotes LDLR degradation after internalization.

 

Option C. Increases the absorption of cholesterol from the intestine: Incorrect. Increased intestinal cholesterol absorption is mediated via NPC1L1 (target of ezetimibe), not PCSK9.

 

Option D. Increases the synthesis and secretion of VLDL in the liver, leading to increased LDL formation in the blood: Incorrect. PCSK9 does not directly increase hepatic VLDL synthesis/secretion; its principal role is LDLR degradation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PCSK9 promotes degradation of hepatic LDL receptors, decreasing LDL clearance and raising plasma LDL; inhibiting PCSK9 preserves LDLRs and lowers LDL-C.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with secondary amenorrhea for 8 months following a dilatation and curettage for postpartum hemorrhage 10 months ago. She has no vasomotor symptoms. Serum β-hCG is negative. FSH and LH levels are normal. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Perform hysteroscopy

 

  • This 30-year-old woman presents with secondary amenorrhea for 8 months following a dilatation and curettage (D&C) for postpartum hemorrhage. The absence of vasomotor symptoms (e.g., hot flashes) and normal FSH/LH levels indicate that ovarian function and hypothalamic-pituitary axis are intact.
  • Given the history of uterine instrumentation after pregnancy, the most likely diagnosis is Asherman syndrome (intrauterine adhesions). This condition results from fibrosis of the endometrial lining following infection or trauma to the basal layer of the endometrium, commonly after D&C for postpartum hemorrhage or incomplete abortion.
  • The next best step in diagnosis is visualization of the uterine cavity to confirm intrauterine adhesions. hysteroscopy can visualize adhesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start progesterone challenge test: Incorrect. The progesterone challenge test is used to evaluate estrogen status and outflow tract patency in secondary amenorrhea. However, in this case, the most likely cause is intrauterine adhesions after D&C, not hormonal imbalance. Moreover, the patient’s normal FSH/LH and lack of withdrawal bleeding after progesterone would still require imaging — so HSG is more direct.

 

Option C. Start combined estrogen-progesterone therapy: Incorrect. This therapy is used in hypoestrogenic states (e.g., premature ovarian failure, hypothalamic amenorrhea) to restore menstruation. However, the patient has normal gonadotropins, indicating normal estrogen levels, and structural uterine damage is the likely cause — so hormone therapy would not resolve the amenorrhea.

 

Option D. Perform diagnostic laparoscopy: Incorrect. Laparoscopy is useful for evaluating pelvic pathology (endometriosis, ovarian cysts, tubal disease), but not for intrauterine adhesions. The appropriate investigation for intrauterine pathology is HSG or hysteroscopy, not laparoscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Asherman syndrome (intrauterine adhesions) should be suspected in women with secondary amenorrhea after D&C for postpartum hemorrhage or abortion and normal FSH/LH levels. The next best diagnostic step is hysteroscopy to visualize intrauterine adhesions.

choices.text: Classify as no dehydration and advise home-based ORS therapy with zinc supplementation
Classify as some dehydration and give ORS 75 ml/kg over 4 hours at the health facility
Classify as severe dehydration and start IV fluids 100 ml/kg over 3 hours immediately
Classify as some dehydration and refer urgently to higher center for IV fluid management

questions.text: A 12-month-old child is brought to the primary health center with a 3-day history of loose stools (8-10 episodes/day) and vomiting (4-5 episodes/day). On examination, the child is irritable, has sunken eyes, skin pinch goes back slowly (2 seconds), and the mother reports decreased urine output. The child weighs 8 kg and appears lethargic but drinks eagerly when offered water. According to IMNCI guidelines, what is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Classify as some dehydration and give ORS 75 ml/kg over 4 hours at the health facility

 

  • According to IMNCI guidelines, this child has signs of "some dehydration" (moderate dehydration). 
  • The key signs present are: sunken eyes, skin pinch goes back slowly (1-2 seconds), irritable/restless behavior, and drinks eagerly/thirsty. 
  • The child does not have signs of severe dehydration (skin pinch goes back very slowly >2 seconds, lethargic/unconscious, unable to drink). 
  • For a child with some dehydration, IMNCI recommends giving ORS 75 ml/kg over 4 hours at the health facility, along with continued feeding and zinc supplementation. 
  • For an 8 kg child, this would be 600 ml of ORS over 4 hours. The child should be monitored during this period and reassessed after 4 hours.
