  • Oral Rehydration Therapy (First 4 hours: 75 mL/kg):

 

 

(Solution used: WHO Reduced Osmolarity ORS)

  • Intravenous Rehydration (Total dose 100 mL/kg):

 

 

(Solution used: Ringer lactate/Hartmann solution, Diarrhoea treatment solution (DTS))

  • Maintenance Therapy:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Classify as no dehydration and advise home-based ORS therapy with zinc supplementation: The presence of sunken eyes and slow skin pinch indicates "some dehydration," not "no dehydration," requiring facility-based ORS therapy.

 

Option C. Classify as severe dehydration and start IV fluids 100 ml/kg over 3 hours immediately: Signs of severe dehydration (skin pinch >2 seconds, lethargic/unconscious, unable to drink) are not present; IV therapy is not indicated at this stage.

 

Option D. Classify as some dehydration and refer urgently to higher center for IV fluid management: Children with some dehydration can be managed at PHC level with ORS therapy; referral is only needed if signs worsen or severe dehydration is present.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • IMNCI classifies dehydration into three categories: no dehydration, some dehydration, and severe dehydration based on specific clinical signs
  • Some dehydration is managed with ORS 75 ml/kg over 4 hours at health facility with close monitoring and reassessment
  • Key signs of some dehydration include sunken eyes, skin pinch 1-2 seconds, irritable/restless, and drinks eagerly/thirsty
  • Zinc supplementation (10-20 mg daily for 10-14 days) should be given along with ORS therapy for all children with diarrhea

choices.text: Normal zona fasciculata and reticularis in the uninvolved adrenal gland
Nests of chromaffin cells with salt-and-pepper chromatin
Diffuse hyperplasia of zona fasciculata and reticularis
Sheets of large polygonal cells with abundant clear cytoplasm due to lipid

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with weight gain, easy bruising, and irregular menstrual cycles. On examination, she has facial rounding (moon facies), central obesity, and purple striae on the abdomen. Her serum cortisol level is elevated, and ACTH level is suppressed. A CT scan reveals a 3 cm well-circumscribed mass in the left adrenal cortex. Which of the following histologic findings in the lesion is most consistent with her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sheets of large polygonal cells with abundant clear cytoplasm due to lipid

 

  • This 35-year-old woman with Cushing’s syndrome (moon facies, purple striae, central obesity, menstrual irregularity, and ACTH suppression) has an adrenal cortical adenoma, confirmed by CT showing a well-circumscribed adrenal mass and low ACTH.
  • The histologic hallmark of an adrenal cortical adenoma is sheets or nests of large polygonal cells with abundant clear or vacuolated cytoplasm due to intracytoplasmic lipid (cholesterol and steroid precursors).
  • These cells resemble those of the zona fasciculata of the adrenal cortex, which is responsible for cortisol production. 
  • The adenoma leads to excess cortisol secretion, causing ACTH suppression and atrophy of the contralateral adrenal gland.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atrophic zona fasciculata and reticularis in the uninvolved adrenal: Incorrect. Although this finding may occur in the contralateral adrenal gland due to ACTH suppression, it does not describe the lesion itself (the question asks for findings in the tumor). The lesion — the adenoma — is characterized by lipid-laden polygonal cells.

 

Option B. Nests of chromaffin cells with salt-and-pepper chromatin: Incorrect. This describes a pheochromocytoma, a tumor of the adrenal medulla derived from chromaffin cells that produce catecholamines, not cortisol.

 

Option C. Diffuse hyperplasia of zona fasciculata and reticularis: Incorrect. Seen in Cushing disease (pituitary ACTH overproduction) or ectopic ACTH syndrome, where ACTH levels are high. This patient’s ACTH is suppressed, excluding secondary hyperplasia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Adrenal cortical adenomas causing ACTH-independent Cushing’s syndrome are composed of large, clear, lipid-rich cells resembling those of the zona fasciculata. 
  • They produce excess cortisol, leading to ACTH suppression and atrophy of the contralateral adrenal gland.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with a 3-year history of chronic low back and buttock pain. The pain is insidious in onset and primarily affects the sacroiliac region bilaterally. He reports the pain is significantly worse in the early morning and after periods of rest, often waking him from sleep. Crucially, he notes that the pain improves with exercise and physical activity. He exhibits a positive Schober's test. Blood work reveals a positive HLA-B27 antigen test and an elevated C-reactive protein (CRP). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ankylosing Spondylitis

 

  • The prototypical inflammatory spondyloarthropathy, characterized by inflammation of the axial skeleton, peripheral joints, and entheses.
  • Young male presenting with chronic back pain.
  • The Inflammatory Pattern: Insidious Onset and Chronic Duration > 3 months
  • Pain is worse at rest and in the early morning/nocturnal waking.
  • Crucially, improves with exercise/activity (a key differentiator from mechanical pain).
  • Positive Schober's test indicates reduced range of motion due to spinal inflammation/stiffness.
  • Primarily affects the sacroiliac joints and the spine.
  • Positive HLA-B27 (present in over 90% of white AS patients) and elevated CRP (a marker of systemic inflammation).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rheumatoid Arthritis:

 

  • A chronic autoimmune inflammatory disorder primarily affecting the lining of the synovial joints (synovitis), leading to joint damage.
  • RA typically affects peripheral, small joints (MCPs, PIPs, wrists) symmetrically. It generally spares the axial skeleton (low back, buttock, sacroiliac joints), except for the upper cervical spine (atlantoaxial joint) in advanced stages.
  • Low back pain in RA is uncommon and not the primary presentation.
  • RA is associated with HLA-DR4 and other HLA alleles, not HLA-B27.

 

Option C. Lumbar Disc Herniation:

 

  • A mechanical cause of low back pain and/or radiculopathy (pain radiating down the leg), caused by protrusion of the intervertebral disc nucleus pulposus.
  • The Mechanical Pattern: Pain from LDH is typically acute in onset, often following an injury or strain. The pain is usually worse with activity/movement (especially bending, lifting, or prolonged sitting) and improves with rest—the exact opposite of the case description.
  • While severe LDH can cause pain at rest, the defining feature of improvement with exercise is absent.
  • LDH pain is generally localized to the low back and often unilateral radiculopathy (sciatica), not bilateral sacroiliac pain.
  • LDH is a structural/mechanical problem; HLA-B27 is negative, and the CRP is typically normal.

 

Option D. Diffuse Idiopathic Skeletal Hyperostosis:

 

  • A non-inflammatory condition characterized by calcification and ossification of ligaments and entheses, primarily along the anterior and right lateral aspects of the spine.
  • DISH is a disease of the elderly (>50-60) and is often discovered incidentally. It typically causes stiffness rather than prominent pain, and the stiffness is less responsive to exercise.
  • Primarily affects the thoracic spine.
  • It is a non-inflammatory process; therefore, HLA-B27 is negative, and the CRP is normal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The case describes the classic presentation of inflammatory back pain (IBP): onset before age 40, insidious onset, duration > 3 months, morning stiffness, nocturnal pain, and improvement with exercise. 
  • The combination of sacroiliitis, a positive Schober's test, a positive HLA-B27 antigen test, and an elevated CRP is virtually pathognomonic for Ankylosing Spondylitis.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man has had a fixed belief for the past 6 months that his neighbors have hidden cameras in his house to spy on him. He continues his daily work and social life, though he spends time checking walls for these devices. There are no negative symptoms or disorganized behavior. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Delusional disorder

 

According to ICD-11, Delusional Disorder is diagnosed when:

 

  • One or more persistent delusions are present for at least 3 months.
  • Apart from the direct impact of the delusion, the person’s behavior, emotions, and speech remain largely normal. E.g. In this case, where delusion is about neighbours, the behaviour of patient in, say office, is likely to be normal.
  • There are no negative symptoms, disorganized thinking, or grossly disorganized behavior.
  • Hallucinations may occasionally occur, but only if they are brief and match the delusional theme (for example, feeling insects crawling when one believes they are infested).

 

This patient’s long-standing persecutory delusion preserved overall functioning, and lack of other features are consistent with Delusional Disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Schizophrenia: Needs at least two characteristic symptoms (delusions, hallucinations, disorganization, experiences of control, negative symptoms, or catatonia) for ≥ 1 month. Here, only a single fixed delusion is seen.

 

Option B. Schizoaffective disorder: Requires concurrent fulfillment of criteria for schizophrenia and a moderate or severe mood episode (depressive, manic, or mixed), lasting ≥ 1 month. No mood symptoms are mentioned.

 

Option D. Acute and transient psychotic disorder: Has sudden onset within 2 weeks, rapid changes in symptoms, no negative symptoms, and a short duration (usually < 1 month, never > 3 months). The 6-month course here rules this out.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Delusional Disorder (ICD-11) involves persistent delusions lasting ≥ 3 months with otherwise stable behavior and personality. 
  • Brief, theme-related hallucinations may occur, but there are no sustained hallucinations, disorganization, or negative symptoms.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with severe pelvic pain and fever. On examination, a fluctuant mass is palpated in the pouch of Douglas. Which surgical approach is most appropriate for drainage?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Posterior Colpotomy

 

  • This 28-year-old woman presents with severe pelvic pain, fever, and a fluctuant mass in the pouch of Douglas, suggestive of a pelvic abscess—most likely a tubo-ovarian abscess or pelvic peritonitis leading to pus collection in the rectouterine pouch (pouch of Douglas).
  • In such cases, the most appropriate and least invasive surgical approach for drainage is Posterior Colpotomy.
  • Posterior colpotomy involves:
    • Making an incision through the posterior vaginal fornix to access the rectouterine pouch directly.
    • Allowing dependent drainage of pus or infected fluid.
    • Providing rapid relief of symptoms with minimal morbidity.
      It is the preferred route when the abscess is localized, fluctuant, and bulging into the posterior fornix, as in this case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior Colpotomy: Incorrect. Anterior colpotomy involves an incision in the anterior vaginal wall to access the bladder or vesicouterine pouch, used for bladder stone removal or fistula repair, not for drainage of a pouch of Douglas abscess.

 

Option C. Laparotomy: Incorrect. Laparotomy is reserved for ruptured abscesses, diffuse peritonitis, or uncertain diagnosis. It is more invasive and not necessary when the abscess is localized and palpable through the posterior fornix.

 

Option D. Culdocentesis: Incorrect. Culdocentesis is a diagnostic procedure, involving needle aspiration of fluid from the pouch of Douglas. While useful for diagnosis, it is not sufficient for complete drainage of a well-formed abscess.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A pelvic abscess localized to the pouch of Douglas and palpable through the posterior vaginal fornix should be drained via posterior colpotomy, as it provides dependent drainage, rapid relief, and minimal surgical morbidity.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman with hypertension, hyperlipidemia, type 2 diabetes, and Raynaud disease presents with headache and blurred vision over 8 hours; she is afebrile, with HR 100, BP 170/95, RR 18, and O₂ sat 97%. Skin shows blanching telangiectasias, sclerodactyly, and nailfold capillary changes (dilated loops, dropout). Labs reveal Hb 8.6, platelets 54, creatinine 3.9, BUN 78, total bilirubin 4.5 (direct 0.4), and urinalysis negative for protein, blood, and infection. Which autoantibody places her at highest risk for this complication?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anti-RNA polymerase III

 

  • This presentation (scleroderma features, acute hypertension, renal failure, negative urine, anemia, thrombocytopenia) is classic for scleroderma renal crisis, a complication of systemic sclerosis.
  • Anti-RNA polymerase III antibodies are most closely linked to scleroderma renal crisis, often associated with rapidly progressive renal impairment, severe hypertension, and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia.​
  • These autoantibodies signal increased risk for renal crisis and should prompt vigilance for this complication and early ACE-inhibitor therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-Scl70: Anti-Scl70 is associated with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis and pulmonary fibrosis, not specifically with renal crisis.

 

Option B. Anti-dsDNA: Anti-dsDNA is a marker for systemic lupus erythematosus and lupus nephritis.

 

Option C. Anti-U1 ribonucleoprotein (RNP): Anti-U1 RNP is seen in mixed connective tissue disease and is not characteristically linked with scleroderma renal crisis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-RNA polymerase III is the autoantibody most strongly associated with the development of scleroderma renal crisis in systemic sclerosis, indicating heightened risk of acute severe hypertension, renal failure, and microangiopathic features; recognize this antibody for prognostication and management.

choices.text: It may metastasize early via lymphatics and blood
Breslow thickness is an important prognostic factor
It shows junctional activity and pagetoid spread
It commonly arises in pre-existing seborrheic keratosis

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a darkly pigmented, irregular lesion on her back that has recently increased in size and shape. Biopsy shows atypical melanocytes invading dermis. All of the following statements regarding this lesion are true, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It commonly arises in pre-existing seborrheic keratosis

 

  • This 40-year-old woman has a darkly pigmented, irregular lesion on the back that has recently increased in size and shape, and biopsy shows atypical melanocytes invading the dermis—all classic for cutaneous melanoma. 
  • Melanoma does not commonly arise in pre-existing seborrheic keratosis; instead, it typically arises de novo or from a pre-existing melanocytic nevus.
  • Therefore, the statement that it “commonly arises in pre-existing seborrheic keratosis” is false and is the correct choice for the except question.
  • Seborrheic keratosis is a benign epidermal tumor; melanoma does not commonly arise from it. (SKs may be numerous in the Leser–Trélat sign, but that is unrelated to melanoma origin.)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It may metastasize early via lymphatics and blood: True. Melanoma is notorious for early metastasis through both lymphatic channels and hematogenous spread, explaining its high mortality.

 

Option B. Breslow thickness is an important prognostic factor: True. Breslow thickness (measured depth of invasion in millimeters) is the single most important prognostic factor for localized melanoma; greater depth correlates with worse prognosis.

 

Option C. It shows junctional activity and pagetoid spread: True. Melanoma often demonstrates junctional activity (atypical melanocytes along the dermoepidermal junction) and pagetoid spread (upward scatter of atypical melanocytes within the epidermis), consistent with the biopsy of atypical melanocytes invading dermis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Melanoma prognosis is driven by Breslow thickness; it metastasizes early via lymphatic and hematogenous routes and shows junctional activity with pagetoid spread.
  • It does not commonly arise from seborrheic keratosis.

questions.text: A 58-year-old multiparous woman presents with a sensation of "something coming down" per vaginum. On examination with maximum Valsalva maneuver, the most distal portion of the prolapse is 2 cm beyond the hymenal ring, but the vagina is not completely everted. According to the POP-Q staging system, what stage is this prolapse?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stage III

 

In the POP-Q (Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantification) staging system, staging is referenced to the hymenal ring during maximum Valsalva maneuver.

 

  • Stage III is defined as the most distal portion of the prolapse >1 cm beyond (distal to) the hymen but without complete vaginal eversion (i.e., not Stage IV).
  • In this 58-year-old multiparous woman with a sensation of “something coming down” per vaginum, the exam finding that the most distal portion is 2 cm beyond the hymenal ring (i.e., +2 cm) and that the vagina is not completely everted fits Stage III precisely.

 

This directly addresses the scenario’s details: per vaginum symptom, maximum Valsalva on examination, 2 cm beyond the hymenal ring, not completely everted, and classification per the POP-Q staging system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage I: Incorrect. Stage I requires the most distal prolapse point to be >1 cm above (proximal to) the hymen (i.e., ≤ –1 cm). Our patient is 2 cm beyond the hymenal ring, not above it.

 

Option B. Stage II: Incorrect. Stage II is when the most distal point lies within 1 cm proximal or distal to the hymen (from –1 cm to +1 cm). The finding of +2 cm beyond the hymenal ring exceeds this range.

 

Option D. Stage IV: Incorrect. Stage IV denotes complete vaginal eversion (or prolapse to within 2 cm of total vaginal length). The stem explicitly states the vagina is not completely everted, ruling out Stage IV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In POP-Q, Stage III pelvic organ prolapse = >1 cm beyond the hymen on maximum Valsalva without complete vaginal eversion; e.g., +2 cm beyond the hymenal ring.

choices.text: Reduced need for transfusions and lower IVH rates

questions.text: For a 29-week preterm infant who does not require immediate resuscitation, delayed cord clamping (DCC) of 30–60 seconds is associated with which outcome?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reduced need for transfusions and lower IVH rates

 

  • In preterm infants (especially <32 weeks gestation), delayed cord clamping for 30–60 seconds allows additional placental transfusion, improving blood volume and hemodynamic stability. 
  • This leads to a reduced need for blood transfusions, lower risk of intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH), and less hypotension in the early neonatal period.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH): Incorrect. DCC reduces, not increases, IVH incidence by improving cerebral perfusion.

 

Option C. Higher incidence of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Incorrect. Studies show no increase in necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) with DCC.

 

Option D. Increased mortality: Incorrect. Mortality is not increased; some evidence even suggests improved survival.

 

Educational Objective:


In preterm neonates who are stable at birth, delayed cord clamping (30–60 seconds) decreases the need for transfusions and lowers the risk of intraventricular hemorrhage without increasing adverse outcomes.

choices.text: It conveys the right bundle branch to the anterior papillary muscle
It connects the interventricular septum to the posterior papillary muscle
It is derived from the left ventricular trabeculae carneae
It is supplied mainly by marginal branches of the right coronary artery

questions.text: In the image shown below, which statement about the structure labeled “A” is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It conveys the right bundle branch to the anterior papillary muscle

 

  • The moderator band, also called the septomarginal trabecula, is a muscular ridge found in the right ventricle. 
  • It extends from the interventricular septum to the base of the anterior papillary muscle and contains part of the right bundle branch (Purkinje fibers).
  • This anatomical arrangement ensures coordinated contraction of the right ventricle by transmitting the electrical impulse rapidly to the anterior papillary muscle, synchronizing it with the rest of the ventricular myocardium.
  • It also helps prevent overdistension of the right ventricle during systole.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. It connects the interventricular septum to the posterior papillary muscle: Incorrect. The moderator band attaches to the anterior papillary muscle, not the posterior one.

 

Option C. It is derived from left ventricular trabeculae carneae: Incorrect. The moderator band is unique to the right ventricle, not found in the left ventricle.

 

Option D. It is supplied mainly by marginal branches of the right coronary artery: Incorrect. It receives blood supply primarily from the septal branches of the left anterior descending (LAD) artery, not the right coronary artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The moderator band (septomarginal trabecula) of the right ventricle carries the right bundle branch fibers to the anterior papillary muscle, ensuring synchronized contraction and efficient right ventricular function. 
  • It is supplied by septal branches of the LAD artery.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with peripheral neuropathy is found to have elevated homocysteine levels. Laboratory investigations reveal impaired conversion of serine and homocysteine to cystathionine. Which vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible for this enzymatic dysfunction?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine)

 

  • The reaction Serine + Homocysteine → Cystathionine + H₂O is catalyzed by the enzyme cystathionine β-synthase (CBS), which requires pyridoxal phosphate (PLP), the active form of vitamin B6, as a coenzyme.

 

Clinical Significance:

 

  • Vitamin B6 deficiency can lead to:
    • Hyperhomocysteinemia (increased cardiovascular risk)
    • Peripheral neuropathy and seizures
    • Sideroblastic anemia
    • Dermatitis and cheilosis
  • This pathway is part of the transsulfuration pathway, critical for converting methionine-derived homocysteine to cysteine, maintaining sulfur amino acid homeostasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin): cofactor for flavoproteins (e.g., succinate dehydrogenase); not the key cofactor for this step.

 

Option B. Vitamin B3 (Niacin): NAD⁺/NADP⁺ cofactor; not required for cystathionine β-synthase.

 

Option C. Vitamin B5 (Pantothenic acid): component of coenzyme A; unrelated to this reaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cystathionine β-synthase (homocysteine + serine → cystathionine) requires pyridoxal phosphate (vitamin B6); B6 deficiency causes impaired transsulfuration and elevated homocysteine.

choices.text: Stop clopidogrel now and continue aspirin monotherapy
Take clopidogrel for at least 1 year

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with diabetes is hospitalized for NSTEMI and undergoes drug-eluting stent (DES) placement in the RCA. He is on aspirin, clopidogrel, metoprolol, metformin, and atorvastatin, and has a low risk of bleeding. He asks when he can stop clopidogrel. What is the best recommendation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Take clopidogrel for at least 1 year

 

  • ACC/AHA guidelines recommend that patients with acute coronary syndrome (ACS) treated with a DES receive dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) with aspirin and clopidogrel for a minimum of 12 months.
  • This duration reduces the risks of stent thrombosis (a potentially fatal complication) and recurrent MI.
  • Shorter DAPT durations (3 or 6 months) may be considered only for those at high bleeding risk or with stable coronary disease - not for ACS patients at low bleeding risk.
  • Stopping clopidogrel early (before 1 year) significantly increases the risk of stent thrombosis, which is particularly dangerous in ACS patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Patients with ACS who have received a drug-eluting stent should continue clopidogrel and aspirin for at least 1 year to minimize the risk of stent thrombosis and recurrent cardiac events; early discontinuation is reserved only for high-bleeding-risk cases.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with alcohol use disorder is hospitalized in the ICU for severe pancreatitis, complicated by hypotension requiring vasopressors and prolonged NPO status. After several days of ileus and bowel rest, she now has spontaneous passage of stool and flatus, is off vasopressors, and has a nasogastric tube removed. She has been maintained on IV D5 and NS and the nurse asks about the next step in her nutrition plan. Which of the following is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Begin enteral nutrition

 

  • With the return of bowel function (passage of stool and flatus), this patient is now able to tolerate enteral nutrition. Early enteral nutrition, even via tube feeding if necessary, is the first-line approach as soon as gut function resumes.
  • Enteral nutrition helps preserve gut integrity, reduces infection risk, and is physiologically superior to parenteral methods in patients with a functioning GI tract.
  • Parenteral nutrition is reserved only for cases where enteral nutrition is not feasible (e.g., persistent ileus, severe malabsorption, bowel obstruction).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Begin peripheral parenteral nutrition: Peripheral parenteral nutrition is not indicated because GI function has returned and enteral feeding can be tolerated.

 

Option C. Begin total parenteral nutrition: Total parenteral nutrition should be avoided if enteral nutrition is possible, due to increased risk of infection and metabolic complications.

 

Option D. Continue IV D5/NS: Continuing IV D5NS alone does not provide sufficient nutrition and should not be continued once the patient can tolerate enteral feedings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Once bowel function has returned after acute pancreatitis or severe illness, early enteral nutrition is preferred over parenteral approaches and should be initiated as soon as tolerated to improve clinical outcomes.

questions.text: A 10-year-old school child presents with the condition shown in the image below. This condition is screened under which of the following national health programs?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) RBSK

 

  • RBSK (Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram) is a child health screening and early intervention program that specifically focuses on the 4 D's - Defects at birth, Deficiency diseases, Development delays including disability, and Diseases. 
  • The image shows developmental delay/disability which falls under the "Development delays including disability" category of RBSK. 
  • This program provides free screening, treatment, and management of these conditions in children from birth to 18 years.

 

Health conditions screened under this program

 

Defects at Birth

  1. Neural tube defect
  2. Down’s Syndrome
  3. Cleft lip & palate /Cleft palate alone#
  4. Talipes (club foot)
  5. Developmental dysplasia of the hip
  6. Congenital cataract
  7. Congenital deafness
  8. Congenital heart diseases
  9. Retinopathy of prematurity

Deficiencies

  1.  Anaemia especially severe anaemia
  2. Vitamin A deficiency (Bitot spot)
  3. Vitamin D deficiency (Rickets)
  4. Severe Acute Malnutrition
  5. Goiter

Childhood Diseases

  1. Skin conditions (Scabies, fungal infection and Eczema)
  2. Otitis Media
  3. Rheumatic heart disease
  4. Reactive airway disease
  5. Dental caries
  6. Convulsive disorders

Developmental delays

  1. Vision impairment
  2. Hearing impairment
  3. Neuro motor impairment
  4. Motor delay
  5. Cognitive delay
  6. Language delay
  7. Behaviour disorder (Autism)
  8. Learning disorder
  9. Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder
  10. Other conditions-sickle cell anaemia, Beta Thalassemia, Congenital Hypothyroidism (optional)
  11. Tuberculosis
  12. Leprosy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IMNCI: IMNCI (Integrated Management of Neo-natal and Childhood Illnesses): It is essentially not a national health program and it deals with management of neo-natal and childhood illnesses. 

 

Option C. NAYAN 2.0: NAYAN 2.0 is not a national health program. Nayanamritham 2.0 is the world's first government-led, AI-powered chronic eye screening program launched by the Government of Kerala in collaboration with a private company.

 

Option D. ICDS: ICDS (Integrated Child Development Services) provides nutrition and early childhood care but RBSK is the specific program for health screening of the 4 D's

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • RBSK screens for 4 D's: Defects at birth, Deficiency diseases, Development delays including disability, and Diseases
  • The program covers children from birth to 18 years of age
  • It provides comprehensive screening, treatment and management services for identified conditions

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with metastatic colon cancer on FOLFOX chemotherapy presents with intermittent shortness of breath and chest pain. Her imaging shows multiple pulmonary metastases but no pulmonary embolism, and ECG reveals sub-millimeter ST depressions in leads II and III. She is not a smoker and physical exam only reveals a soft systolic murmur at the apex. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Coronary artery vasospasm

 

  • Chemotherapy agents, especially 5-fluorouracil (part of FOLFOX), are known to cause coronary artery vasospasm, leading to transient ischemia, chest pain, and ECG changes—even in patients without atherosclerotic disease.
  • Vasospasm is a reversible complication that presents with acute chest pain and transient ECG changes but typically lacks evidence of plaque rupture or fixed coronary obstruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Progression of metastatic disease: Progression of metastatic disease is unlikely with acute onset chest pain and clear lungs on exam, especially in the absence of new radiographic findings to explain ischemic symptoms.

 

Option B. Coronary artery plaque rupture: Coronary artery plaque rupture would usually present in those with vascular risk factors and produce persistent and often more severe ECG changes indicative of myocardial infarction.

 

Option D. Occult pulmonary embolism: Occult pulmonary embolism is not supported by normal CT angiography and lack of hypoxemia or tachycardia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coronary artery vasospasm is a recognized side effect of 5-FU-based chemotherapy and should be suspected in cancer patients presenting with acute chest discomfort and ischemic ECG changes in the absence of classic cardiovascular risk factors or clear infarction.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man with a long history of smoking presents with progressive dyspnea and chronic cough. Spirometry is performed, and is shown below. Which of the following conditions best explains these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) COPD

 

  • The red curve in the abnormal graph shows:
    • Reduced slope and prolonged expiratory phase → classic for airflow obstruction.
    • FEV₁ (forced expiratory volume in 1 second) is markedly reduced.
    • FVC (forced vital capacity) is normal or only mildly reduced.
    • FEV₁/FVC ratio is decreased (<70%).
  • This is the hallmark of obstructive lung disease.
  • COPD (Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease), which includes emphysema and chronic bronchitis, is the prototypical cause.
  • Hence, the correct diagnosis is COPD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulmonary fibrosis:

 

  • Pulmonary fibrosis is a restrictive lung disease.
  • In restriction, both FEV₁ and FVC are reduced, but the FEV₁/FVC ratio is normal or increased.
  • This does not match the given abnormal graph.

 

Option C. Sarcoidosis:

 

  • Sarcoidosis is also a restrictive disease affecting lung parenchyma.
  • Like pulmonary fibrosis, both volumes fall proportionally, and the FEV₁/FVC ratio is preserved or elevated.
  • This is inconsistent with the “scooped-out” obstructive pattern.

 

Option D. Bronchiectasis:

 

  • Bronchiectasis is an obstructive disease, but the most classic exam association for this abnormal spirometry curve is COPD, particularly in a heavy smoker with chronic symptoms.
  • While both COPD and bronchiectasis cause obstruction, COPD is the correct, best answer in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A decreased FEV₁/FVC ratio with a concave expiratory curve on spirometry indicates obstructive lung disease, most classically COPD.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents with profuse watery diarrhea after returning from a trip abroad. His stools are described as pale and watery, resembling “rice water.” Laboratory testing confirms infection with a toxin-producing organism. Which of the following structures is most likely damaged in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zona occludens

 

  • Zona occludens (tight junctions) are specialized cell junctions located at the apical end of epithelial cells.
  • They prevent paracellular leakage of water and solutes, maintaining the integrity of epithelial barriers in the gut.
  • Infections such as cholera release toxins that disrupt tight junctions, leading to massive fluid secretion into the intestinal lumen and the clinical finding of watery, “rice water” stools.
  • Thus, the structure damaged in this case is the zona occludens.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemidesmosomes:

 

  • Hemidesmosomes anchor epithelial cells to the basement membrane through integrins.
  • Their disruption leads to blistering skin diseases (e.g., bullous pemphigoid), not watery diarrhea.

 

Option C. Gap junctions:

 

  • Gap junctions are channels formed by connexins that permit intercellular communication and passage of ions and small molecules.
  • They play no role in maintaining paracellular barrier integrity, so their damage would not explain massive watery diarrhea.

 

Option D. Adherens junctions:

 

  • Adherens junctions link actin filaments of adjacent cells through cadherins.
  • They provide mechanical strength but do not regulate paracellular permeability to fluids, so they are not responsible for the described diarrhea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Watery diarrhea resembling “rice water stool” occurs in cholera due to disruption of intestinal tight junctions (zona occludens), which normally prevent paracellular fluid leakage.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding a breast tumor shown in the image are correct? 

 

 

  1. It arise from the epithelial component of the breast lobules.
  2. They are characterized histologically by a leaf-like architecture.
  3. The tumor displays both stromal and epithelial elements, with stromal overgrowth being the neoplastic component.
  4. Malignant variant of the tumor spread hematogenously to lungs or bones.
  5. Axillary lymph node metastasis is common and helps differentiate it from fibroadenoma.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Only 2, 3 and 4 are correct

 

Statement 2. They are characterized histologically by a leaf-like architecture: Correct. The name phyllodes (Greek: “leaf-like”) comes from the leaf-like clefts seen histologically due to epithelial-lined projections of cellular stroma.

 

Statement 3. The tumor displays both stromal and epithelial elements, with stromal overgrowth being the neoplastic component: Correct. Phyllodes tumors are biphasic, but only the stromal component is neoplastic and determines tumor grade (benign, borderline, malignant).

 

Statement 4. Malignant variant of the tumor spread hematogenously to lungs or bones:Correct. When malignant, they behave like sarcomas — spreading hematogenously, not via lymphatics.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 1. It arise from the epithelial component of the breast lobules: Incorrect. Phyllodes tumors arise from the stromal (connective tissue) component, not epithelial. The epithelium is benign and reactive.

 

Statement 5. Axillary lymph node metastasis is common and helps differentiate it from fibroadenoma: Incorrect. Lymph node involvement is rare. This feature actually helps distinguish phyllodes tumor from carcinoma, not fibroadenoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Phyllodes tumors are biphasic (stromal and epithelial elements) breast tumors characterized by a leaf-like architecture. 
  • Their malignant variant primarily metastasizes hematogenously to sites like the lungs or bones, with axillary lymph node metastasis being rare.

choices.text: Stage 1 - High birth rate and high death rate
Stage 2 - High birth rate and declining death rate
Stage 3 - Declining birth rate and low death rate
Stage 4 - Low birth rate and low death rate

questions.text: The demographic transition model describes the transition from high birth and death rates to low birth and death rates as a country develops economically. In which stage of the demographic transition model does a population experience the maximum growth rate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stage 2 - High birth rate and declining death rate

 

  • Stage 2 of the demographic transition model is characterized by high birth rates and declining death rates due to improvements in healthcare, sanitation, and nutrition. 
  • This creates the largest gap between birth and death rates, resulting in maximum population growth rate. 
  • Most developing countries are currently in this stage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage 1: Stage 1 has both high birth and death rates, resulting in minimal population growth due to the small gap between births and deaths.

 

Option C. Stage 3: Stage 3 shows declining birth rates while death rates remain low, leading to reduced population growth compared to Stage 2.

 

Option D. Stage 4: Stage 4 has both low birth and death rates, resulting in minimal or zero population growth with a stable population size.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Demographic transition model has four distinct stages based on birth and death rate patterns

 

 

  • Stage 2 produces maximum population growth due to the largest gap between high birth rates and declining death rates

choices.text: Diffuse interstitial fibrosis with loss of alveolar architecture
Patchy organizing pneumonia with Masson bodies

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with progressive shortness of breath and dry cough for 6 months. She also reports skin tightening over the fingers and Raynaud’s phenomenon. On examination, she has sclerodactyly and telangiectasias. HRCT chest shows bilateral interstitial fibrosis with honeycomb pattern. Serologic testing is positive for anti–topoisomerase I (anti–Scl-70) antibodies. Which of the following pathologic features best correlates with this patient’s pulmonary findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Diffuse interstitial fibrosis with loss of alveolar architecture

 

  • This patient has systemic sclerosis (scleroderma) with diffuse cutaneous features (sclerodactyly, telangiectasias, Raynaud’s) and anti–topoisomerase I (anti–Scl-70) antibodies, which strongly associate with interstitial lung disease. 
  • Her HRCT showing bilateral interstitial fibrosis with honeycombing correlates pathologically with diffuse interstitial fibrosis and destruction of normal alveolar architecture (a usual interstitial pneumonia–like pattern common in scleroderma lung).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Noncaseating granulomas in alveolar septa: Characteristic of sarcoidosis, not systemic sclerosis.


Option C. Eosinophilic infiltrate with Charcot–Leyden crystals: Seen in allergic/eosinophilic lung diseases (e.g., allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis, eosinophilic pneumonia), not scleroderma ILD.


Option D. Patchy organizing pneumonia with Masson bodies: Describes organizing pneumonia (BOOP/COP), which presents with patchy consolidations rather than honeycombing typical of fibrosing ILD in scleroderma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In systemic sclerosis (especially anti–Scl-70 positive), pulmonary involvement commonly manifests as fibrosing interstitial lung disease with honeycombing on HRCT and diffuse interstitial fibrosis with loss of alveolar architecture on pathology.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with symptomatic uterine fibroids is planned for hysterectomy. Which type of hysterectomy has the fastest recovery time and least post-operative pain?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vaginal Hysterectomy

 

  • In women undergoing hysterectomy for benign uterine conditions such as symptomatic fibroids, the route of surgery is chosen based on uterine size, mobility, presence of adnexal pathology, surgeon’s expertise, and previous surgeries.
  • Among all types of hysterectomy, the vaginal route is considered the safest, with the shortest recovery time and least postoperative pain.
  • Reasons why vaginal hysterectomy is preferred:
    • No abdominal incision → minimal postoperative discomfort.
    • Shorter hospital stay and faster recovery.
    • Less blood loss and lower risk of infection.
    • Fewer complications and earlier return to daily activities.
  • Hence, for a 45-year-old woman with benign fibroids, vaginal hysterectomy offers the best postoperative outcome when feasible.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Total Abdominal Hysterectomy: Incorrect. Involves a larger abdominal incision, resulting in more pain, longer hospital stay, and slower recovery compared with vaginal or laparoscopic approaches.

 

Option C. Laparoscopic Hysterectomy: Incorrect. Though minimally invasive and associated with faster recovery than open surgery, it is still generally slower than vaginal hysterectomy in terms of recovery and requires specialized equipment and skills.

 

Option D. Radical Hysterectomy: Incorrect. Performed for malignant conditions (e.g., cervical cancer) and involves removal of parametrium, upper vagina, and pelvic lymph nodes, leading to significant morbidity, longer recovery, and greater postoperative pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For benign uterine conditions such as fibroids, vaginal hysterectomy provides the fastest recovery, least postoperative pain, and lowest complication rate, making it the preferred route when feasible.

choices.text: Non-ischemic CRVO; chronic cystoid macular edema
Branch retinal vein occlusion; macular edema

questions.text: A 62-year-old diabetic and hypertensive male presents with sudden painless loss of vision in his right eye since morning. Visual acuity is counting fingers at 2 meters. Relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is present. Fundus photograph of the affected eye is shown below. Fundus fluorescein angiography reveals  extensive areas of capillary non-perfusion measuring more than 10 disc areas. What is the most likely diagnosis and the most feared complication within the next 3 months?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ischemic CRVO; neovascular glaucoma

 

  • The fundus photograph demonstrates classic features of Ischemic Central Retinal Vein Occlusion (CRVO). 
  • The pathognomonic finding is the 'splashed-tomato' appearance due to massive hemorrhages throughout all four quadrants. 
  • Key distinguishing features include marked venous engorgement with severe tortuosity, numerous cotton wool spots (usually more than 6-10), disc edema and hyperemia, and extensive macular involvement. 
  • The presence of RAPD and severely reduced visual acuity (counting fingers or worse) further confirms ischemic CRVO. 
  • Fundus fluorescein angiography showing extensive areas of capillary non-perfusion (more than 10 disc areas) is diagnostic of the ischemic type. 
  • The most feared complication is rubeosis iridis leading to neovascular glaucoma (NVG), which occurs in approximately 20% of ischemic CRVO cases within 3 months (hence called 90-day glaucoma or 100-day glaucoma). 
  • This occurs due to release of VEGF from the ischemic retina, causing neovascularization of the iris (NVI) and angle (NVA), ultimately leading to intractable glaucoma.

 

Incorrect Options:

 

Option A. Non-ischemic CRVO; chronic cystoid macular edema:  Unlikely. Non-ischemic CRVO shows mild venous dilatation, scattered peripheral hemorrhages, few cotton wool spots, and no RAPD. Vision loss is moderate (6/12–6/60), and neovascular glaucoma is rare (2–3%). The fundus here shows extensive hemorrhages and numerous cotton wool spots, typical of ischemic CRVO.

 

Option C. Diabetic retinopathy; vitreous hemorrhage: Less likely. Diabetic retinopathy is usually bilateral with dot-blot hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and circinate hard exudates. It shows venous beading, not the diffuse venous engorgement and tortuosity seen in CRVO. The acute, unilateral onset favors CRVO over diabetic retinopathy.

 

Option D. Branch retinal vein occlusion; macular edema:  Incorrect. BRVO involves one quadrant, usually superotemporal, with localized hemorrhages and edema. The present case shows all four quadrants affected with the classic “blood and thunder” (splashed-tomato) appearance of CRVO. Neovascular glaucoma is far more common in ischemic CRVO (≈20%) than in BRVO (2–3%).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ischemic CRVO is characterized by massive hemorrhages in all quadrants ('splashed-tomato' appearance), marked venous tortuosity, numerous cotton wool spots, RAPD positivity, and capillary non-perfusion >10 disc areas on FFA; the most serious complication is neovascular glaucoma occurring in 20% cases within 3 months, requiring urgent panretinal photocoagulation when neovascularization develops.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man with Crohn disease and a history of recurrent severe diarrhea presents with elevated serum creatinine. His current S.Cr is 2.3 (previous 1.8). He has a diet-controlled diabetes (HbA1c 6.6%), and a controlled hypertension (on amlodipine). His urine PCR is 0.2 g/dL and renal ultrasound is relatively normal. What is the most likely etiology of his kidney disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oxalate nephropathy

 

  • Patients with chronic inflammatory bowel disease (like Crohn’s) are at risk for enteric hyperoxaluria due to malabsorption. Unabsorbed fatty acids in the gut bind calcium, leaving more oxalate available to be absorbed, leading to hyperoxaluria, nephrolithiasis, and ultimately oxalate nephropathy.
  • Typical features include CKD with minimal proteinuria and normal appearing renal parenchyma in ultrasonography. Progression of creatinine over time reflects ongoing tubular and interstitial damage, not glomerular disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diabetic nephropathy: Diabetic nephropathy usually presents with progressively worsening creatinine and significant proteinuria, neither seen in this well-controlled diabetic.

 

Option B. Hypertensive nephropathy: Hypertensive nephropathy generally develops over many years of poorly controlled hypertension, which is not reflected here.

 

Option D. Recurrent AKI: Recurrent AKI causes acute-on-chronic changes and fluctuating creatinine, but this patient’s trend supports steady progression rather than repetitive acute insults.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oxalate nephropathy is an important cause of CKD in patients with malabsorptive disorders; it results from increased oxalate absorption and is associated with kidney stones, tubular injury, and minimal proteinuria. Dietary modifications and hydration are key to management.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with chronic lymphocytic leukemia and no complaints - is found to have Na - 132 mEq/L, K - 8.2 mEq/L (and, after calcium gluconate, insulin, and dextrose, repeat K is 8.5 mEq/L). His HCO₃ is 26 mEq/L, BUN 28 mg/dL, Cr 1.2 mg/dL, glucose 220 mg/dL and his WBC count is 372000/µL; ECG shows normal sinus rhythm without peaked T waves, and repeat ECG remains unchanged. What is the most likely etiology of his hyperkalemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pseudohyperkalemia

 

  • Persistently high serum potassium with no ECG changes or improvement after treatment, in the context of extreme leukocytosis due to chronic lymphocytic leukemia, strongly suggests pseudohyperkalemia.
  • Pseudohyperkalemia results from in vitro lysis of fragile leukemic cells during blood sample handling, leading to falsely elevated serum potassium; true hyperkalemia would be expected to respond to treatment and produce ECG changes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperglycemia: Hyperglycemia may cause mild hyperkalemia but would typically respond to insulin therapy and may show some ECG findings.

 

Option B. Hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism: Hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism may cause hyperkalemia in chronic kidney disease, but usually with altered renal function and clinical response to therapy.

 

Option D. Renal failure: Renal failure may lead to hyperkalemia, but this patient has normal creatinine and potassium is unresponsive to treatment, making it unlikely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pseudohyperkalemia is a lab artifact that occurs in patients with extreme leukocytosis and fragile cell membranes, leading to falsely elevated serum potassium; it is recognized by a normal ECG, lack of symptoms, and failure of potassium levels to decrease with typical treatments. Correct identification prevents unnecessary interventions.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman presents with a 5-month history of progressive limb weakness and sensory loss. She reports difficulty climbing stairs and frequent falls, and examination shows symmetric proximal and distal limb weakness, reduced reflexes, and diminished vibration and pinprick sensation in all four extremities. She has no bladder or bowel involvement, and cranial nerve function is intact. CSF analysis reveals elevated protein and normal cell count. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CIDP

 

  • Subacute to chronic progression of symmetric sensorimotor weakness and sensory loss over ≥2 months, with reduced reflexes and albuminocytologic dissociation on CSF, is highly characteristic of CIDP.
  • Unlike GBS, CIDP evolves over months (not days to weeks) and often presents with both proximal and distal weakness with sensory involvement but without cranial nerve or autonomic findings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myasthenia gravis: Myasthenia gravis typically presents with fluctuating weakness, especially affecting ocular and bulbar muscles, without sensory loss or reduced reflexes.

 

Option C. Guillain-Barré syndrome: Guillain-Barré syndrome presents with similar features but evolves acutely (days to 4 weeks) not chronically over months.

 

Option D. Multiple sclerosis: Multiple sclerosis predominantly affects the CNS (brain and spinal cord) with features of central demyelination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CIDP should be suspected in patients with progressive, symmetric weakness and sensory changes over at least 2 months, diminished reflexes, and albuminocytologic dissociation on CSF; timely diagnosis is essential as immunomodulatory therapies can prevent long-term disability.

questions.text: A public health officer is reviewing air quality data from an urban monitoring station that shows AQI values of 55, 155, 255, and 355 on different days. Match the following NAQI ranges with their appropriate health effects and recommendations:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-Q, 2-S, 3-P, 4-R

 

  • The National Air Quality Index (NAQI) of India classifies air quality into six categories. 
  • NAQI is given by CPCB. It is based on 8 parameters.
    • PM 2.5 – CO, NO2, Lead
    • PM 10 – SO2, O3, NH3
  • The correct matching is: AQI 51-100 (Satisfactory) causes minor breathing discomfort to sensitive people; AQI 101-200 (Moderate) causes breathing discomfort to people with lung disease such as asthma; AQI 201-300 (Poor) causes breathing discomfort to most people on prolonged exposure; and AQI 301-400 (Very Poor) causes respiratory illness on prolonged exposure. 
  • This systematic classification helps in providing appropriate health advisories to the public.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • NAQI ranges from 0-50 (Good) to 401-500 (Severe) with specific health advisories for each category
  • Higher AQI values correspond to more severe health effects, progressing from sensitive individuals to general population

choices.text: High plasma protein binding leading to displacement resulting in free drug accumulation
First-order elimination kinetics with linear dose-response relationship
Enzyme auto-induction increasing metabolism over time

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with newly diagnosed epilepsy is started on phenytoin. After achieving therapeutic levels (15 μg/mL) on 300 mg/day, the dose is increased to 350 mg/day due to persistent seizures. Three weeks later, the patient develops ataxia, nystagmus, and confusion. Serum phenytoin level is now 35 μg/mL. What pharmacokinetic principle explains this disproportionate increase in drug levels?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Zero-order kinetics at therapeutic concentrations

 

  • Phenytoin exhibits zero-order kinetics at therapeutic concentrations where hepatic enzymes (CYP2C9/CYP2C19) become saturated. 
  • Once saturated, a constant amount (not fraction) is eliminated per unit time, causing small dose increases (17% from 300→350 mg) to produce disproportionately large plasma level increases (133% from 15→35 μg/mL), explaining the toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High plasma protein binding leading to displacement resulting in free drug accumulation: High plasma protein binding may result in more drug interactions when given with other drugs having high plasma protein binding. Altered binding changes free-to-bound ratio but here no other drug is being given with phenytoin. 

 

Option B. First-order elimination kinetics with linear dose-response relationship: In first-order kinetics, a constant fraction is eliminated per unit time with linear dose-proportional increases. A 17% dose increase would produce only ~17% concentration increase (15→17.5 μg/mL), not the 133% increase observed—this disproportionate rise is pathognomonic of saturation kinetics.

 

Option D. Enzyme auto-induction increasing metabolism over time: Auto-induction increases CYP450 enzyme synthesis over 2-3 weeks, causing decreasing plasma levels at constant doses (requiring dose increases to maintain levels). This scenario shows increasing levels after dose escalation—the opposite effect of auto-induction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phenytoin's saturation kinetics at therapeutic levels requires small dose increments (25-30 mg) with careful monitoring, as modest dose increases produce disproportionate plasma level rises once enzymes are saturated.

choices.text: Administer only rabies vaccine (4-dose regimen) on days 0, 3, 7, and 14
Administer rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) around the wound site followed by intradermal rabies vaccine at 8 sites on day 0
Administer rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) around the wound site and distally, followed by intramuscular rabies vaccine on days 0, 3, 7, 14 and 28
Observe for 10 days for signs of rabies in the dog before initiating any prophylaxis

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought to the emergency department 8 hours after being bitten by a stray dog who escaped and could not be found. The bite wound appears as in the image below. The child has no prior history of rabies vaccination. After thorough wound washing and tetanus prophylaxis, what is the most appropriate next step in rabies post-exposure prophylaxis according to current guidelines under the National Rabies Control Program?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Administer rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) around the wound site and distally, followed by intramuscular rabies vaccine on days 0, 3, 7, 14 and 28

 

  • This case represents a Category III exposure (single or multiple transdermal bites on head, neck, face, hands, or genitals; or licks on broken skin/mucous membranes) by an unknown dog. 
  • According to WHO and current Indian guidelines, Category III exposure requires both passive immunization with rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) and active immunization with rabies vaccine. 
  • RIG (HRIG 20 IU/Kg) should be infiltrated around and into the wound site as much as anatomically feasible, with any remaining RIG given intramuscularly at a distant site. 
  • Rabies vaccine - 
    • ESSEN regimen – i.m. 5 doses on Day 0, 3, 7, 14 and 28 (1-1-1-1-1)
    • Updated THAI red cross regimen – i.m. 4 doses on Day 0, 3, 7 and 28 (2-2-2-0-2)
  • The updated WHO recommendation (2018) now favors a 4-dose intramuscular vaccine schedule (days 0, 3, 7, 14) over the previous 5-dose regimen for post-exposure prophylaxis in immunocompetent individuals.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Administer only rabies vaccine (4-dose regimen) on days 0, 3, 7, and 14: Vaccine alone is insufficient for Category III exposure; RIG is mandatory as passive immunization due to high risk of transmission from facial bites.

 

Option B. Administer rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) around the wound site followed by intradermal rabies vaccine at 8 sites on day 0: Intradermal route with 8-site regimen is used for pre-exposure prophylaxis, not post-exposure; intramuscular route is preferred for post-exposure prophylaxis.

 

Option D. Observe for 10 days for signs of rabies in the dog before initiating any prophylaxis: 10-day observation is only applicable when the biting animal can be observed and confined; since the dog escaped, immediate prophylaxis is indicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Category III rabies exposure (facial/head bites, deep wounds) mandates both RIG and vaccine administration regardless of animal observation possibility
  • Current program guidelines recommend 5-dose intramuscular vaccine schedule (0, 3, 7, 14 and 28 days) for post-exposure prophylaxis in immunocompetent individuals
  • RIG must be infiltrated around wound sites with any remaining dose given intramuscularly at distant site on day 0
  • When the biting animal cannot be observed, immediate prophylaxis should never be delayed pending animal surveillance

questions.text: During superficial parotidectomy, a surgeon identifies the main trunk of the facial nerve at its emergence from the stylomastoid foramen. Which landmark best aids in locating this nerve intraoperatively?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Posterior belly of digastric muscle

 

  • The facial nerve exits the stylomastoid foramen, then passes just deep to the posterior belly of digastric and stylohyoid muscles before entering the parotid gland.
  • This muscle serves as a reliable surgical landmark for identifying the facial nerve trunk during parotid surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Stylohyoid ligament: The stylohyoid ligament is variable and not a reliable guide.

 

Option C. Retromandibular vein: The retromandibular vein lies deep to the facial branches; used later for orientation, not initial identification.

 

Option D. Greater auricular nerve: The greater auricular nerve crosses the SCM superficially and is a sensory nerve, not a landmark for the facial trunk.

 

Educational Objective:


In superficial parotidectomy, the posterior belly of the digastric muscle is the most consistent landmark to locate the facial nerve trunk.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with Type II Diabetes is posted for surgery. His HbA1c is 6 gm %. What is his ASA-physical status classification is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ASA-PS II

 

  • In the case presented, the patient is a 45-year-old male with Type II Diabetes, and his HbA1c level is 6%. 
  • A HbA1c level of 6% suggests that his diabetes is reasonably well-controlled, and it does not indicate severe systemic disease. 
  • Therefore, the appropriate ASA-PS classification for this patient would be:
    • ASA-PS II (American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status II) category includes patients with mild to moderate systemic diseases. 
    • These conditions are well-controlled and do not limit the patient's daily activities. 
    • For example, controlled hypertension, well-managed diabetes, or mild asthma would fall into this category.

 

Other Options:

 

American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status classification:

 

Option A. ASA-PS I (American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status I): This category represents a normal healthy patient with no underlying medical conditions. Patients in ASA-PS I have an excellent chance of a successful outcome after surgery.

 

Option C. ASA-PS III (American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status III): Patients in this category have severe systemic diseases that limit their daily activities. These conditions may not be well-controlled and could pose significant risks during surgery. Examples include patients with poorly controlled diabetes, significant heart disease, or severe lung disease.

 

Option D. ASA-PS IV (American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status IV): This category is reserved for patients with severe systemic diseases that are a constant threat to their life. Patients in this category are often unstable and may require immediate medical attention. Examples include patients with decompensated heart failure, severe respiratory failure, or end-stage organ failure.

 

Note:

 

ASA-PS V (American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status V): This category represents patients who are in a moribund state and are not expected to survive without the surgery. The surgery may be performed as a last resort to prolong life, even though the chances of survival are extremely low. Patients in ASA-PS V often have severe, life-threatening conditions and may be comatose or near death.

 

ASA-PS VI (American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status VI): This category includes patients who have been declared brain-dead but are being kept on life support for the purpose of organ donation. These patients are not expected to recover, and their organs are being preserved for transplantation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) Physical Status Classification System

choices.text: 1 Community Health Officer (CHO) + 1 ANM + 1 ASHA
1 Community Health Officer (CHO) + 1 ANM + 1 MPW

questions.text: According to IPHS 2022 guidelines, what is the minimum staffing pattern required for a Health and Wellness Center- Sub-Health center serving a population of 6000 in the plains area?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 Community Health Officer (CHO) + 1 ANM + 1 MPW 

 

  • According to IPHS 2022 guidelines, an HWC-SHC requires one Community Health Officer (CHO), an Auxiliary Nurse Midwife (ANM) and a Multi-Purpose Worker (MPW) (Male) or two ANMs, and support staff as the minimum staffing pattern. 
  • The trap in this question lies in the phrase "serving a population of 6000" - many candidates might think this requires additional staff or confuse it with larger population norms. 
  • ASHA workers are community volunteers and not part of the formal staffing pattern of Sub-centers. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • IPHS 2022 specifies 1 ANM as the sole staffing requirement for Sub-centers in plains areas
  • Sub-centers serve 3000-5000 population in plains and 3000 population in tribal/hilly areas
  • ASHA workers are community volunteers, not formal healthcare staff at Sub-centers

questions.text: A 55‑year‑old man presents for evaluation of hyperthyroidism discovered during an evaluation for palpitations. Laboratory testing shows undetectable TSH and elevated free T4 of 3.8 ng/dL (normal 0.9-1.8). A radioiodine uptake scan demonstrates absent uptake. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Painless thyroiditis

 

  • Painless (silent) thyroiditis is a transient hyperthyroid phase of autoimmune thyroid inflammation, typically associated with Hashimoto thyroiditis. 
  • It results from leakage of preformed thyroid hormone into the circulation rather than increased synthesis. 
  • Because new hormone synthesis is suppressed, radioiodine uptake is absent or very low. 
  • The hyperthyroid phase is self‑limited and may be followed by hypothyroidism before recovery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Graves disease: Characterized by diffuse increased radioiodine uptake due to excessive hormone synthesis driven by TSH‑receptor–stimulating antibodies.

 

Option C. Toxic adenoma: A single overactive thyroid nodule autonomously produces thyroid hormone, showing focal increased radioiodine uptake.

 

Option D. TSH‑producing pituitary adenoma: Causes elevated TSH and high thyroid hormone levels, not suppressed TSH, and does not show absent radioiodine uptake.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Absent radioiodine uptake in the setting of hyperthyroidism indicates release of preformed thyroid hormone, as seen in painless or subacute thyroiditis, rather than increased synthesis as occurs in Graves disease or toxic adenoma.

choices.text: Reassurance; normal eruption can be as late as 10–12 months
Start vitamin D therapy for rickets

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant has no erupted teeth but is otherwise growing normally and meeting developmental milestones. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reassurance; normal eruption can be as late as 10–12 months

 

  • Tooth eruption is highly variable among infants. 
  • The first teeth—usually the lower central incisors—typically appear around 6 months of age, but eruption can occur anytime up to 10–12 months and still be considered normal. 
  • In a child with normal growth, nutrition, and developmental milestones, delayed tooth eruption alone is not concerning and requires only observation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate endocrine workup for hypothyroidism: Incorrect. Hypothyroidism may delay tooth eruption, but it would also present with poor growth, lethargy, hypotonia, and constipation—none of which are present.

 

Option C. Start vitamin D therapy for rickets: Incorrect. Rickets causes delayed eruption with bony deformities, widened wrists, and hypotonia, which are absent here.

 

Option D. Genetic testing for amelogenesis imperfect: Incorrect. Amelogenesis imperfecta affects enamel formation (quality), not the timing of eruption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In healthy infants, absence of tooth eruption at 9 months is often a normal variant. 
  • Eruption may be delayed up to 12 months without underlying pathology, requiring only reassurance and continued observation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old boy with a known history of severe haemophilia A presents to the clinic with progressively worsening pain, stiffness, and recurrent swelling in his left knee over the past three years. The episodes of swelling often occur after minor trauma and take several days to resolve completely. On physical examination, left knee is visibly enlarged, warm, and has flexion contracture. He has a noticeable limp. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Haemophiliac Arthropathy

 

  • A destructive joint disease that results from hemarthrosis into the joint space, most commonly the knees, elbows, and ankles. 
  • The blood irritates the synovium, causing synovitis. 
  • Chronic synovitis leads to thickening, joint cartilage destruction, bone erosion, and ultimately, a fixed deformity.
  • Patient is known as severe Haemophilia A.
  • Recurrent hemarthrosis is the initiating event.
  • Recurrent swelling after minor trauma, progressively worsening pain and stiffness, and eventual development of a fixed flexion contracture and joint enlargement. The knee is the most common joint affected.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis:

 

  • A chronic inflammatory arthritis with onset before age 16.
  • The primary cause of the joint damage in this patient is his bleeding disorder, not an autoimmune process. 
  • While JIA can cause chronic synovitis, pain, and contractures, the patient's existing severe Haemophilia A provides a more direct and definitive explanation for the joint destruction through recurrent bleeding.
  • JIA would not explain the history of recurrent swelling occurring after minor trauma (i.e., haemarthrosis).

 

Option B. Pigmented Villonodular Synovitis:

 

  • A rare, benign, and proliferative disorder of the synovium characterized by villous and nodular overgrowth. It often contains deposits of haemosiderin (iron from old blood).
  • While PVNS often presents with recurrent swelling and pain, it is idiopathic. In this patient, the cause of the recurrent blood is clearly the severe Haemophilia A, making Haemophiliac Arthropathy the more specific and appropriate diagnosis.

 

Option C. Septic Arthritis:

 

  • Bacterial infection of the joint space.
  • Septic arthritis presents as an acute, critical emergency with severe pain, fever, chills, and significantly elevated inflammatory markers (WBC, ESR, CRP).
  • The patient's three-year history of chronic, recurrent swelling and progressive deformity does not fit the acute, destructive course of an untreated infection.
  • While haemophiliacs are not immune to infection, the chronic course is not characteristic of septic arthritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The case describes a young male with a known history of severe Haemophilia A who develops chronic, progressive joint damage in a single joint. 
  • This clinical picture is the classic presentation of a haemophiliac complication known as Haemophiliac Arthropathy.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man begins treadmill exercise testing to assess functional capacity. After he reaches steady state during moderate exertion, his measured oxygen consumption is 1500 ml/min. Baseline resting oxygen consumption is estimated to be 250 ml/min. What is the patient’s approximate MET (metabolic equivalent of task) score during this exercise?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 6

 

  • MET (Metabolic Equivalent of Task) is a physiological unit that expresses the energy cost of physical activities.
  • By definition, 1 MET = oxygen consumption at rest = ~250 ml/min (or 3.5 ml O₂/kg/min).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • 1 MET equals resting oxygen consumption (approximately 250 ml/min or 3.5 ml/kg/min). 
  • MET scores during exercise are calculated by dividing activity oxygen consumption by resting oxygen consumption.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with hypertension, and a 25-pack-year smoking history presents with fatigue, thirst, frequent urination, weight loss, and confusion. He drinks several liters of water daily. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Squamous cell cancer

 

  • Symptoms including fatigue, confusion, excessive thirst, polyuria, and weight loss are classic manifestations of hypercalcemia.
  • Hypercalcemia in a patient with lung cancer is most commonly caused by a paraneoplastic syndrome mediated by parathyroid hormone-related peptide (PTHrP).
  • Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is the type most strongly associated with hypercalcemia via PTHrP production, making it the most likely diagnosis in a smoker presenting with these symptoms and a new syndrome of polyuria and polydipsia.​
  • Additional findings such as neuropsychiatric changes (confusion) and renal symptoms (polyuria, polydipsia) further support the hypercalcemia diagnosis.​

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Small cell cancer: Typically associated with paraneoplastic syndromes like SIADH (causing hyponatremia) and ectopic ACTH production (leading to Cushing’s syndrome), not hypercalcemia.​

 

Option C. Large cell cancer: Rarely linked with paraneoplastic syndromes; hypercalcemia may occur but is much less common compared to squamous cell carcinoma.​

 

Option D. Adenocarcinoma: Not classically linked with hypercalcemia of malignancy, and does not frequently produce PTHrP or cause these metabolic effects.​

 

Educational Objective:

 

Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is the classic lung malignancy causing hypercalcemia through PTHrP secretion and should be strongly suspected in smoking patients with symptoms of dehydration, confusion, and polyuria.

choices.text: Caused by immune complex deposition after streptococcal infection
It is an example of type III hypersensitivity reaction
There is linear deposition of IgG and C3 on immunofluorescence

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with cola-colored urine, periorbital edema, and mild hypertension 2 weeks after a throat infection. Urine analysis shows RBC casts, mild proteinuria with reduced serum C3. Which of the following statements regarding his condition is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) There is linear deposition of IgG and C3 on immunofluorescence

 

  • A 12-year-old boy who presents 2 weeks after a throat infection (post-streptococcal pharyngitis) with cola-colored urine, periorbital edema, and mild hypertension, plus urine analysis showing RBC casts, mild proteinuria, and reduced serum C3, has acute post-streptococcal (post-infectious) glomerulonephritis (PSGN).
  • PSGN is caused by immune complex deposition after streptococcal infection and is an example of type III hypersensitivity reaction. 
  • On electron microscopy, PSGN characteristically shows subepithelial “hump-like” deposits formed by immune complexes. 
  • On immunofluorescence, PSGN classically demonstrates granular (“lumpy-bumpy”) deposition of IgG and C3, not linear deposition. 
  • Therefore, the statement “There is linear deposition of IgG and C3 on immunofluorescence” is incorrect in this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Caused by immune complex deposition after streptococcal infection: Correct. PSGN follows a streptococcal infection (often throat infection) by about 2 weeks and is caused by immune complex deposition in glomeruli, explaining reduced serum C3, RBC casts, mild proteinuria, periorbital edema, mild hypertension, and cola-colored urine.

 

Option B. Electron microscopy shows subepithelial “hump-like” deposits: Correct. On electron microscopy, PSGN shows subepithelial “hump-like” deposits of immune complexes, consistent with the urine analysis findings (RBC casts, mild proteinuria) and the post-streptococcal timing (2 weeks after a throat infection) with reduced serum C3.

 

Option C. It is an example of type III hypersensitivity reaction: Correct. PSGN is mediated by type III hypersensitivity due to circulating immune complexes (IgG with streptococcal antigens) depositing in the glomerular basement membrane and mesangium, activating complement (reduced serum C3) and producing cola-colored urine, periorbital edema, mild hypertension, and RBC casts with mild proteinuria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, occurring ~2 weeks after a streptococcal throat infection, expect low C3, RBC casts, mild proteinuria, and granular (not linear) IgG/C3 deposition with subepithelial “hump-like” deposits.

choices.text: Thiazides increase lithium absorption from the gastrointestinal tract
Thiazides decrease lithium metabolism in the liver
Thiazides increase renal tubular reabsorption of lithium
Thiazides displace lithium from intracellular binding sites

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with bipolar disorder stable on lithium therapy for 3 years develops hypertension. His physician starts hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg daily. Two weeks later, he presents with coarse tremors, confusion, vomiting, and ataxia. Serum lithium level is 2.8 mEq/L (therapeutic: 0.6-1.2 mEq/L). What is the most likely mechanism of this drug interaction?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thiazides increase renal tubular reabsorption of lithium

 

  • Thiazide diuretics increase lithium toxicity by enhancing renal tubular reabsorption. 
  • Lithium is handled like sodium—freely filtered at the glomerulus and 80% reabsorbed in the proximal tubule. 
  • Thiazides cause volume depletion, triggering compensatory increased proximal tubular reabsorption of both sodium and lithium. 
  • This reduces lithium clearance by 25-40%, causing accumulation. 
  • Lithium has a narrow therapeutic index (0.6-1.2 mEq/L), making this interaction dangerous.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiazides increase lithium absorption from the gastrointestinal tract: Lithium has >95% oral bioavailability and is completely absorbed from the GI tract regardless of thiazide use. Diuretics don't affect GI absorption. The toxicity mechanism involves renal elimination, not absorption.

 

Option B. Thiazides decrease lithium metabolism in the liver: Lithium is not metabolized at all—it's eliminated entirely unchanged by the kidneys. As a simple ion, it undergoes no hepatic biotransformation. Drug interactions involving metabolism don't apply to lithium.

 

Option D. Thiazides displace lithium from intracellular binding sites: Lithium doesn't bind to proteins; it exists as a free ion. Displacement interactions only occur with highly protein-bound drugs (>90%). The toxicity results from reduced renal excretion, not displacement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thiazides increase lithium toxicity by enhancing proximal tubular reabsorption due to volume depletion; reduce lithium dose by 50% when starting thiazides and monitor levels frequently.

choices.text: Respiratory minute volume refers to the total volume of air inspired (or expired) per minute.
Residual volume is the amount of air remaining in the lungs after a maximal forceful expiration.
Vital capacity is the maximum volume of air that can be exhaled following a normal tidal inspiration.
Physiological dead space is the portion of inspired air that does not participate in gas exchange with blood.

questions.text: Which of the following definitions is incorrect regarding respiratory physiology?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vital capacity is the maximum volume of air that can be exhaled following a normal tidal inspiration.

 

  • Vital capacity (VC) is defined as the maximum amount of air that can be exhaled after a maximal inspiration, not after a normal tidal inspiration.
  • It represents the sum of tidal volume (TV) + inspiratory reserve volume (IRV) + expiratory reserve volume (ERV).
  • The option in the question incorrectly limits vital capacity to exhalation after only a normal inspiration, which underestimates its true definition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory minute volume refers to the total volume of air inspired (or expired) per minute:

 

  • This is correct.
  • Respiratory minute volume (also called minute ventilation) is calculated as: 
    • Minute ventilation= Tidal volume (TV) × Respiratory rate (RR) 
  • It represents the amount of air inspired (or expired) per minute.

 

Option B. Residual volume is the amount of air remaining in the lungs after a maximal forceful expiration:

 

  • This is correct.
  • Residual volume cannot be expelled, even with maximum expiratory effort.
  • It maintains alveolar patency and prevents lung collapse.

 

Option D. Physiological dead space is the portion of inspired air that does not participate in gas exchange with blood:

 

  • This is correct.
  • Physiological dead space = anatomical dead space (conducting airways) + alveolar dead space (alveoli that are ventilated but not perfused).
  • By definition, it is the amount of air not equilibrating with blood.

 

Educational Objective:
