Vital capacity is the maximum volume of air that can be exhaled after a maximal inspiration, not after a normal tidal inspiration.

choices.text: Laryngomalacia with omega-shaped epiglottis on laryngoscopy
Hypoplastic orbital fissures and single palmar crease
Micrognathia with round face and wide nasal bridge

questions.text: A 3-month-old girl has high-pitched cat-like cry, microcephaly, hypotonia, epicanthal folds, and developmental delay. Which additional finding most strongly supports the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Micrognathia with round face and wide nasal bridge.

 

Cri du chat (5p deletion) features: high-pitched cry, microcephaly, hypotonia, micrognathia, round face, hypertelorism/wide nasal bridge, and developmental delay.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Café-au-lait macules and axillary freckling: Incorrect. These are suggestive of Neurofibromatosis type 1.

 

Option B. Laryngomalacia with omega-shaped epiglottis on laryngoscopy: Incorrect. Laryngomalacia can cause stridor but the characteristic cry arises from laryngeal/neurologic immaturity specific to 5p deletion; omega epiglottis is not a hallmark of cri du chat.

 

Option C. Hypoplastic orbital fissures and single palmar crease: Incorrect. Single palmar crease is nonspecific; hypoplastic orbital fissures do not define cri du chat.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cri du chat (5p−) classically presents with cat-like cry plus facial features including micrognathia, round face, and wide nasal bridge.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man who frequently consumes undercooked freshwater fish presents with vague upper abdominal discomfort. His stool sample is submitted for real-time PCR to confirm the suspected diagnosis of liver fluke infection. Which of the following gene targets is most specific for detecting Clonorchis sinensis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) NADH dehydrogenase subunit 2 (nad2) gene

 

  • The NADH dehydrogenase subunit 2 (nad2) gene is a mitochondrial DNA element specifically targeted by real-time PCR assays for the detection of Clonorchis sinensis. 
  • This gene offers high sensitivity and specificity in molecular diagnostics and is commonly used in surveillance and confirmation, especially when stool microscopy is inconclusive. 
  • It distinguishes C. sinensis from other similar flukes such as Opisthorchis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 18S ribosomal RNA gene: Although the 18S rRNA gene is widely conserved and used in parasitology for genus-level detection, it lacks species-specificity, especially for differentiating between closely related trematodes.

 

Option C. β-tubulin gene: This gene is more commonly associated with helminth resistance studies, particularly for benzimidazole resistance, not for species detection or confirmation of Clonorchis.

 

Option D. K13 propeller gene: This gene is specific to Plasmodium falciparum and is used to detect artemisinin resistance in malaria. It has no role in fluke or helminth detection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Real-time PCR targeting the nad2 mitochondrial gene is a highly specific molecular diagnostic tool used for confirmation of Clonorchis sinensis in stool specimens, especially in endemic areas or when microscopic findings are ambiguous.

questions.text: A patient with recent onset of acute desaturation in the hospital is found to have a sudden rise in ventilator peak inspiratory pressure to 46 cm H2O (from 27 cm H2O previously) while plateau pressure remains unchanged at 22 cm H2O. What is the most likely etiology of this change?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Excessive secretions

 

  • An acute increase in peak inspiratory pressure with unchanged plateau pressure suggests increased airway resistance rather than reduced lung compliance.
  • Excessive secretions in the airway obstruct airflow, raising resistance and thereby increasing peak pressures, but do not affect plateau pressure, which reflects compliance.
  • This finding, along with acute desaturation, is classic for airway obstruction due to secretions that should be managed promptly to restore effective ventilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Auto-PEEP: Auto-PEEP would typically increase both peak and plateau pressures due to air trapping and reduced compliance.

 

Option C. Pneumothorax: Pneumothorax increases both peak and plateau pressures as it impairs lung compliance.

 

Option D. Vent asynchrony: Vent asynchrony may cause inefficient ventilation but would not selectively and significantly elevate peak pressure without affecting plateau pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A sudden rise in peak pressure with unchanged plateau pressure on the ventilator indicates increased airway resistance, most commonly due to excessive secretions; prompt airway management is essential to prevent hypoxemia.

questions.text: A 28-year-old trauma patient in hypotension requires emergency surgery. Which intravenous anaesthetic agent would be most appropriate for induction?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ketamine

 

  • Ketamine is the agent of choice for hypovolemic patients because of its unique cardiovascular profile. 
  • Unlike other intravenous anaesthetics that cause cardiovascular depression, ketamine produces sympathetic stimulation leading to increased heart rate, cardiac output, and blood pressure. 
  • This makes it invaluable in patients who have bled or are in shock.
  • The mechanism involves stimulation of the sympathetic nervous system, which counteracts the hypotension that would otherwise worsen with other anaesthetic agents. 
  • ketamine has been specifically good for hypovolemic patients.
  • Ketamine produces what is termed "dissociative anaesthesia" characterized by profound analgesia, immobility, and amnesia with only light sleep. 
  • At doses of 1-2 mg/kg IV or 3-5 mg/kg IM, it acts rapidly within one minute.
  • Additional advantages include maintained respiration, bronchodilatation, and preserved airway reflexes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Propofol: Causes profound fall in blood pressure primarily due to vasodilatation with less marked cardiac depression. This hypotension is "more profound than that with thiopentone" and would be particularly dangerous in hypovolemic patients. The baroreflex is suppressed, preventing compensatory tachycardia.

 

Option B. Thiopentone sodium: Causes immediate fall in BP after injection, mainly due to vasodilatation. cardiovascular collapse may occur if hypovolemia, shock or sepsis are present." It reduces cardiac contractility and would severely compromise an already unstable circulation.

 

Option D. Midazolam: While producing less cardiovascular depression than barbiturates, midazolam causes "somewhat greater" fall in BP than diazepam. In a hypovolemic patient, even this modest hypotensive effect could be detrimental. Additionally, BZDs are poor analgesics and would require opioids, further compromising cardiovascular stability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ketamine's sympathomimetic properties making it increase BP and cardiac output render it uniquely suitable for anaesthesia in hypovolemic and shocked patients, unlike all other IV anaesthetics which cause cardiovascular depression.

choices.text: A patient says that his internal organs have been stolen by aliens who have fitted machinery in place of his internal organs.
A patient says that aliens control the movement of his hand.
A patient reports that he can hear two aliens talking to each other and discussing about him.
A patient says that he experiences burning sensations in his stomach caused by UV rays being thrown at him by the aliens.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a Schneider’s First-Rank Symptom (SFRS)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A patient says that his internal organs have been stolen by aliens who have fitted machinery in place of his internal organs.

 

  • Schneider’s First-Rank Symptoms (SFRS) are specific psychotic experiences that are highly characteristic of schizophrenia. 
  • They primarily involve disturbances of thought, perception, and the sense of self-agency.
  • Option A describes a somatic delusion — a false belief about bodily changes (organs stolen or replaced), not an SFRS. It reflects a delusional belief, not a first-rank symptom.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. A patient says that aliens control the movement of his hand: This represents made volition, where the patient feels that an external force is controlling his actions — a classic SFRS.

 

Option C. A patient reports that he can hear two aliens talking to each other and discussing about him: This is voices heard arguing, another classical SFRS related to auditory hallucinations.

 

Option D. A patient says that he experiences burning sensations in his stomach caused by UV rays being thrown at him by the aliens: This represents somatic passivity, where sensations are experienced as being externally imposed — also an SFRS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Somatic or bodily delusions (e.g., “my organs have been replaced”) are not SFRS, while phenomena such as made volition, voices arguing, and somatic passivity are typical Schneider’s First-Rank Symptoms of schizophrenia.

questions.text:
In the floor of the fourth ventricle, the afferent nuclear columns of the brainstem are arranged in a specific sequence from medial to lateral. Which of the following correctly represents this order?

 

  1. General somatic 
  2. General visceral 
  3. Special somatic 
  4. Special visceral
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 4, 1, 3

 

  • The sensory (afferent) nuclei of the brainstem are organized lateral to the sulcus limitans, while the motor (efferent) nuclei lie medial to it. 
  • Among the afferent columns, the arrangement from medial to lateral is as follows:
    • 2. General Visceral Afferent (GVA): Receives sensory impulses from visceral organs such as the pharynx, larynx, and thoracic and abdominal viscera.
    • 4. Special Visceral Afferent (SVA): Carries taste sensations (via cranial nerves VII, IX, X).
    • 1. General Somatic Afferent (GSA): Conveys general sensory information like touch, pain, and temperature from the face.
    • 3. Special Somatic Afferent (SSA): Transmits special sensory input related to hearing and balance (from cranial nerve VIII).
  • Hence, the correct medial to lateral sequence is: General Visceral → Special Visceral → General Somatic → Special Somatic or numerically: 2, 4, 1, 3.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the floor of the fourth ventricle, the afferent (sensory) columns are arranged from medial to lateral as: General Visceral → Special Visceral → General Somatic → Special Somatic (2, 4, 1, 3).

choices.text: No anti-D is needed as she already received prophylaxis at 28 weeks
Give anti-D within 72 hours of delivery
Give anti-D only if DCT becomes positive
No anti-D is needed as the baby's blood group is B positive

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida with O negative blood group and husband with B positive blood group delivered a baby at term. She had received anti-D prophylaxis at 28 weeks of gestation. The baby's blood group is B positive with a negative Direct Coombs Test (DCT). What is the appropriate management regarding anti-D administration?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Give anti-D within 72 hours of delivery

 

  • A 28-year-old primigravida with O negative blood group delivered at term; the husband is B positive and the baby is B positive with a negative Direct Coombs Test (DCT) after anti-D prophylaxis at 28 weeks of gestation.
  • Because the mother is Rh(D)-negative and the infant is Rh(D)-positive, she must receive postpartum anti-D within 72 hours to prevent alloimmunization from delivery-related fetomaternal hemorrhage.
  • The 28-week antenatal prophylaxis does not replace the postpartum dose.
  • A negative DCT in the baby does not affect the indication for maternal anti-D.
  • O mother/B positive baby (possible ABO mismatch) may reduce but does not eliminate Rh sensitization risk—anti-D is still required.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. No anti-D is needed as she already received prophylaxis at 28 weeks: Incorrect. the 28-week dose is antepartum; a postpartum dose is still required within 72 hours when the baby is B positive and the mother is O negative.

 

Option C. Give anti-D only if DCT becomes positive: Incorrect. DCT reflects antibodies on the newborn’s RBCs; maternal prophylaxis is indicated regardless of a negative DCT when an Rh-negative mother delivers an Rh-positive infant.

 

Option D. No anti-D is needed as the baby's blood group is B positive: Incorrect: “B positive” confirms Rh positivity, which triggers postpartum anti-D in the Rh-negative (O negative) primigravida who delivered at term.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An Rh-negative mother who delivers an Rh-positive (e.g., B positive) baby must receive anti-D immunoglobulin within 72 hours postpartum—even if she received 28-week prophylaxis and the newborn’s DCT is negative.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child with primary nocturnal enuresis (bedwetting) has not responded to behavioral interventions. The parents are seeking pharmacological treatment. The child has no other medical conditions and normal daytime voiding patterns. Which medication would be most appropriate for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Desmopressin at bedtime

 

  • Intranasal or oral desmopressin at bedtime controls primary nocturia by reducing urine volume. 
  • It stimulates the B2 receptors and increases the urine output 
  • For bedwetting in children, the dose is 5-10 μg intranasally at bedtime. Desmopressin is a selective V₂ receptor agonist that increases water reabsorption in the collecting ducts. 
  • Fluid intake must be restricted 1 hour before and till 8 hours after the dose to avoid fluid retention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Furosemide at bedtime: Furosemide would increase urine production, worsening bedwetting

 

Option C. Hydrochlorothiazide in the morning: Hydrochlorothiazide in morning would not help nighttime urine production

 

Option D. Spironolactone at bedtime: Spironolactone has no role in treating bedwetting

 

Educational Objective:

 

Desmopressin at bedtime reduces nocturnal urine volume and is effective for primary nocturnal enuresis in children.

choices.text: Hair clipping is preferred over shaving to reduce surgical site infection risk
Alcohol-based hand rubs are superior to soap and water for routine hand hygiene
Preoperative skin hair removal should be done in the ward the night before surgery
Minimising preoperative hospital stay helps reduce nosocomial infection risk

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding preoperative preparation is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Preoperative skin hair removal should be done in the ward the night before surgery

 

Hair removal, if necessary, should be done immediately before surgery in the operating theatre, not the night before, to reduce microbial colonization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hair clipping is preferred over shaving to reduce surgical site infection risk: Hair clipping is the recommended method for preoperative hair removal — it causes less skin trauma than shaving.

 

Option B. Alcohol-based hand rubs are superior to soap and water for routine hand hygiene: Alcohol-based hand rubs are more effective than soap and water for routine hand hygiene, unless hands are visibly soiled.

 

Option D. Minimising preoperative hospital stay helps reduce nosocomial infection risk: Shorter preoperative hospital stays reduce the risk of hospital-acquired infections and improve surgical outcomes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Hair clipping on OT table is associated with least risk of SSI (surgical site infections).

choices.text: To allow formation of the foveal fixation reflex

questions.text: A 6-week-old infant is diagnosed with a dense unilateral congenital cataract. The ophthalmologist recommends urgent surgery. What is the most important reason for early surgical intervention in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) To allow formation of the foveal fixation reflex

 

  • In infants, visual development is highly time-sensitive. The critical period for the development of the foveal fixation reflex and normal visual pathways occurs in the first few months of life. 
  • If a dense congenital cataract is not removed early, visual input is blocked, and the brain fails to develop the proper cortical connections for vision in that eye — a condition known as stimulus-deprivation amblyopia.
  • In unilateral cataract, early surgical correction (typically by 6–8 weeks) is especially important because the other eye can dominate, worsening the amblyopia in the affected eye.
  • This intervention allows proper light stimulus to reach the retina, promoting development of central vision and foveal fixation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To improve cosmetic appearance: While appearance may improve after cataract removal, this is not the primary indication. Early surgery is aimed at preventing irreversible vision loss, not cosmetic benefit.

 

Option B. To reduce intraocular pressure early: Congenital cataracts are not primarily associated with increased intraocular pressure (IOP). This is more relevant to congenital glaucoma, not cataracts.

 

Option D. To prevent development of nystagmus: Nystagmus can develop from sensory deprivation, but it is a secondary outcome. The primary goal is to allow visual input and proper cortical development, which will incidentally reduce the risk of nystagmus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In infants with unilateral congenital cataracts, early surgical removal is critical to allow visual pathway development and prevent amblyopia — the formation of the foveal fixation reflex is time-sensitive and must not be delayed.

choices.text: Tropical traveler with ring forms inside RBCs and pigment
Temperate-region patient with pear-shaped organisms forming a cross pattern
Patient from Africa presenting with high-grade fever and cerebral signs
Blood smear showing gametocytes and Maurer’s dots

questions.text: In which of the following scenarios is artemisinin combination therapy not the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Temperate-region patient with pear-shaped organisms forming a cross pattern

 

  • The scenario described Babesiosis, a tick-borne infection caused by Babesia species, most commonly seen in temperate regions like the northeastern United States. 
  • On peripheral smear, Babesia often presents with pear-shaped intraerythrocytic parasites arranged in Maltese cross (tetrad) formation.
  • The treatment of choice for babesiosis is atovaquone + azithromycin (or clindamycin + quinine in severe cases), not artemisinin combination therapy, which is reserved for malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tropical traveler with ring forms inside RBCs and pigment: This description is classic for Plasmodium falciparum infection. ACT is the treatment of choice here.

 

Option C. Patient from Africa presenting with high-grade fever and cerebral signs: Suggests cerebral malaria caused by P. falciparum. ACT is first-line therapy, especially in endemic regions.

 

Option D. Blood smear showing gametocytes and Maurer’s dots: These are classic features of P. falciparum. Maurer’s clefts (dots) and banana-shaped gametocytes are hallmark features. ACT is the drug of choice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT) is the first-line treatment for falciparum malaria, especially in endemic regions.
  • Babesiosis, though morphologically similar to malaria, is treated with atovaquone and azithromycin, not ACT.

questions.text: Which sinus drains into the middle meatus through the hiatus semilunaris and is most commonly infected due to its dependent drainage pathway?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Maxillary sinus

 

  • The maxillary sinus drains via the ostium in the middle meatus hiatus (semilunaris).
  • The ostium lies high on the medial wall, above the sinus floor, resulting in poor gravity-assisted drainage.
  • Hence, it is the most frequently infected sinus in sinusitis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Frontal sinus: Frontal sinus drains via frontonasal duct into the infundibulum of middle meatus.

 

Option B. Sphenoid sinus: Sphenoid sinus drains into sphenoethmoidal recess superior meatus).

 

Option D. Posterior ethmoidal sinus: Posterior ethmoids drain into superior meatus, not middle meatus.

 

Educational Objective:


The maxillary sinus, with an ostium high on its medial wall, drains poorly and is most prone to infection.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of IV drug use, hepatitis C and cirrhosis presents with 2 days of new palpable purpura on his lower extremities. He reports a week of malaise, arthralgias, and lower leg paresthesia with mild weakness. His blood pressure is 93/64 mmHg and heart rate is 97 beats/min. Exam shows a systolic murmur in tricuspid area with reduced power and sensation in both lower legs. Labs reveal anemia, thrombocytopenia, proteinuria, and positive rheumatoid factor. Which of the following is not an appropriate immediate next step in his evaluation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Kidney biopsy

 

  • This patient’s presentation is suggestive of infection-associated or cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. Contributing factors include hepatitis C, recent endocarditis, IV drug use, palpable purpura, arthritis, neuropathy, and proteinuria.
  • Kidney biopsy is not indicated acutely in the setting of active infection and likely vasculitis; management should initially focus on infectious and vasculitic assessment and treatment. Biopsy is reserved for cases where the diagnosis remains uncertain or if renal pathology worsens despite appropriate therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blood cultures: Blood cultures are necessary to assess for persistent bacteremia, especially considering his history of IV drug use and a murmur.

 

Option B. Echocardiogram: Echocardiogram is indicated to detect active endocarditis or new valvular lesions, which could explain ongoing systemic emboli or vasculitic phenomena.

 

Option C. Complement levels: Complement levels can help evaluate for cryoglobulinemia - common in hepatitis C -with low complement supporting the diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Initial evaluation of possible systemic vasculitis in a high-risk patient should prioritize laboratory and cardiac investigations over invasive procedures like kidney biopsy, unless renal involvement is rapidly progressive or diagnosis is unclear after standard work-up.

choices.text: Photobacterium and Armillaria help to release stored light in the putrefying tissue
Putrefying tissue provides ideal conditions for microbial luciferase to act on luciferin, producing light
Decomposition gases react with air to emit light
As there body liquefies, it reflects more light

questions.text: Which of the following best explains the cause of postmortem luminescence?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Putrefying tissue provides ideal conditions for microbial luciferase to act on luciferin, producing light

 

  • Postmortem luminescence (also called bioluminescence of decomposition) occurs due to the action of bioluminescent bacteria, such as Photobacterium and Vibrio species, that colonize putrefying tissue.
  • These bacteria produce light through a biochemical reaction involving: Luciferase (enzyme) acting on Luciferin (substrate),in the presence of oxygen, forming an excited intermediate that releases visible light when it returns to its ground state.
  • The warm, moist, nutrient-rich, and anaerobic environment of decomposing tissue provides ideal conditions for this reaction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Photobacterium and Armillaria help to release stored light in the putrefying tissue: light is not “stored”; it’s produced chemically through a luciferase–luciferin reaction.

 

Option C. Decomposition gases react with air to emit light: Gases from decomposition don’t emit light; they only cause bloating and odor.

 

Option D. As there body liquefies, it reflects more light: Reflection of light increases visibility but doesn’t generate light.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Postmortem luminescence is caused by bioluminescent bacteria that colonize decomposing tissue.
  • They produce light through the luciferase–luciferin enzymatic reaction, a hallmark of microbial bioluminescence under suitable postmortem conditions.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man sustains a deep laceration to the posterior aspect of his forearm. On examination, he is unable to straighten his fingers, but wrist extension is preserved, though slightly weak and deviated to the radial side. Pronation and supination remain normal. Which of the following nerves is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Posterior interosseous nerve

 

  • The posterior interosseous nerve (PIN), a deep branch of the radial nerve, supplies most of the extensor muscles of the forearm—including extensor digitorum, extensor digiti minimi, and extensor indicis. 
  • These muscles extend the metacarpophalangeal joints of the fingers.
  • Injury to the PIN results in:
    • Loss of finger extension at the metacarpophalangeal joints,
    • Weak wrist extension (due to intact extensor carpi radialis longus), and
    • No sensory deficit, since the PIN is a purely motor nerve.
  • Thus, the patient’s inability to extend fingers with preserved wrist motion is diagnostic of posterior interosseous nerve palsy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Median nerve: Injury leads to loss of thumb opposition, weakened wrist flexion, and sensory loss over the lateral palm — not finger extension weakness.

 

Option B. Ulnar nerve: Causes claw hand deformity, weakness in finger abduction/adduction, and sensory loss over the medial hand — again, not loss of finger extension.

 

Option D. Musculocutaneous nerve: Affects elbow flexion (biceps, brachialis) and forearm sensation on the lateral side — unrelated to finger extension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The posterior interosseous nerve (a motor branch of the radial nerve) injury leads to loss of finger extension with preserved wrist extension. It is commonly injured in forearm trauma or radial head dislocation.

questions.text: A 36-year-old female is posted for Modified radical mastectomy under general anesthesia. Halfway through the surgery, this is her capnograph. What should be the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Repeat Muscle Relaxant

 

  • This capnograph shows a ‘Curare Cleft’.
  • The ‘Curare Cleft’ is an indication that the patient is out of neuromuscular blockade and is making an attempt to breathe spontaneously.
  • As they are halfway through the surgery, a top up dose of muscle relaxant needs to be given to paralyze the patient again.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extubate the patient: Patient cannot be extubated as they are halfway through the surgery.

 

Option C. Deepen the Plane of Anesthesia: Deepening anaesthesia will not paralyze the patient.

 

Option D. Give Reversal Agent: Patient cannot be reversed from neuromuscular blockade as they are halfway through the surgery, surgery is not over.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases where the capnograph waveform shows a curare cleft in the capnograph during surgery, the appropriate next step may be to repeat the muscle relaxant to ensure adequate muscle paralysis for the procedure.

choices.text: Horizontal line through the angle of the mandible

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a lump under her jaw. On examination, the lump is found to be associated with the submandibular gland. Which structure separates the superficial and deep lobes of the submandibular gland?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mylohyoid muscle

 

  • The mylohyoid muscle separates the superficial and deep lobes of the submandibular gland. 
  • The submandibular gland wraps around the posterior edge of the mylohyoid muscle, forming its superficial and deep parts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyoid bone: The hyoid bone is located in the anterior neck and does not play a role in separating the lobes of the submandibular gland.

 

Option B. Posterior belly of digastric: The posterior belly of the digastric muscle is located near the submandibular gland, but it does not separate the superficial and deep lobes of the gland.

 

Option D. Horizontal line through the angle of mandible: A horizontal line through the angle of the mandible is an anatomical reference but does not separate the superficial and deep lobes of the gland

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The mylohyoid muscle separates the superficial and deep lobes of the submandibular gland.

choices.text: Direct osteolytic metastasis causing bone resorption
Secretion of parathyroid hormone–related peptide (PTHrP) by tumor cells
Ectopic secretion of intact parathyroid hormone
Increased synthesis of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D (calcitriol) by tumor macrophages

questions.text: A 65-year-old man, chronic smoker, presents with persistent cough, hemoptysis, and weight loss for 3 months. Chest X-ray shows a hilar mass in the right lung. Biopsy of the lesion shows polygonal cells with intercellular bridges and keratin pearls. Serum studies reveal hypercalcemia, but PTH levels are suppressed. Which of the following is the cause of hypercalcemia in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Secretion of parathyroid hormone–related peptide (PTHrP) by tumor cells

 

  • This 65-year-old chronic smoker with persistent cough, hemoptysis, weight loss, and a right hilar mass showing polygonal cells with intercellular bridges and keratin pearls has squamous cell carcinoma of the lung.
  • Squamous cell carcinoma is strongly associated with paraneoplastic hypercalcemia due to ectopic production of parathyroid hormone–related peptide (PTHrP) by tumor cells.

 

Mechanism:

 

  • PTHrP mimics the actions of PTH on bone and kidney:
    • Increases bone resorption → releases calcium into circulation.
    • Increases renal calcium reabsorption and phosphate excretion.
  • Unlike true PTH, PTHrP does not increase 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D (calcitriol) synthesis in the kidney.
  • As a result, serum calcium is elevated, but PTH is suppressed due to feedback inhibition.
  • Thus, the hypercalcemia in this case is paraneoplastic, caused by tumor secretion of PTHrP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct osteolytic metastasis causing bone resorption: Incorrect. This mechanism is seen in breast cancer, multiple myeloma, and renal cell carcinoma, where bone metastases cause local bone destruction. In this case, the hilar mass (primary lung lesion) with keratin pearls suggests squamous cell carcinoma, not osteolytic metastasis.

 

Option C. Ectopic secretion of intact parathyroid hormone: Incorrect. Ectopic production of intact PTH is extremely rare in malignancy. PTH levels are suppressed in this patient, ruling this out.

 

Option D. Increased synthesis of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D (calcitriol) by tumor macrophages: Incorrect. This occurs in lymphomas (especially Hodgkin lymphoma), where macrophages express 1α-hydroxylase, increasing calcitriol and promoting calcium absorption from the gut. Not seen in lung squamous carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung causes paraneoplastic hypercalcemia via ectopic secretion of PTH-related peptide (PTHrP), leading to increased bone resorption and renal calcium reabsorption with suppressed PTH levels.

choices.text: Tab Chloroquine 600mg stat, then 300mg after 6 hours, followed by 300mg daily for 2 days
Tab Paracetamol 500mg TDS, adequate fluid intake, and platelet monitoring
Tab Doxycycline 100mg BD for 7 days with supportive care
Tab Artemether- Lumefantrine therapy for 3 days

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman from a village in tribal area of Madhya Pradesh presents with high-grade fever, headache, and myalgia for 5 days. Local health workers have identified the mosquito larvae shown in the image breeding in water storage containers around her house. What is the most appropriate first-line treatment for the likely condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tab Paracetamol 500mg TDS, adequate fluid intake, and platelet monitoring

 

  • The image shows Aedes aegypti larvae, identifiable by their characteristic siphon tube and tendency to hang from the water surface at an angle. 
  • The clinical presentation of fever, headache, and myalgia in an endemic area with confirmed Aedes breeding strongly suggests dengue fever. 
  • Treatment for dengue is supportive, including paracetamol for fever (avoiding aspirin due to bleeding risk), adequate hydration, and monitoring for complications like thrombocytopenia and plasma leakage.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tab Chloroquine 600mg stat, then 300mg after 6 hours, followed by 300mg daily for 2 days: Chloroquine is antimalarial therapy, inappropriate for dengue fever caused by Aedes aegypti

 

Option C. Tab Doxycycline 100mg BD for 7 days with supportive care: Doxycycline is used for rickettsial diseases or scrub typhus, not dengue fever

 

Option D. Tab Artemether- Lumefantrine therapy for 3 days: Artemether-Lumefantrine is antimalarial combination therapy, not indicated for dengue

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aedes aegypti larvae are identified by their siphon tube and surface-hanging behavior in clean water collections
  • Dengue fever requires supportive treatment with paracetamol, hydration, and monitoring for complications

choices.text: Discharge with symptomatic treatment and follow-up
Report to child protective services and admit for neuro-monitoring

questions.text: A 2-month-old baby is brought by the parents with history of seizures. CT scan reveals subdural hemorrhage without any skull fracture. A bloody cerebrospinal fluid tap is obtained, and MRI reveals delayed white matter myelination. Ophthalmic exam confirms retinal hemorrhages. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Report to child protective services and admit for neuro-monitoring

 

  • This clinical scenario is highly suspicious for non-accidental trauma (NAT), specifically Shaken Baby Syndrome (SBS). 
  • The classic triad includes:
    • Subdural hemorrhage
    • Retinal hemorrhages
    • Neurologic symptoms (e.g., seizures, altered consciousness)

 

 

  • The absence of external trauma with intracranial bleeding and retinal hemorrhages—especially in a non-mobile infant—warrants mandatory reporting to child protective services. 
  • Immediate inpatient care with neuro-monitoring is essential due to the risk of ongoing or worsening brain injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Discharge with symptomatic treatment and follow-up: Dangerous and inappropriate. This ignores the signs of potential abuse and could place the child at risk for further harm or death.

 

Option B. Platelet transfusion and intravenous antibiotics: No evidence supports thrombocytopenia or infection. The etiology is traumatic, not infectious or hematologic.

 

Option D. Lumbar puncture followed by anticonvulsants: LP is contraindicated in suspected raised intracranial pressure (ICP), and seizures must be managed, but that’s secondary to addressing the cause (abuse).

 

Educational Objective:

 

In any infant presenting with seizures, subdural hemorrhage, and retinal hemorrhages, always suspect Shaken Baby Syndrome. Immediate reporting to child protection services and hospital admission is a medicolegal and ethical obligation.

questions.text: A 34 year old woman at 8 weeks of gestation requests medical termination of pregnancy. Which of the following methods is not appropriate for first-trimester MTP?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Extra-amniotic instillation of ethacridine lactate

 

This 34-year-old woman at 8 weeks of gestation is seeking medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) in the first trimester.
According to the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act and standard obstetric guidelines, the recommended methods for first-trimester MTP (up to 12 weeks) include:

 

  1. Medical methods:
    • Mifepristone (antiprogestin) + Misoprostol (prostaglandin E1 analogue)
      → Effective, safe, and widely used for termination up to 9–12 weeks.
  2. Surgical methods:
    • Manual Vacuum Aspiration (MVA) or
    • Dilatation and Evacuation (D&E) → Both suitable and effective up to 12 weeks of gestation.

 

The extra-amniotic instillation of ethacridine lactate is obsolete and not appropriate for first-trimester MTP.

 

  • It is used for second-trimester terminations (13–20 weeks) because it requires an adequately enlarged uterine cavity to instill the solution.
  • At 8 weeks, the uterine cavity is too small, increasing the risk of uterine perforation and incomplete evacuation.

 

Hence, the most appropriate answer is D. Extra-amniotic instillation of ethacridine lactate — it is not suitable for first-trimester termination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mifepristone plus misoprostol: Correct method (for first trimester). Combination of 200 mg mifepristone orally, followed 24–48 hours later by 800 µg misoprostol vaginally or orally, is safe and effective for medical abortion up to 9–12 weeks.

 

Option B. Manual vacuum aspiration: Correct method (for first trimester).
MVA is a safe surgical technique used for termination up to 12 weeks, with minimal complications and rapid recovery.

 

Option C. Dilatation and evacuation: Correct method (for first trimester). D&E is a surgical method also used up to 12 weeks, though gradually being replaced by MVA due to fewer complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Extra-amniotic instillation of ethacridine lactate is used for second-trimester MTP (13–20 weeks) and not appropriate for first-trimester termination, where mifepristone + misoprostol, MVA, or D&C are preferred safe methods.

questions.text: A patient has a tumor in his right lobe of liver. A right hemi-hepatectomy is planned. What segments will be resected in this procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 5, 6, 7, 8

 

  • In a right hemi-hepatectomy, the entire right anatomical lobe of the liver is resected. 
  • This corresponds to Couinaud segments 5, 6, 7, and 8.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Couinaud’s classification divides the liver into 8 functionally independent segments based on vascular inflow, outflow, and biliary drainage.
  • Right hemi-hepatectomy removes segments 5–8, preserving the left lobe (segments 2–4) and often segment 1 (caudate), unless specifically involved.

choices.text: Give a bolus of 10ml/kg Hartmann solution
Give normal saline in the remaining period

questions.text: A child with 20% burns is resuscitated as per Parklands equation. After 6 hours his urine output is 0.3ml/kg/hour, and his vitals are unstable with cool extremities. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Give a bolus of 10 mL/kg Hartmann solution

 

  • In this scenario, the child is under-resuscitated: low urine output (<0.5 mL/kg/hr), unstable vitals, and cool extremities suggest hypoperfusion.
  • This is a standard response to inadequate perfusion during burn resuscitation. 
  • Hartmann’s (Ringer’s lactate) is preferred for volume expansion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Give colloids: Not first-line in the first 24 hours post-burn. Capillary leak is ongoing; colloids may extravasate and worsen edema.

 

Option B. Wait for 2 hours and reassess: Delaying resuscitation in a child with signs of shock is dangerous. Immediate action is needed.

 

Option D. Give normal saline in the remaining period: NS is not preferred due to risk of hyperchloremic acidosis. Also, this doesn’t address the acute hypoperfusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Urine output <0.5 mL/kg/hr in a burn patient signals inadequate fluid resuscitation.
  • Hartmann’s solution is the fluid of choice for bolus resuscitation in burns, especially in the first 24 hours.

choices.text: In differentiating between suicidal and homicidal cuts
In estimating postmortem interval based on drying pattern of wounds
In confirming site of impact in vehicular collision trauma
In diagnosing thermal injuries in explosion victims

questions.text: In which forensic context would the presence of flaying injuries on the legs be most significant?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) In confirming site of impact in vehicular collision trauma

 

  • Flaying injuries are a specific type of avulsion injury involving extensive removal of skin, most commonly seen on the legs in road traffic accidents.

 

 

  • These injuries occur when the limbs strike or are dragged across rough surfaces, such as road pavement, during high-speed collisions. 
  • Their location and pattern can help forensic experts confirm the point and side of impact, direction of force, and even potential contact with vehicle surfaces like bumpers or wheels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. In differentiating between suicidal and homicidal cuts: Suicidal and homicidal cuts are typically incised wounds, not avulsion-type. Flaying injuries have no diagnostic value in assessing intent (suicide vs homicide), as they result from mechanical trauma, not self-infliction.

 

Option B. In estimating postmortem interval based on drying pattern of wounds: While certain wound changes can assist in estimating time since death, flaying injuries do not play a significant role in this. The drying pattern of lacerations or abrasions is more relevant.

 

Option D. In diagnosing thermal injuries in explosion victims: Flaying injuries are mechanical, not thermal. Burn injuries involve charring, blistering, or tissue necrosis due to heat exposure, not skin detachment from forceful trauma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Flaying injuries are large skin avulsions most frequently observed on the legs in road traffic accidents. 
  • Their presence and pattern can provide critical information in reconstructing the mechanism and site of impact during forensic analysis.

questions.text: Which of the following non‑fermenting Gram‑negative bacilli is lysine decarboxylase positive?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Burkholderia cepacia

 

  • Burkholderia cepacia is a non‑fermenting, oxidase‑positive, lysine‑positive Gram‑negative bacillus. 
  • It belongs to the Burkholderia cepacia complex (BCC), a group of opportunistic pathogens known for causing infections in immunocompromised patients and those with cystic fibrosis or chronic granulomatous disease.
  • The organism can decarboxylate lysine due to the presence of lysine decarboxylase enzyme, which differentiates it biochemically from several other non‑fermenters.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Burkholderia pseudomallei: Though biochemically similar, B. pseudomallei (causative agent of melioidosis) is lysine‑negative and can be differentiated from B. cepacia by its distinct colony morphology and bipolar “safety‑pin” appearance on microscopy.

 

Option C. Acinetobacter baumannii: This organism is oxidase‑negative and non‑motile, typically lysine‑negative. It is an important nosocomial pathogen causing ventilator‑associated pneumonia and bacteremia, especially in ICU settings.

 

Option D. Pseudomonas aeruginosa: Although a classic non‑fermenter, P. aeruginosa does not decarboxylate lysine. It is arginine‑positive and produces pyocyanin pigment—key diagnostic features used in differentiation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Among the non‑fermenting Gram‑negative bacilli, only Burkholderia cepacia is lysine decarboxylase positive, a feature that aids its laboratory identification and distinction from other opportunistic pathogens like Pseudomonas and Acinetobacter.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman who has not seen a doctor in over 20 years presents with dyspnea on exertion and is found to have an oxygen saturation of 92%. Her chest X-ray, PFTs and CT scan are normal. Echocardiogram demonstrates an EF of 54% with normal valves and RVSP of 55 mmHg, and right heart catheterization reveals a PCWP of 13 mmHg and mean pulmonary artery pressure of 35 mmHg. What is the most likely cause of her dyspnea?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension

 

  • Elevated RVSP and mean pulmonary artery pressure with normal PCWP and echocardiogram findings are characteristic features of pre-capillary pulmonary hypertension, most consistent with idiopathic PAH.
  • The absence of imaging or PFT findings for interstitial lung disease and a normal ejection fraction exclude ILD and heart failure as causes.
  • COPD typically shows obstructive patterns on PFTs, which are not present here, and would not account for the hemodynamic findings noted on right heart catheterization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. COPD: Would show obstructive changes on PFTs, not found in this patient, and would not account for her normal imaging and right heart findings.

 

Option B. Heart failure: Generally causes an elevated PCWP and may show a reduced EF or left-sided filling pressures, which are normal in this patient.

 

Option D. ILD: Would usually present with significant restrictive findings on PFTs and radiographic interstitial changes; both are absent here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Idiopathic PAH is identified by elevated pulmonary artery pressures on right heart catheterization, normal left-sided heart pressures, and exclusion of left heart and lung disease on imaging and PFTs; right heart catheterization is essential for diagnosis.

questions.text: What is the name of this technique of mask ventilation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) C and E technique 

 

  • The image depicts a technique commonly used in medical settings during bag and mask ventilation. 
  • The technique illustrated is known as the "C and E Technique," which is a method employed during Bag-Valve-Mask (BVM) ventilation.
  • This approach is utilized to maintain an open airway and ensure effective ventilation in patients who are not breathing adequately or at all. 
  • The "C and E" refers to the hand placement:
    • "C" represents the shape formed by the thumb and index finger, which are placed on the mask to create an airtight seal against the patient's face.
    • "E" signifies the remaining fingers (middle, ring, and little fingers) that are positioned under the mandible (jawbone) to lift and thrust the jaw forward.
    • This maneuver helps in keeping the airway open by preventing the tongue from occluding the oropharynx.
    • The thumb and index fingers pressing against the mask while the other fingers lift the jaw forms the distinctive "C" and "E" shapes, hence the name. 
    • The jaw thrust achieved by the "E" fingers is vital as it elevates the tongue off the back wall of the throat, reducing airway obstruction and facilitating better airflow during artificial ventilation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The technique depicted in the image is known as the 'C and E technique' for mask ventilation during bag-valve-mask (BVM) ventilation. 
  • This technique involves forming a 'C' shape with the thumb and index finger to create an airtight mask seal and using the remaining fingers to lift and thrust the jaw forward ('E' shape) to maintain an open airway, preventing tongue obstruction during artificial ventilation.

choices.text: Downregulation of GnRH receptors leading to decreased gonadotropin release
Decreased sensitivity of target organs to gonadotropins

questions.text: Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) when administered in continuous fashion versus pulsatile fashion has different therapeutic effects. What is the primary mechanism behind continuous GnRH administration?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Downregulation of GnRH receptors leading to decreased gonadotropin release

 

  • Continuous GnRH administration causes receptor downregulation and desensitization, leading to paradoxical suppression of gonadotropin release.
  • This mechanism is therapeutically exploited in conditions requiring sex hormone suppression like prostate cancer, breast cancer, and endometriosis. 
  • Pulsatile administration maintains normal receptor sensitivity and hormone release.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Continuous GnRH administration paradoxically suppresses the reproductive axis through receptor desensitization.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents with subacute onset of cognitive dysfunction, confusion, and intractable seizures. He has multiple abnormal movements and rapid neurological deterioration. Anti-Hu antibodies are detected in his serum and CSF. Brain MRI is unremarkable. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Whole body PET scan

 

  • Anti-Hu antibody–associated autoimmune encephalitis is strongly paraneoplastic, most commonly linked to small cell lung cancer, but can be associated with other occult malignancies.​
  • After confirming anti-Hu positivity, whole body PET is the most sensitive test for cancer screening to identify occult malignancy not evident on standard imaging.
  • The results guide both cancer-directed therapy and immunosuppression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chest CT with contrast: Chest CT with contrast may miss non-pulmonary malignancies; PET scan is more comprehensive.

 

Option C. EEG: EEG can support diagnosis of encephalitis but does not guide the search for underlying cancer at this stage.

 

Option D. Repeat brain MRI with contrast: Repeat MRI is usually not helpful when prior MRI is unremarkable and anti-Hu confirmed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In anti-Hu–mediated autoimmune encephalitis, comprehensive cancer screening with a whole body PET scan is critical after antibody confirmation, due to the high risk of underlying malignancy; timely detection allows for treatment of both the tumor and encephalitic syndrome.

choices.text: Conduct vulnerability assessment and hazard mapping

questions.text: A district health officer is reviewing the disaster management preparedness following recent flash floods in a rural area. The immediate response phase has been completed with rescue operations and emergency medical care. The community now requires restoration of basic health services and temporary shelter arrangements. What would be the next best step in the disaster management cycle?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Initiate recovery and rehabilitation activities

 

  • In the disaster management cycle, after the immediate response phase (rescue, emergency medical care, evacuation), the next logical step is recovery and rehabilitation. 
  • This phase focuses on restoring essential services, providing temporary shelter, rehabilitating health infrastructure, and helping the community return to normalcy. 
  • Recovery activities include restoration of healthcare facilities, ensuring safe water supply, temporary housing arrangements, and psychological support.
  • The other options represent activities from different phases: vulnerability assessment (preparedness phase), early warning systems (mitigation/preparedness phase), and training programs (preparedness phase).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conduct vulnerability assessment and hazard mapping: Vulnerability assessment and hazard mapping are components of the preparedness phase, conducted before disasters occur to identify risks and plan mitigation strategies.

 

Option C. Develop early warning systems: Early warning systems are established during the mitigation and preparedness phases to provide advance notice of potential disasters, not after the immediate response.

 

Option D. Establish disaster preparedness training programs: Disaster preparedness training programs are part of the preparedness phase, aimed at building capacity before disasters strike, not during post-disaster recovery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The disaster management cycle consists of four phases: mitigation, preparedness, response, and recovery/rehabilitation
  • Recovery phase immediately follows the response phase and focuses on restoring normalcy and essential services
  • Each phase has specific objectives and activities that must be implemented in proper sequence for effective disaster management
  • Understanding the cyclical nature helps in appropriate resource allocation and timely intervention during different disaster phases

questions.text: A 50-year-old female has recently undergone total thyroidectomy for a thyroid mass. The histopathological examination shows papillary thyroid cancer. What would be the further management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Radioiodine scan

 

  • After a total thyroidectomy for papillary thyroid cancer, the usual next step is a radio-iodine scan to look for metastasis.
  • After total thyroidectomy for papillary thyroid cancer, a radioiodine scan (also known as I-123 or RAI scan) is often used to detect any remaining thyroid tissue or metastatic disease. 
  • It can also aid in planning for subsequent radioactive iodine therapy, if necessary, to ablate residual tissue or treat metastatic disease. 
  • The patient is usually given a dose of radioactive iodine, which is taken up by any remaining thyroid cells, and then imaging is done to determine the distribution of the radioactivity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Post-operative calcitonin and CEA: Incorrect. They are performed in medullary thyroid cancer. In PTC, serum Thyroglobulin is done.

 

Option C. Lugol’s iodine supplement: Incorrect. This is used in preoperative preparation of patients with thyrotoxicosis.

 

Option D. Chemotherapy: Incorrect for early and most intermediate stages. Chemotherapy isn't a standard treatment for most thyroid cancers. However, it might be recommended for people who don't respond to standard treatments and for certain types of aggressive thyroid cancers.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Radioiodine scan to detect any remaining thyroid tissue and potential metastasis usually after 3-6 weeks. 
  • Based on the findings, further therapeutic radioactive iodine might be administered. 
  • Regular follow-up, including blood tests and imaging studies, will be necessary to monitor for any recurrence or metastasis.

choices.text: It is the most common cause of gas gangrene
The organism shows a positive Nagler reaction
The most common toxin is hyaluronidase
Food poisoning strains produce heat-resistant spores

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the Clostridium perfringens is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The most common toxin is hyaluronidase

 

  • Clostridium perfringens is the most common cause of gas gangrene (clostridial myonecrosis). 
  • It is a gram-positive, spore-forming, anaerobic bacillus found in soil and the intestinal tract.
  • The major toxin responsible for tissue destruction and systemic toxicity is the α-toxin (lecithinase or phospholipase C), which hydrolyzes cell membrane phospholipids, leading to massive hemolysis, vascular injury, and necrosis.
  • Hyaluronidase is indeed produced by C. perfringens, but it is a spreading factor, not the main toxin responsible for gas gangrene pathology.
  • The Nagler reaction, a test for α-toxin (lecithinase), is characteristically positive for C. perfringens.
  • Food poisoning strains (Type A) form heat-resistant spores, which survive cooking and germinate in inadequately reheated food.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is the most common cause of gas gangrene: True. C. perfringens, especially Type A strain, is the major cause of traumatic gas gangrene and soft tissue infection.

 

Option B. The organism shows a positive Nagler reaction: True. The Nagler reaction detects α-toxin (lecithinase) on egg yolk agar; neutralization with specific antitoxin confirms the result.

 

Option D. Food poisoning strains produce heat-resistant spores: True. The enterotoxin-producing strains (Type A) cause food poisoning due to survival of heat-resistant spores in cooked meat or gravy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The α-toxin (lecithinase) is the principal virulence factor of Clostridium perfringens in gas gangrene, causing cell lysis, hemolysis, and tissue necrosis.
  • Hyaluronidase acts only as a spreading factor and is not the main toxin.

choices.text: Relative risk = 8.0; There is 8 times higher risk of acute kidney injury in exposed children
Relative risk = 5.3; There is 5.3 times higher risk of acute kidney injury in exposed children
Relative risk = 0.4; There is 60% lower risk of acute kidney injury in exposed children
Relative risk = 2.67; There is 2.67 times higher risk of acute kidney injury in exposed children

questions.text: During an outbreak investigation of acute kidney injury in children, epidemiologists found that among 200 children who consumed contaminated cough syrup, 80 developed acute kidney injury. Among 300 children who did not consume the contaminated cough syrup, 15 developed acute kidney injury. What is the relative risk of developing acute kidney injury among children who consumed contaminated cough syrup compared to those who did not, and how should this be interpreted?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Relative risk = 8.0; There is 8 times higher risk of acute kidney injury in exposed children

 

  • To calculate relative risk (RR), we use the formula: RR = (Risk in exposed group)/(Risk in unexposed group). 
  • Risk in exposed group = 80/200 = 0.4 (40%)
  • Risk in unexposed group = 15/300 = 0.05 (5%)
  • Relative Risk = 0.4/0.05 = 8.0
  • This means children who consumed contaminated cough syrup have 8 times higher risk of developing acute kidney injury compared to those who did not consume it. 
  • A relative risk of 8.0 indicates a very strong association between exposure (contaminated cough syrup) and outcome (acute kidney injury), which is consistent with a causative relationship in an outbreak scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Relative risk quantifies the strength of association between exposure and disease outcome in cohort studies and outbreak investigations
  • RR > 1 indicates increased risk in exposed group, RR = 1 indicates no association, and RR < 1 indicates protective effect
  • In outbreak investigations, high relative risk values (>5) suggest strong causal relationship between exposure and disease
  • Proper calculation requires clear identification of exposed/unexposed groups and accurate attack rates in both groups

choices.text: Great auricular and lesser occipital nerves
Ventral rami of C1 to C3 spinal nerves
Small sensory branches from the dorsal rami of C1 to C3 spinal nerves

questions.text: The foramen indicated by the arrow in the image is surrounded by structures receiving sensory innervation from which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Small sensory branches from the dorsal rami of C1 to C3 spinal nerves

 

  • The foramen magnum (shown by the arrow) is the large opening at the base of the skull through which the medulla oblongata, meninges, vertebral arteries, and spinal roots of the accessory nerves pass.
  • The skin around the foramen magnum receives sensory innervation from small branches of the dorsal rami of the C1–C3 spinal nerves (suboccipital, greater occipital, and third occipital nerves).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Great auricular and lesser occipital nerves: The great auricular and lesser occipital nerves supply the parotid region and posterior ear, not the posterior scalp near the foramen magnum.

 

Option B. Ventral rami of C1 to C3 spinal nerves: The ventral rami of C1–C3 form the cervical plexus, which supplies the anterior and lateral neck, not the region around the foramen magnum.


Option C. Glossopharyngeal nerve and vagus nerve: The glossopharyngeal and vagus nerves supply mucosa of the pharynx and larynx, not the external occipital or suboccipital skin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The posterior scalp and skin surrounding the foramen magnum are innervated by small sensory branches from the dorsal rami of C1–C3 spinal nerves.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with vertical diplopia following a motor vehicle accident. On examination, there is hypertropia of the right eye in primary gaze. The vertical deviation increases when the patient looks to the left. On performing the Bielschowsky head tilt test, the hypertropia worsens when the head is tilted to the right shoulder. Which extraocular muscle is most likely paretic?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Right superior oblique 

 

  • This patient’s vertical strabismus can be analyzed using Parks three-step test to identify the paretic muscle:
    • Step 1 – Identify hypertropic eye: The right eye is higher, suggesting weakness of a right depressor (Rt inferior rectus or Rt superior oblique) or left elevators (Lt superior rectus or Lt inferior oblique).
    • Step 2 – Assess horizontal gaze: Hypertropia worsens on left gaze (opposite gaze), indicating weakness of a muscle whose vertical action is maximal in adduction (Rt superior oblique) or indicating weakness of a muscle whose vertical action is maximal in abduction (Lt superior rectus).
    • Step 3 – Bielschowsky head tilt test (BHTT): Hypertropia worsens on right head tilt (same side as hypertropic eye), consistent with right superior oblique weakness, as the unopposed extorters exaggerate the deviation.
  • So, Right hypertropia + worse on opposite gaze + worse on same-side head tilt = right superior oblique palsy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right superior rectus:

 

  • Elevates the eye in abduction, not adduction.
  • Hypertropia would worsen on right gaze, not left.
  • Head tilt to the opposite side (left) would worsen diplopia — inconsistent with findings.

 

Option C. Left inferior rectus:

 

  • Depresses the left eye in abduction.
  • If weak, left hypertropia (not right) would result, and deviation would worsen on right gaze — opposite of this case.

 

Option D. Left inferior oblique:

 

  • Elevates the left eye in adduction.
  • Weakness would cause left hypotropia (not right hypertropia) and worsen on left head tilt — again opposite of findings.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Superior oblique palsy produces vertical diplopia, hypertropia, and excyclotorsion of the affected eye.
  • The Bielschowsky head tilt test helps localize the lesion — hypertropia worsens on ipsilateral head tilt.
  • Mnemonic: SIN RAD SOLID – Superiors are Intorters, Recti are Adductors, Superior Oblique: Lateral, Intorsion, Depression.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the Lisfranc ligament is incorrect?

 

  1. It connects the medial cuneiform to the base of the second metatarsal.
  2. It is one of the cuneometatarsal interosseous ligaments.
  3. It is the weakest among the three cuneometatarsal interosseous ligaments.
  4. Its disruption can lead to instability and deformity of the tarsometatarsal joint.
  5. It extends from the lateral cuneiform to the base of the fifth metatarsal.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3 and 5 are incorrect

 

  • The Lisfranc ligament is a strong interosseous cuneometatarsal ligament that extends from the medial cuneiform to the base of the second metatarsal. 
  • It is the strongest of the cuneometatarsal interosseous ligaments and provides essential stability to the tarsometatarsal (Lisfranc) joint complex.
  • Disruption or injury to this ligament—often called a Lisfranc injury—results in instability, pain, and deformity of the midfoot. 
  • Such injuries commonly occur following twisting trauma, falls, or crush injuries to the foot.

 

 

Statement 3. It is the weakest among the three cuneometatarsal interosseous ligaments: Incorrect. The Lisfranc ligament is the strongest, not the weakest.

 

Statement 5. It extends from the lateral cuneiform to the base of the fifth metatarsal: Incorrect. The ligament does not extend from the lateral cuneiform to the fifth metatarsal; that description is anatomically false.

 

Correct Statements:

 

Statement 1. It connects the medial cuneiform to the base of the second metatarsal: Correct. It truly connects the medial cuneiform to the base of the second metatarsal.

 

Statement 2. It is one of the cuneometatarsal interosseous ligaments: Correct. It belongs to the group of cuneometatarsal interosseous ligaments.

 

Statement 4. Its disruption can lead to instability and deformity of the tarsometatarsal joint: Correct. Its injury causes tarsometatarsal joint instability and deformity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Lisfranc ligament is a strong interosseous ligament connecting the medial cuneiform to the base of the second metatarsal, providing crucial midfoot stability. 
  • It is the strongest cuneometatarsal ligament, and its rupture leads to tarsometatarsal instability and deformity known as Lisfranc injury.

questions.text: Which drug combination is contraindicated in the management of heart failure due to risk of severe bradycardia and AV block?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Verapamil + Metoprolol

 

  • Verapamil (or diltiazem) plus beta-blockers (e.g. metoprolol) is contraindicated due to additive negative effects on heart rate and AV conduction. 
  • Both slow SA node firing and AV conduction, risking severe bradycardia, high-degree AV block, or asystole. 
  • Both also have negative inotropic effects that can worsen heart failure. 
  • This combination is absolutely contraindicated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enalapril + Telmisartan: Although generally not recommended, but this combination increases risk of hyperkalemia and hypotension. It does not cause bradycardia/AV block.

 

Option C. Digoxin + Spironolactone: Commonly used combination; not contraindicated. Complementary mechanisms - digoxin for inotropy, spironolactone for mortality reduction. Monitor potassium.

 

Option D. Furosemide + Epleronone: Standard beneficial combination. Loop diuretics with aldosterone antagonists are routinely combined with potassium monitoring.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Verapamil/diltiazem should NEVER be combined with beta-blockers due to additive negative chronotropic and dromotropic effects.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease is admitted for evaluation of cardiac performance. His oxygen consumption (VO₂) is measured at 250 mL O₂/min. The oxygen content of his pulmonary vein (systemic arterial blood) is 0.20 mL O₂/mL blood, and the oxygen content of his pulmonary artery (mixed venous blood) is 0.15 mL O₂/mL blood. What is this patient’s cardiac output?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 5.0 L/min

 

  • This problem is based on the Fick Principle, which states that:

 

 

 

  • Thus, the cardiac output is 5 L/min, which is within the normal physiologic range for an adult at rest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • According to the Fick Principle, cardiac output is calculated as:

 

 

  • It reflects the relationship between total body oxygen consumption and the oxygen extraction difference between arterial and venous blood.
  • Increased oxygen extraction (wider A–V O₂ difference) → low cardiac output
  • Decreased oxygen extraction (narrow A–V O₂ difference) → high cardiac output
  • This principle is fundamental for hemodynamic assessment in critical care and cardiology.

questions.text: A 45-year-old immunocompromised patient develops cryptococcal meningitis. Which of the following represents the most appropriate initial treatment regimen?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amphotericin B with 5-Flucytosine

 

  • Amphotericin B is the drug of choice for cryptococcal meningitis during the acute induction phase, often combined with flucytosine for synergistic effect and to reduce total AMB dose requirements. 
  • Amphotericin B is a polyene antifungal that binds to ergosterol in fungal cell membranes, creating pores that lead to cell death, making it fungicidal. 
  • It represents the gold standard of antifungal therapy with effectiveness against practically all types of systemic mycoses. 
  • When combined with flucytosine, the therapy is typically limited to the first 2 weeks to avoid flucytosine's bone marrow toxicity. 
  • The major adverse effects of amphotericin B include nephrotoxicity (most important dose-related toxicity causing azotemia, reduced GFR, acidosis, hypokalemia), infusion-related reactions (chills, fever—most common immediate side effect), and anemia from bone marrow depression. 
  • Liposomal amphotericin B formulations are less nephrotoxic but significantly more expensive. 
  • After the acute phase is controlled with AMB, long-term maintenance therapy with oral fluconazole is used in AIDS patients to prevent relapse, as fluconazole has excellent CNS penetration and is preferred for fungal meningitis continuation therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluconazole monotherapy intravenously:  Is incorrect because while fluconazole is the preferred azole for fungal meningitis due to good CNS penetration, it is used for maintenance therapy after initial AMB treatment, not as first-line monotherapy for acute cryptococcal meningitis. Starting with fluconazole alone would be inadequate for severe infection in immunocompromised patients.

 

Option B. Itraconazole oral therapy: Is incorrect because itraconazole has poor CSF penetration and is not the drug of choice for cryptococcosis. Itraconazole is preferred for histoplasmosis, blastomycosis, sporotrichosis, and paracoccidioidomycosis, but amphotericin B is superior for cryptococcal infections.

 

Option D. Voriconazole oral therapy: Is incorrect because voriconazole is a second-generation triazole that is the drug of choice for invasive aspergillosis, not cryptococcal meningitis. Its indications include disseminated fluconazole-resistant Candida infections, Fusarium infections, and febrile neutropenia not responding to antibacterial therapy.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Cryptococcal meningitis requires initial treatment with amphotericin B (±flucytosine) followed by long-term fluconazole maintenance therapy; amphotericin B is the gold standard but causes significant nephrotoxicity.
